PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
* That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
* That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
* That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 49 citizens) and Sherry (from 66 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a refusal of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Knowles (from 12 citizens) and Parer (from 23 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
* That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
* That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
* That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
* That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
* That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
* That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of enquiry into
a) the export of Australian military hardware and services;
b) the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
c) the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the Senate to proposals to introduce a 15% consumption tax on gas, electricity, wood, transport fares and entertainment will create hardship for pensioners who have to pay this out of their pension. Many may have to do without heating, hot water and cooking.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will not agree to such a tax.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday questions were asked of me about the right of Senator McMullan, as a Parliamentary Secretary, to take certain steps in Senate proceedings, and I undertook to make a statement on the matter. When Senator McMullan was appointed as a Parliamentary Secretary, a paper was prepared, and was made available to honourable senators who inquired about the matter, setting out the procedural steps which Senator McMullan could not in his own right take because he is not a Minister. With the concurrence of the Senate I will incorporate the paper in Hansard at the end of this statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Apart from answering questions, which Senator McMullan has not attempted to do, the following are the procedural actions which, under the Standing Orders, only Ministers can take: moving the adjournment of the Senate; moving a motion without notice to rearrange the business on the Notice Paper; and tabling any document without leave. Whenever Senator McMullan has taken any of these actions, it has been assumed that he is acting on behalf of a Minister, although he has not always so indicated.

The ability of an honourable senator to act on behalf of another is recognised in the Standing Orders, and whenever a senator indicates that he or she is acting on behalf of another senator, that is invariably accepted by the Senate. I should point out that senators of all parties take advantage of this practice and that senators frequently act on behalf of other senators. If Senator McMullan indicates that he is acting on behalf of a Minister, therefore, the Chair will accept his right to do so.
The paper read as follows-
Senate Procedures and Parliamentary Secretaries

The appointment of parliamentary secretaries under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 has raised the question of the exercise and performance by Senators appointed to such offices of the powers and functions conferred upon ministers by the procedures of the Senate.

This question was raised on previous occasions when parliamentary secretaries or assistant ministers were appointed. Prior to the passage of the 1980 Act, these office-holders were appointed on various and doubtful bases, but the issues of principle are the same. The advice now given reflects in substance the past practices of the Senate.
The Senate's procedures as they affect ministers may be considered in relation to questions, legislation, other procedures and Estimates Committees.
Questions

The relevant Senate standing order (SO 72) provides for questions to be put to ministers relating to public affairs and to other Senators relating only to matters connected with the business on the Notice Paper of which such Senators have charge. There is also provision (SO 72(2)) for questions to chairmen of committees. Most of the questions which are put to ministers, therefore, cannot be put to other Senators.

Parliamentary secretaries could perhaps answer questions on behalf of ministers (see the discussion below on Senators acting on behalf of others), but the answering of questions involves significant principles of ministerial responsibility. The Senate has insisted on ministers accepting full personal responsibility for answers given on behalf of others, and ministers have been censured by the Senate on this basis. It would be necessary for the government to clarify the matter of responsibility if parliamentary secretaries are to answer questions.

It is suggested, therefore, that, if parliamentary secretaries are to answer questions, it would be best for the Senate to explicitly empower them to do so with the understanding that they are to be treated as ministers for the purposes of the Senate's procedures.
Legislation

The new procedures which were adopted by the Senate on 13 May 1987, and which are now contained in the new standing orders, draw no distinction between government bills and private Senators' bills; the same procedures apply to all legislation.
There is therefore no barrier to parliamentary secretaries introducing and conducting through the Senate any government bills.

The fact that parliamentary secretaries are office-holders of the executive government, although not ministers, is sufficient to place bills introduced by them on the Notice Paper as government business.
Other procedures
The standing orders confer upon ministers certain powers not possessed by other Senators, including:
* the ability to move the adjournment of the Senate at any time (SO 53(2))
* the ability to move a motion connected with the conduct of the business of the Senate at any time without notice (SO 56)
* the ability to table any document without order or leave (SOs 61 and 166).

In relation to these and other procedures, however, any Senator may act on behalf of another. The ability of a Senator to act on behalf of another is explicitly provided in relation to the moving of the adjournment of the Senate by a minister (SO 53(2)), the giving of notice (SO 76(4)), the moving of motions (SO 83(1)) and the moving or postponing of orders of the day (SO 97(3)).
If a Senator indicates that he or she is acting on behalf of another Senator, that statement is always accepted by the Senate.

There is no necessity, therefore, for any further authorisation of parliamentary secretaries to exercise and perform the powers and functions of ministers in relation to ordinary procedures. A parliamentary secretary need only indicate that he or she acts on behalf of a minister.
Estimates Committees

The relevant standing order relating to Estimates Committees (SO 26(13)) refers to the committees seeking explanations from ministers of state in the Senate, and the practice has been for a Senate minister to be in attendance except on rare occasions of unavoidable absence. It has always been regarded as desirable for a minister to be present to ensure that questions which appropriately should be answered by a minister are so answered.

When there was an assistant minister in 1971, however, that assistant minister acted for a minister at meetings of an Estimates Committee. Presumably this was on the basis of the general rule relating to a Senator acting for another. Such a procedure would have to be acceptable to the committee in the first instance and to the Senate.
Proposed order

If it is proposed to have parliamentary secretaries answer questions, it is suggested that any doubt about their participation in other proceedings also be resolved by the adoption of an order in the following terms:

That any Senator appointed a parliamentary secretary under the Parliamentary Secretaries Act 1980 may exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred upon ministers by the procedures of the Senate.
(Harry Evans)
11 April 1990

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, could I clarify one point? Have the Government amendments and the Committee amendments been moved together?
—Only the amendments recommended in the report of the Standing Committee have been moved.

—This is not a Bill with which I have been associated to date, but to make sure there is no misunderstanding I inform the chamber that I have been advised that the Government amendments are incorporated in those which I have moved as Committee amendments. There are no other Government amendments. There are Opposition and Australian Democrats amendments, some of which the Government will be supporting, but there are no other Government amendments. I hope that neither I nor the Temporary Chairman misled Senator Bell as a result of our choice of language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six sets of amendments are proposed by the Australian Democrats. The first set concerns the mandatory national code. The Democrat amendments that are numbered 1, 8, 9 and 11 are part of a set which is directed to the mandatory national code.

SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment states that the registration of providers should be subject to compliance with a code of conduct at a national minimum standard. That code should be contained in a schedule to the legislation. This code is supplied by the Australian Education Council (AEC), which comprises Commonwealth, State and Territory education Ministers. It is the current definitive statement on national conduct and standards and was agreed to by all governments in July 1990. The status of the code, however, is one of agreement only; it is not mandatory. If Australia is to recover its reputation in this area, the Democrats believe that national standards must be mandatory and they must be vigorously maintained. Our amendment is supported by students and providers. It is beyond my understanding why the Government and the other contributors in the Committee failed to recognise the importance of this.

At the moment there are two sets of national standards. The Australian Education Council and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee have each developed a code of conduct with set standards for providers of education services for overseas students. It has been agreed by the States and Territories that the first code will apply to all providers. The latter code, which is now being revised, applies to higher education institutions only. Obviously that is the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee's code.

It is only logical that a national code of conduct and minimum standards are enshrined in legislation. The Australian Democrats tried to achieve this position earlier through the committee process. The problem there was that the Department of Employment, Education and Training responded to the suggestion by saying that, apparently, all States and Territories had already agreed to the AEC code, so this type of provision was unnecessary.

New South Wales has legislated to require compliance with minimum standards. Such a thing requires national parallel legislation. If New South Wales has seen that it is necessary to do this, obviously its experience has pointed to that. The New South Wales code of practice became operational from 25 January 1990 and was a regulation under the New South Wales Fair Trading Act 1987. As such, it provides a perfect model, which illustrates the need to have such a code legislated. The code was developed after consultation with industry providers. It is a mandatory code of practice which requires providers to give an undertaking to uphold and comply with that code of practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell, do you simply intend to move that a new clause be inserted after clause 5, or do you intend to move a whole range of new clauses?
—I seek leave to move together amendments Nos 1, 8, 9 and 11, all of which are to do with the mandatory national code.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. After clause 5, page 3, insert following clause:
Conditions of registration
``5a. (1) The Minister may direct that the registration of a provider in accordance with section 5 is to be subject to compliance with the code set out in the Schedule.''
8. Clause 9, page 6, subclause (1), line 3, omit ``6, 7 or 8'', substitute, ``6, 7, 8 or the Schedule''.
9. Clause 18, page 9, after paragraph (b), add the following word and paragraph:
``; or (c) amending the Schedule''.
11. After clause 18, page 9, add the following Schedule:
``SCHEDULE
Section 5a
CODE OF CONDUCT AND NATIONAL MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR THE APPROVAL OF COMMONWEALTH, STATE AND TERRITORY INSTITUTIONS PROVIDING COURSES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS

All Commonwealth, State and Territory institutions providing courses for overseas students in accordance with the Education Services (Export Regulation) Act 1990 must comply with the following minimum standards to obtain and maintain registration under the Act:
(a) the institution must demonstrate that it is financially viable and has the necessary physical and human resources to ensure continuing provision of courses;
(b) the institution must have adequate indemnity procedures or meet appropriate fiduciary standards which ensure protection of fees and provision of services for which students have paid;
(c) the facilities of the institution must be adequate;
(d) the institution must have the capacity to deliver the nominated course(s);
(e) the institution must have appropriate student support services, including grievance mechanisms;
(f) fees paid to institutions for accommodation or living expenses must be protected;

(g) fees charged for higher education courses in publicly funded institutions must comply with the Commonwealth minimum indicative fee schedule. Non-government secondary schools must certify that fees have been determined on a full cost basis; and
(h) institutions must comply with nationally consistent course nomenclature and standards.''.

I have moved the amendments together because they are part of a set and are relevant to each other. As such, rather than waste the time of the Committee in having to deal with them separately, I thought it sensible to move them together. I have referred to the legislation in New South Wales, how it works and why it has been found necessary. I will describe what happens if an institution fails to comply with the mandatory code of practice. The institution will not be included on the register of approved full-fee studies, which is a prerequisite to obtaining a Commonwealth issued student visa. As such, the compulsion to comply with that code is well observed.

The fact that the Australian Education Council's code already has common agreement supports the requirement that this code should be adhered to, rather than being something new which is imposed. This is the code which should be adhered to by the providers. The Department of Employment, Education and Training put the position that it need not be mandatory, but the difficulty with that position is that members of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training were presented with not one document but three separate documents which apparently contained that code. In other words, there was confusion about what the code was. It was very difficult, therefore, to have a sensible conversation or even a sensible set of submissions with regard to that. There was no single set of AEC rules, so which document was the Department referring to when it gave us its answer?

That was a problem we encountered throughout the Committee's deliberations. It has been referred to already by both the coalition and the Government sides. We found it another difficulty with this particular consideration of the code. There had been no one set of codes, yet the Department was responding as if there were one. The Democrats have now obtained the definitive document. It provides standards agreed to by Commonwealth, State and Territory education Ministers at a meeting in Canberra in June 1990. That is the code which we propose to include in this legislation.

Finally, with regard to the need for national standards, we should note the comments made by Senator Bolkus, representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), in this chamber on 4 June 1991. In rejecting the thrust of the Industry Commission's draft report, which is entitled Exports of Education and which was released that day, Senator Bolkus stated on page 4211 of the Senate Hansard that the Minister is:

. . . concerned that the international education community is particularly sensitive about quality assurance matters and would reject Australia as a study destination were we to appear less than interested in accreditation and other educational quality issues.

I would suggest that that justifies the inclusion of an agreed national code of practice for education providers. I fail to see why there is any reticence to include this. It is a genuine national code which should be mandatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to indicate that the Opposition will be opposing all of the Democrat amendments. I do not profess to be an expert in the field, but just by having a quick glance at what is being proposed I note that the Minister may direct compliance with the code. That would seem immediately to introduce differential standards whereby some service providers have to comply with the code and others do not. The fatal vice of this whole approach is that, whilst they are noble aspirations and no doubt a worthy set of objectives, they would enable a government simply to tie up any institution with red tape in such a way that it could not move without ministerial approval.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply cannot accept the proposition that to have a requirement that the facilities of the institution must be adequate somehow constitutes a code of conduct. Normally there is a set of standards by which someone is aware of the obligations and then ensures that they comply. In a situation like this it would be impossible to make an honest self-assessment as to whether the facilities of the institution were adequate. One person might think they are, someone else may not think they are and there is endless disputation.

The Opposition does not regard this as a true code of conduct. It might be a set of objectives. We may well use those objectives as a guide to the approach that we take. To enshrine them in legislation in the way that the Democrats propose is simply a recipe for tying up the whole system in such a way that it would probably be strangled in due course.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government does not support these amendments. In the Government's view, the code is not necessary, given the roles of the States and Territories in the accreditation or registration process for the institutions offering courses to overseas students. There is also the fact that the States have indicated their agreement, through the Australian Education Council, to abide by the principles embodied in the proposed code in fulfilling that registration function.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that, in endeavouring to do something super well, we may do it less well than is currently envisaged. Trying to discharge the same process twice at different levels of government does not necessarily mean that the process will be done better. It may mean that one gets conflict about the conduct of that process and it will be done less well. The proposed amendments seem to have no significant potential to enhance the operation of the Act and some potential to make it less effective. Therefore, as it is not necessary, the Government does not support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have here an example of the sort of confusion that is brought about when people do not understand what this is all about. On the one hand we have the Opposition claiming that parts of the code cannot honestly stand up to scrutiny when, in fact, the Minister has reminded us that all State and Territory Ministers have agreed to comply with the code. If the Opposition's position is true, one wonders why there is such unanimity of agreement with the code. If the Government's position is true-that is, that it is unnecessary-one wonders why the Ministers have agreed with it.

SPEECH.PARA: One wonders also what would happen if those providers chose to dismiss it and not comply, as there are no sanctions. It may be a gentleperson's agreement between Ministers of the States, but the simple scene could be set where one State suddenly decides, with a change of government, to take itself off and to the disadvantage of its neighbour States operate outside the previously agreed code. That, of course, may attract considerable business to that State. That is the basic commercial strategy that could be followed. We have no constraints to apply if that were to happen. We have this gentleperson's agreement and we have one State-New South Wales-seeing the need to make compliance mandatory, yet we sit here and pontificate about its not being necessary. I think we are just ignoring the reality that the States have already recognised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Bell points out, if the institutions and the States were prepared to abide by a general set of objectives, we would have the best outcome, one that leaves regulation with the States. To superimpose another level of regulation, where we may well have different judgments being made on a subjective assessment, would be a recipe for disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 6, page 4, paragraph (3) (a), line 21, after ``person'', add ``and for the benefit of that person''.

Subclause 6(3) provides for moneys to be withdrawn from a special account. This may be for the purposes of health payments under subclause 6(3) (b) or for course fees under subclause 6(3) (c). Subclause 6(3) (a) refers to the third situation of withdrawal with the written authority of the person. The only acceptable basis for withdrawal under this provision is to access pre-paid accommodation and living allowances. It is therefore logical and correct to ensure that this withdrawal is with the authority and for the benefit of the person. Living expenses should not be used for other purposes.

This amendment is concerned not so much with the risk of duress, which we recognise as well, as the basic uneven bargaining power in the relationship. That is something which is not recognised sufficiently in the rules, regulations and legislation that we devise in this place. Somebody who is perhaps unsure of English to start with is certainly not likely to be well-informed about consumer rights or the opportunities for other sorts of negotiations to take place. It is an uneven bargaining situation and, therefore, we think the person at the short end of the stick would be well served if these words were included in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support this amendment either. The broader principle, as articulated by Senator Bell, relates not so much to this Bill but to an expression of concern that treating unequals equally can lead to an unjust outcome. It is one which, as a matter of principle and philosophy, I share. It is a problem that does arise with some proposals about public policy under debate at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not see, correct as that principle is, that it gets us over the hurdle of this particular amendment. The intent is worthy, but the best advice I have is that the insertion is not necessary. I do not think that it adds anything. The one thing it might do is add an illusion of comfort to the individual whom it is seeking to assist. But I do not think it in fact improves the situation. It is not necessary and we do not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition cannot support this amendment either. It certainly seems to me that, on the face of it, if one authorises a withdrawal then it is presumed to be for one's benefit, but if we were to get into a situation where someone else had to make a judgment about whether it was in fact for the benefit of the person withdrawing the moneys, then I would have thought again that would simply make the system that much more complex. We ought to presume that these things are going to be handled in a proper and sensible way and that people will withdraw only voluntarily.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 6, page 4, paragraph (4) (b), line 35, after ``course'' (first occurring), insert ``or is unable to continue the course''.

Minister Dawkins has acknowledged that further institutional collapses could occur, yet refunds are limited under subclause 6(4) to the situation where a student is unable to commence, or voluntarily withdraws from, a course. That is the only situation where refunds are able to be paid.

This covers the situation where a change in government policy prevents students from coming to Australia and, therefore, tries to prevent a repeat of the current taxpayer payout of over $50m to students left stranded at home after the tightening of these rules. The provision also means that a student who decides to drop out and work full time illegally, or a student who is perhaps poached by another provider, may claim a refund. However, the obvious and common situation where a student who has been attending an institution which then collapses is not covered.

The definition of `withdrawal' in the draft regulations clarifies the fact that withdrawal under subclause 6(4) is voluntary only: it is where a student states in writing that he or she wishes to withdraw. It is ludicrous that a student who decides to withdraw may seek a refund, yet a student who is stranded because of an institution's failure has no such right. It is a major omission and fundamental flaw that has to be rectified.

Subclause 6(4) serves to reinforce the obligation of providers to meet any refund. If it were extended to include the term `involuntary termination of studies', it could be construed as an acknowledgment of the government liability for all students who are currently stranded in Australia. I suspect that that is the danger. The Industry Commission suggested strongly-and we accept the suggestion-in a draft report released recently that this responsibility should be met by the Government. That is the report which causes Senator Tierney concern in that it is being considered concurrently with the legislation reaching this place, and I share his confusion about why we should be so dealing with this.

The Industry Commission also recommends that students should no longer be required by the Government to prepay funds and that institutions should not be government accredited. I am not so sure about that, but I can see why the report states that the required prepayment misleads students as to the safety of their prepaid funds and also leads to pressure on the Government to guarantee those funds. With accreditation, that is an assumption which could be easily understood.

The Government's current refund commitment extends to students who were attending institutions which collapsed, provided the students paid their money before-and this is a strange thing to understand-the Government's arbitrary cutoff date of 24 August 1990. The Government has decided to wash its hands of a further 4,000-plus overseas students who are also the victims of institutional collapses. Of course, none of these students were withdrawing voluntarily. That is why the Australian Democrats propose this amendment. The Democrats believe that the Government's responsibility to pay refunds should not be pinned on an arbitrary date. Looking ahead, the Government would best avoid liability by the logical extension of subclause 6(4) to students who are forced to discontinue their studies in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Government will not be supporting this amendment, because the broader view is that it does not necessarily achieve the purpose that is set out for it or add to the meaning of the subclause, I believe Senator Bell has raised some points that are worthy of further consideration. I cannot, and will not, support the amendment but I indicate to Senator Bell that it is matter that I have already indicated I will be seeking a review of by the Minister to ensure that the concerns that the honourable senator has raised and some other concerns that have occurred to me in looking at the wording are met. They may well be covered elsewhere, but I think these concerns need to be reviewed and the arguments that the honourable senator has put need to be examined. However, we will not be supporting this amendment as the mechanism to resolve the problem Senator Bell raises.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 6, page 4, subclause (4), line 38, after ``repay'', insert ``within 30 days after that non-commencement or withdrawal''.

Amendment No. 4 would place a time limit on refunds under subclause 6(4) and we seek to insert the words `within 30 days'. This subclause provides an obligation to repay and that obligation must be within a set time frame; if not, why bother repaying? That obligation can be extended forever. So we cannot see any reason why a time limit should not be placed on it.

An earlier statement by the Department of Employment, Education and Training in response to this was that the inclusion of a time limit was quite possible, although it raised three issues. First, a time limit would be interpreted as a maximum time available to defer a refund. That is fair enough. Some operators often see that; it applies to all sorts of limits that are seen as the maximum. I suggest that that is not a sufficient reason not to apply a limit. Secondly, the Department suggested that the time limit would have to vary according to course length and money owing. Thirdly, a penalty would be required removing the issue of non-compliance from State consumer affairs offices.

We believe that this time limit sets a normal commercial time period. It is not an excessive period and according to legal advice the same time limit should apply once any course is terminated. With respect to the third concern of the Department, I point out that the provision already contains a penalty of $5,000. None of those, as far as I am concerned, provides a reason for not establishing a normal commercial time limit. Without that time limit this aspect of the legislation is as vague as the rest of the legislation. There is very little reason for compliance with it. I suggest that this sort of limitation should be applied just to bring it within normal commercial practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that normal commercial practice was that these sorts of requirements were set down in the contracts between the parties and that is the fundamental reason why the Government is not supporting this amendment. We should not need to specify in this legislation a period for repayment. The appropriate mechanism is to deal with this in the contract between the institution and the student.

SPEECH.PARA: Going back to the point raised previously about the unequal status of the parties, my understanding is that part of the registration process conducted by the States is to examine aspects such as the policies of colleges and institutions with regard to this matter. Therefore, it is not the Government's view that it is necessary to have this sort of provision in this Bill and we will not support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what it is all about; this is why we sought to have the code of conduct included. It may well be that some institutions see fit to engage in a contract which includes normal commercial practice. It may also well be that some institutions seek to exploit students or that some institutions decide to venture into an area which cannot be sustained commercially and they collapse. Many of them have collapsed because they have made promises that they have been unable to sustain. Rather than presume, as the Minister has, that the sorts of contracts which will be entered into are, in fact, normal commercial practice, we would like to take the track record of this industry and say that a great number of the contracts that have been entered into have failed because either the institution has failed or the contracts have not been up to scratch as far as what is normally considered commercially honourable.

SPEECH.PARA: That is why this legislation was brought forward. That is what the Government told us was a reason for the introduction of this legislation-to bring some sort of regularity to this area, some sort of reliability to what was going on, some measurements. Yet here we have the Government afraid even to put in this legislation a normal commercial status of a time limit on refunds. I think that that is an admission that the legislation is as weak as water.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (2), line 13, omit ``each quarter'', substitute ``the conclusion of each half year''.
6. Clause 8, page 5, paragraph (2) (c), lines 24 to 26, omit ``quarter'' (wherever occurring), substitute ``half year''.
7. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (3), line 33, omit ``quarter or particular quarters'', substitute ``half year or particular half years''.

I move amendment No. 5 with not a great degree of enthusiasm because it provides an alternative to what I sense is a deal which is being cooked up between the coalition and the Government. I see a great lack of enthusiasm for our amendments so far. That is probably because the Government does not need to accept any of our amendments because the passage of the Bill is almost guaranteed. However, I will persist because this amendment is proposed as an alternative to the current onerous requirement of quarterly audits and the coalition's suggestions require annual returns only. It is a classic halfway position which, in our belief, is the right position.

Given the export education sector's record of and reputation for problems-its reputation has travelled overseas, where it is doing damage-whether of fraud, dishonesty or just institutional collapses for other reasons, the provision of six-monthly biannual returns would appear to strike an effective and logical compromise between the Government and the coalition's proposals.

The Democrats' position is, in fact, supported by the current provision which gives the Minister a discretion to request more frequent material, whether it is a follow-up to information provided in this return or otherwise. Under subclause 8 (4) the Minister may require information on the activities of the provider in connection with the recruitment and enrolment of intending overseas students and the provision of courses to those overseas students.

The coalition proposes, as I understand it, to delete subclause 8(4). Instead, it suggests a new subclause 8(2a) which would limit the Minister's discretion to further information in three cases: first, where a provider fails to provide even an annual return; secondly, where the Minister believes that an annual return contains misleading or deceptive information; and, thirdly, where the provider is a private provider who fails to comply with the financial requirements under clause 6.

Even with the requirement of quarterly returns, the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training noted that problems can always occur in between periods. The Minister may receive information about allegedly serious misbehaviour which does not involve the financial arrangements as described in clause 6. But according to the coalition's amendment, the Minister must sit on his hands and wait for an annual return. As far as I am concerned, that is not a satisfactory proposition. We propose quite simply that we attempt this compromise. Associated with that, our amendment No. 6 is to do with the review of the operation of the Act before January 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not have a major conflict of principle here; we have a slightly different method of approach. The Government will not be supporting the Democrats amendments. We will subsequently be supporting the amendments proposed by the Opposition to these clauses.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10. After clause 18, page 9, add the following clause:
Review of operation of Act
``19. (1) Before 1 January 1993, the Secretary shall review, and report to the Minister on, the operation of this Act.
``(2) The report to the Minister must deal with:

(a) whether the Act has been effective in eliminating abuses and malpractices in the provision of education services, including the financial dealings of providers and recruitment and enrolment practices covered by the Act;
(b) whether the Act has been effective in securing a uniform and high standard of courses for overseas students;
(c) the effectiveness of the Code of Conduct contained in the Schedule in setting national minimum standards for providers;
(d) any matter set out in a Resolution of the Senate for the purposes of the subsection; and
(e) any other matter the Secretary considers appropriate.
(3) For the purposes of the review the Secretary must seek submissions on the operation of the Act from persons in all States and Territories, and any such submissions must be attached to the report.
(4) The report to the Minister may include suggestions for amendment of the Act to solve problems identified in the report.
(5) The Minister must cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the report is received by the Minister.''.

The final amendment provides for a review of the operation of the Act before 1 January 1993. We have serious contention with what is proposed by the coalition. A review of this Act, including public comment, is particularly important given the history of this sector and the need to develop an appropriate system of regulation. It is preferable to a sunset clause, which could also force a review but does involve the risk of a period of non-regulation.

As we understand it, a sunset clause could leave a situation where there is no regulation of providers in any particular State or Territory. Such a sunset clause could mean that any misbehaviour which occurs after the relevant date-that is, 1 January 1994-could quite easily go unchecked without any recourse and, as unsatisfactory as this legislation may be in providing for any recourse or any regulation, to remove it certainly provides no threat whatsoever. In the words of one provider, a sunset provision would mean that the industry would start to get on edge, because if legislation is not prepared in time, the whole thing disappears down a black hole-a black hole of ignorance about what might happen in the future.

The coalition argues that a sunset clause would encourage the States to hurry up with their own legislation. I fail to see how. I fail to see what sort of sanction is provided by the threat that the legislation before us now will be removed. It is hardly a threat in my understanding of what is going on. Indeed, the date for cessation of operation of the Act has been extended one year from the coalition's earlier proposed date and the argument is that this would give the States even more time to bring in their own legislation. But where is the compulsion? The compulsion seems to rest on the fact that we would withdraw this legislation, unsatisfactory as it is.

However, in amongst all this, the Department of Employment, Education and Training reports that all States are in the process of doing this anyway. Only the two Territories are yet to make any sort of commitment. They seem to be doing this in blind ignorance-I say this with some degree of irony-of the supposedly terrible threat of a sunset clause proposed by the coalition. In fact, I am sure they do not even know about it. To be able not only to do that, but to agree on their code of conduct without reference to what is going on here, shows me the very limits of what we are doing. Rather than propose a clause which removes the legislation, we propose a clause which certainly compels review of it, because that is certainly necessary. I suggest that a review of it would be necessary tomorrow. A review at some stage of where it is going and what it has achieved would make some commonsense.

It would be wrong and foolish, as I have already argued, for the Federal Government to continue to promote the development of totally disparate systems of regulation, which is something that we could have to a considerable degree without some sort of nationally agreed, regulatory standard of conduct. Australia cannot afford to operate any longer on the international market with several different sets of regulations.

Members of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training had enough trouble as it was trying to find a nationally agreed code. We had the departmental advisers unsure about what the code was, and it was only when the Australian Education Committee's code came up that we were able to point to something which had some degree of consensus about it. But that was not generated from the Department's understandings.

The legislation as it stands leaves so many holes and so little regulation that the States may be in the situation where they can create disparate and separate sets of regulations. What we ought to be looking for is the development of something from the Federal scene with the cooperation of and in conjunction with the States and Territories. That should occur as soon as possible after the release of the Industry Commission's report, which is still officially expected by the end of July, and then after broad public consultation of that report and the Government's intentions.

We are refusing to amend patently inadequate legislation which will achieve none of the objectives set out by the Government. The objectives have not been canvassed by the Industry Commission or the providers, nor has it been established that they are required by the students. What we propose to do with the legislation is to sunset it. Big threat! What we should be proposing to do is to at least review it in time to take into account the concerns of the Industry Commission, the providers, the State Ministers and the students.

Finally, in support of this amendment it must be noted that there are no guarantees that any or all of the States and Territories will legislate, let alone include and enforce minimum standards of performance or codes of behaviour or conduct. According to Minister Dawkins's senior adviser during the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training hearing on 12 April 1991, the scheme under this Bill is `very much the minimum standard the industry should be observing'. Another adviser from the Department of Employment, Education and Training stated that any institution operating within the bounds of this legislation will be subject to an extraordinarily limited range of regulation.

Clearly, self-regulation has not worked. A few unscrupulous providers and erratic changes in government regulation have ruined things for the legitimate majority of students, providers and their staff. The Federal Government now must be seen to be making a genuine effort to clean up the sector. It would be worth considering an individual apology to each student and each country affected by what has gone on before. That is the sort of good manners that might enable us to restore our reputation in this area. That is the sort of genuine concern and respect which we really need to consider if we are genuine in our efforts to re-establish our reputation.

As well as minimum standards of performance, all providers should be required-as is already done in New South Wales under its new registration system-to undergo a regular and full review. A regular and full review would not be a bad idea for this legislation, and that is really what we are proposing with this amendment. It is with a great deal of regret that I see that it has not inspired the interest of either the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer or the coalition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate briefly that the Government will not be supporting this amendment. As Senator Bell had the courtesy of indicating for us, we will not be objecting to the Opposition's proposal to add a sunset clause. It is also proposed that there will be a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training to conduct a review. We think that is the more appropriate package and that is what we will be supporting.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will now proceed to the Opposition amendments on the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990.

—I simply indicate that there are nine Opposition amendments. Amendments Nos 1 and 9 will be moved by Senator Tierney and Nos 2 to 8 will be moved by Senator Crane in three blocks. I think that is as much as I will be contributing to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (1), lines 11 and 12, omit the subclause.
3. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (2), line 13, omit ``each quarter'', substitute ``the conclusion of each financial year''.
4. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (3), line 33, omit ``quarter or particular quarters'', substitute ``year or particular years''.
5. Clause 8, page 5, paragraph (2) (c), lines 24 to 26, omit ``quarter'' (wherever occurring), substitute ``financial year''.

These amendments deal with clause 8, which is under the heading `Returns and other information'. The amendments were outlined in my speech during the debate on the second reading and I will not go into a lot of detail.

These amendments seek to remove the onerous requirements, as they were first placed in the Bill, from the providers in the industry and put them on a commercial basis. It means that providers will have to provide the financial information on a yearly basis. The way the Act was written suggested that all providers were guilty and had to prove their innocence. We are putting emphasis the other way around. Where quarterly reports are now required, our amendments will move the emphasis to annual returns under standard accounting practice. As the Government has agreed to these amendments, I will leave my comments at that point.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. Clause 8, page 5, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:
``(2A) If the Minister forms a reasonable belief that a registered provider may have:
(a) failed to comply with the requirements of subsection (2);
(b) failed to comply with the requirements of section 6; or
(c) provided an annual return which contains misleading or deceptive information;
the Minister may, by written notice given to a provider, require the provider to give the Minister such further information as the Minister specifies.''.
7. Clause 8, page 5, subclause (4), lines 36 to 42, omit the subclause.

Amendment No. 6 to clause 8 includes subclause (2A) which spells out the situation where, if the Minister forms a reasonable belief that he requires additional information, he may request it. Amendment No. 7 removes subclause (4) of clause 8 from the Bill. In effect, it is replaced by (2a).
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8. Clause 9, page 6, subclause (1), line 2, omit ``is of the opinion'', substitute ``forms a reason- able belief''.

In this amendment we wish to substitute the words `forms a reasonable belief' for the words `is of the opinion'. We believe those words are much more definitive in terms of what the Minister has to do to determine that. It also makes that amendment consistent with the wording of the previous amendments I have moved.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 7, page 5, lines 4 to 9, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
``7. (1) A provider must make and maintain such arrangements which will ensure that the provider can at all times comply with the requirements of subsection 6(4).
``(2) The provider will make available to the Secretary details of those arrangements.
``(3) The regulations may make provision for or in relation to the exemption of a specified provider or a specified class of providers from the requirements of subsection (1).''.

The original clause 7 was intended to ensure protection of the trust funds through insurance or other agreed arrangements, and non-compliance would invoke a penalty. The amendment of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training to this clause changes the provision for an undefined insurance to insurance or bond arrangements.

My amendment is based on a suggestion put to the Senate Standing Committee by Mr Jack Evans of the Australian Council for Private Education and Training. It has the effect of allowing the provider to make whatever arrangements are the most convenient for the provider as long as they comply with clause 6(4). Clause 7 in its original form, or in the Senate Standing Committee amended form, imposes yet another cost on the industry which is rapidly losing its competitive edge.

The Industry Commission in its draft report has provided clear advice to the Government on the added costs to both institutions and students caused by the proposed insurance provisions. During the examination of the Bill by the Senate Standing Committee, we asked officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training for information on the cost of insurance or bond arrangements. They were not able to provide any satisfactory or precise information. They could only guess that half to one per cent of the amount insured would be the amount to add to those costs, but no-one really knows what will be incurred by clause 7 if we retain the compulsory insurance or bond arrangements.

New providers to the industry are likely to be particularly disadvantaged as the risk will be higher in the initial stages of their enterprise. Therefore their premium rates will be even higher than those paid by established providers. There are already complaints from overseas students that Australian costs are too high. Added costs, because of government regulation, will have to be passed on to the students in the form of even higher fees, which will be very much to the disadvantage of this industry.

The Industry Commission in its draft report takes a very different approach to that suggested by the Bill. It suggests that students should be informed of their rights and status of their fees in the event of the collapse of an institution. It further indicates that one approach might be for institutions or industrial bodies to establish some form of insurance scheme. There is already a penalty to a provider who fails to comply with clause 6(4), so that it is only necessary in clause 7 to insist that providers have some arrangement in place to ensure that they do not fail to comply with clause 6(4). On page 99 the draft report states:
A preferred approach is to provide institutions with more incentive to make sure that students are better informed about the status of their fees and their legal rights in the event of a collapse.
The key recommendation on this matter is made by the Industry Commission on pages 10 and 11 of its draft report. It states:

The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs should develop techniques to help reduce infringements of visa conditions and to check bona fides of student visa applications. The Department should also provide student visa applicants with explanatory material, which should emphasise the need for care in choosing where to study. Information on students' rights under Australian consumer protection law might also be included.

This seems to be a better way to go, to follow the Industry Commission findings and to tighten up the main provisions in the Bill, rather than to have large amounts of money for fees and living expenses held in trust, which then have to be protected by expensive insurance arrangements.

Our amendment will still ensure that some arrangement is made to ensure compliance with clause 6(4), but it will be up to the provider to find an arrangement that is convenient and at the lowest cost to the institution and subsequently to the student.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is just a continuation of the type of confusion we have had since the introduction of this legislation and during the committee stage. This is a continuation of that confusion. We have already had the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training proposing an amendment which received support from all parties in that Committee. Now we have the Opposition proposing to amend that again.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the reason for that because, as Senator Tierney has just mentioned, the Industry Commission report has brought a different perspective to this discussion. That report was not available to the Committee when it was considering what amendments might be appropriate. Nor was it available to the Government when it was drafting this legislation. The Industry Commission report is in draft form. The consideration which has been given to it so far has been limited by the very fact it became available only recently and in draft form.

The suggestion by the Industry Commission, as expressed just now by Senator Tierney, that students be better informed about their rights and the status of their fees in the case of a collapse, is certainly a worthy suggestion and is one which I and the Democrats would endorse. But it does not mean that the passage of this coalition amendment gives rise to that information and to the status of students being better explained.

This amendment adds to the confusion. It leaves a situation which is more vague than that which was suggested and amended by the Committee. The coalition amendment to omit and substitute a new clause 7 suggests that providers should be required to make and maintain such arrangements which will ensure that the provider can at all times comply with the requirements of subsection 6(4). There is no direction, no suggestion, no compulsion and no regulation. Details of the arrangement must be made available to the Secretary. There is no guidance-and this is an area which requires guidance.

In contrast to clause 7 as it is presently drafted, the Senate Committee's proposal is quite stark. The Senate Committee at least said that this would require arrangements by way of insurance-bond arrangements-so that other arrangements could be made and were still available to the satisfaction of the Secretary. At least there was a direction about the sorts of arrangements, such as insurance bonds. We had an explanation for it in the Committee's amendment. It was for the purpose of ensuring that no person suffers a loss if the provider fails to comply with the requirements of proposed subsection 6(4). There was also a penalty of $3,000, which has disappeared under the coalition's vague and meaningless version.

After considerable discussion, the Senate Committee amended the clause by inserting the term `bond arrangement' to provide some clue as to what it meant. But we have no idea what the coalition is talking about, because it has left in the words `such arrangements'. They can be any arrangements; there is no guidance given. It is meaningless, because it could refer to some personal indemnity-and that is only as good as the provider's trustworthiness.

If a provider mismanages or misappropriates students' funds, currently there is no provision to safeguard their educational financial investment by insurance, et cetera. Refund, including repayment of living expenses and/or the option of transfer to another institution, is not guaranteed. The option to transfer it to another similar institution or course should be guaranteed. We need to be specific. I would like to have seen the Committee's amendment go further and be more specific; but, as is the nature with committee deliberations, we reached a compromise. I was satisfied with the position we reached. But now to alter that and retain the highly instructive-I say that ironically-phrase `such arrangements' is not providing any guidance whatsoever.

We are left in an unforgivable position. We could have achieved something. The Committee agreed on a form of words. For the coalition now to remove that completely is taking all meaning out of the legislation. In the view of the Minister, does the coalition amendment stand or not?

The present situation is that those English language intensive courses for overseas students (ELICOS) colleges which have attempted to obtain insurance in anticipation of this legislation being passed have not been successful with insurance providers. What is going to happen when the ELICOS colleges are unable to obtain commercial insurance at any price? This legislation, whether or not it is amended in this way, will require some arrangement to be made. The onus is not on the ELICOS colleges to provide individual bonds or cooperative industrial based bonds. They are asked in this amendment to make such arrangements, but with the Committee's previous amendments it became instructive and directive. But what happens if those instructions and directions, or such arrangements, cannot be met? How can we ensure that these students are not left in a destitute situation? What will the Government do about this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not rise simply to speak in response to Senator Bell; but, in responding to the Opposition amendment, I will respond to his remarks as well. As I indicated earlier in more general remarks, the Government has no objection to this amendment. It has to be seen in the context that, wherever one is proposing government regulation, a variety of things need to be looked at-not merely the benefit that is hoped might flow from the regulation but also the cost of the regulation to the taxpayers in supervising, monitoring and ensuring compliance with the regulation, and the cost imposed on citizens in complying with the requirements set down by the Parliament. There must always be a cost benefit. This amendment clearly is seeking to change the balance of that cost benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a downside risk in losing the benefit, the Government proposes to refer the operations of this Act straight back to the Committee. The terms of the amendment as outlined are satisfactory to protect the interests of the students, about whom we are all concerned. But even if that proved not to be the case, the downside risk is very low and it is appropriate to look at the costs of regulation as well as the potential benefits. Therefore, the Government is quite prepared to accept the amendment.

In response to the question concerning the apparent or alleged difficulty of colleges in achieving adequate insurance arrangements which may be necessary to comply with these requirements, or to achieve the objectives, I think all honourable senators share my understanding of the Government's expectation: there will not be such a problem and when the insurance requirements on the colleges are properly understood there will be-there already is-available appropriate insurance arrangements which will enable them reasonably to be able to discharge their obligations under the Act.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9. After clause 18, page 9, line 2, add the following clause:
Cessation of Operation of Act
``19. This Act, unless sooner repealed, shall cease to be in force on 1 January 1994.''.

This amendment seeks to insert a sunset clause providing for the Act to cease on 1 January 1994. In September 1990 Tony Harris, the special adviser to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), submitted the report Future Operations of the Non-Formal Export Education Industry. This report indicated a great concern about regulation. It pointed out that regulatory activities were very costly and interfered with the marketplace. In addition, the Commonwealth had not been previously involved in regulation of the export of educational services.

The report noted that government regulation in educational services of overseas students was complicated by the overlapping role of the Commonwealth Government and the State or Territory governments. The Commonwealth is responsible for exports and relations with foreign states. The States and Territories are responsible for education. These overlapping roles have caused concern, and some of the amendments moved by Senator McMullan on behalf of Senator Aulich and the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training have addressed this problem.

I share with Mr Harris a grave concern about the cost of regulation. There is no doubt that regulation of this industry will be a considerable cost to the taxpayer and to the provider institutions. These costs will, of course, be reflected in fees. Australia is already regarded overseas as a high cost country for education. The Harris report notes that there has been a loss of faith in the Australian education industry and that it is becoming an enormous problem for those institutions that are proven providers of excellent courses.

Regulation can be an inhibiting factor for the industry in its growth, competition and scope for innovation. However, it has to be recognised that Australia is in a difficult and recessive economic period. Small businesses are facing enormous problems, and there probably has to be some protection for students who elect to study at a small private institution at this time. The Commonwealth Government faces a large expenditure to reimburse overseas students if the provider institutions fail and are not in a position to reimburse students themselves. The Harris report reluctantly admits that the Commonwealth regulatory scheme will be useful for a short period while the industry becomes more firmly established and while Australia faces a more than ordinarily difficult economic situation.

The Harris report also predicts that the adjustment process should be complete by the end of 1992 and that after that the Commonwealth should withdraw from its regulatory role. By then all States and Territories should have set up their own regulatory regimes and they should be a sufficient adjunct to normal market forces. Self-regulation mechanisms should then be firmly in place and providers and users should be familiar with these mechanisms by that time and be able to take full advantage of them.

The Harris report spoke very highly of the self-regulation scheme developed by the Association of Recognised ELICOS Centres and recommended that it should be encouraged to maintain and to refine that scheme. The Harris report emphasises the importance of the Commonwealth acknowledging now that the industry should be deregulated over the next few years in order to encourage those States that have not already done so to establish their own regulations for the industry; to encourage industry to promote self-regulation and competition; and to allow the market to operate in this industry.

I support the findings of the Harris report. To that end, I consider it essential that this Bill should include a sunset clause that will enable this country to achieve the basic objectives of the Bill, which is a healthy education export industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support this amendment. The clues to that statement are contained within Senator Tierney's earlier remarks, when he cited the report to indicate that the Commonwealth had not previously been involved in the regulation of export education services. That is the problem. The fact that the Commonwealth had not been involved meant that the cavalier, carefree, exploitative cowboys were ripping people off. That is what it was all about and that is why this legislation was brought forward. The threat of removal of the legislation in a couple of years is hardly a threat that will terrify those who may wish to continue as rip-off merchants.

SPEECH.PARA: The suggestion that such regulation would be useful for a short period, with later reduced effectiveness, is perhaps understandable. The suggestion that after 1992 the States would have in place sufficient regulation to be able to control the industry may be accurate, but it may not. Why put an arbitrary time on this? It may be based on some calculations or guesstimates as to when the States could have active legislation. But rather than having a time limit, why not set as a goal that, if and when the States achieve parallel, relevant, useful, sufficient-whatever qualifier one might like to use-legislation in this area, that would be the trigger for the sunsetting of this legislation?

I can imagine the ridiculous situation of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) travelling overseas promoting our wonderful education provision and having to say, `Well, yes, you are guaranteed a certain standard and code of behaviour, or at least you are guaranteed that your fees will be safe and the provider will be an honourable fellow, but only for a couple of years. We will then pull off any sort of legislation that governs this'. It would be ridiculous to have to make that sort of statement. If there were a requirement that this legislation would stay in place until the States came up with their own legislation, I could see a reason for sunsetting it. But the date should not be chosen out of the blue. That date terrifies nobody; it does not force the States into anything.

The removal of this legislation, weak as it is, would threaten nobody with fear of non-compliance. People would say, `Well, we can wait for a while before we can start our shonky business again. After a few years there will be no Commonwealth legislation, so we can get back into the game'. I am sure that that is not a guarantee for anybody overseas. The only justification for sunsetting the legislation would be the achievement of parallel legislation in the States. But the insertion of this date, which might as well be Christmas year XXXX, really has no relevance. I cannot see any justification for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be accepting this amendment. It seems to us to be a comfortable corollary to the review that will be undertaken. It may be that at the end of the day we decide we need further legislation because the optimistic assessments were not well founded. That is within the competence of the Parliament to resolve prior to the sunset clause taking effect. That is the reason we have them; they impose deadlines by which this Parliament needs to make decisions about the continuation of legislation. It does put pressure on somebody: it puts pressure on us-and that is exactly where it should be put.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the motion for the third reading of the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill. This Bill was very badly drafted and rushed through the House of Representatives with unseemly haste. There was an attempt to rush the Bill through the Senate with the same haste, but fortunately there was the opportunity to have this Bill referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for investigation and report. It is just over 20 years since the first legislative and general purpose standing committees were established in the Senate. This move was the most fundamental change to the Parliament since Federation. It strengthened the Australian parliamentary system of government and made it possible for the Senate to take on its proper role as a house of review.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bi-annual complaint in this Parliament that legislation is rushed through at the end of each half-yearly session without proper scrutiny and without proper debate. That might have happened to this Bill. It was only a short Bill, but it had to be drastically amended, as was seen today, before it became in any way an acceptable Bill or even achieved the purpose that the Government intended for it.

Although we have had Senate committees for over 20 years, it was relatively rare, until last year, for committees to perform their legislative role as opposed to their general purpose role. Last year the Senate procedures were restructured to allow easier referral of Bills to the appropriate Senate standing committee. This was how this Bill came before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

As a result of the efforts of the Committee, which first met to consider this Bill on 12 April and reported on 7 May, the Bill was comprehensively amended by the Government, by the Committee and by the Opposition. In less than a month the Committee had made the Government change its mind on a number of issues within the Bill. I will not repeat all the changes that have been made to the Bill, but I will remind the Senate that, had it not been for the Committee and for the opportunity to take advice and conduct public hearings relating to the export of education services, this would not only have been an ineffective Bill, but a Bill that would have done much towards destroying a very valuable industry rather than helping it. The work of the Senate Standing Committee and the persistence of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have made the Government back down and accept every single one of our amendments in order to have a reasonable Bill.

I still have one final concern. The Bill has been rushed through in the final stages of this session, yet the Treasurer-now the ex-Treasurer-had authorised the Industry Commission to inquire into and report on the whole of the exports of education services industry. So far it has had no public hearings on the matter and will not do so until next month. Its final report is not expected until the end of July. My final comment is that it is an extraordinary situation where one Minister rushes a Bill through and another authorises an inquiry into the very same matter which the Bill is meant to cover. I say to the Government: learn a lesson from the Senate Standing Committee. Inquire first, and then get the legislation right.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Aulich)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Education Services (Export Regulation) Bill 1990, when enacted as an Act, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for consideration and report on or before the first sitting day in December 1992.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 June of House of Representatives message.
House of Representatives message:
SCHEDULE OF THE AMENDMENT MADE BY THE SENATE TO WHICH THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES HAS DISAGREED
After clause 2, page 2, insert the following clause:
Grant to minimise transitional pressures on gas prices

``2a. There is payable to the State of Victoria, out of monies appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose, an amount of $30 million in respect of each of the two years after 1 July 1990, in order to minimise transitional pressure on gas prices on an equitable basis.''.
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment No. 1 of the Senate.
Senate amendment No. 1 is unacceptable because:

(1) The amendment to insert a clause 2a, ``Grant to minimise transitional pressures on gas prices'', is not directly related to the purposes of the Bill to apply the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax to petroleum recovered from Bass Strait and to provide for the wider deductibility of exploration expenditure, and for related purposes.

(2) The Government's decision to provide a special grant of $30 million for each of the first two years of application of Resource Rent Tax, will be made through an Appropriation to be brought before the Parliament in the Budget Session. The safeguards provided by the standard provisions of the Appropriate process deal appropriately with any concerns related to the disbursement of the special grant.

(3) The amendment is superfluous and unnecessary and bears no direct relationship to the purposes of the Bill. It is, therefore, not appropriately contained in the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 was considered in the Senate, as honourable senators will recall, on 6 June. It was amended in two ways and returned to the House of Representatives. The first of the two amendments related to the Senate inclusion of a clause in the Bill designed to provide a grant to Victoria to minimise transitional pressures on gas prices. It read:

SPEECH.PARA: There is payable to the State of Victoria, out of monies appropriated by the Parliament for the purpose, an amount of $30m in respect of each of the 2 years after 1 July 1990, in order to minimise transitional pressure on gas prices on an equitable basis.

The second amendment sought and passed by the Senate was to insert an additional part VII in the Act requiring the Minister for Resources by 30 November 1992 to report to both Houses of the Parliament on the operation of the Act, that report to include, firstly, whether the Act has been effective in achieving its objectives; secondly, the impact on prices and on industry; and, thirdly, the impact on the development of new offshore petroleum projects.

The Government has accepted the second of those amendments, namely, the reporting requirement amendment, and on behalf of the Opposition I welcome that. The Government did indicate its acceptance of that amendment in this chamber when it was debated on 6 June, and indeed earlier when it was considered by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. It is pleasing that the House of Representatives has also accepted that amendment. It is the key amendment that the Opposition was seeking because it requires the Government to report back to the Parliament within a period of five months after the completion of the first two years of the new arrangements for the application of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait oil and gas, and that is what this Bill is all about. It requires the Government to report back on the impact of those measures given the uncertainty at this stage as to just what that impact will be. The impact can be in various directions. There will certainly be an impact on gas users in Victoria. There will be an impact on gas producers in the Bass Strait field, Esso-BHP, and it is simply not possible at this time to be able to predict with any great confidence what that impact will be. We welcome the House's acceptance of that amendment.

I regret that the Government has not accepted the first amendment, namely, to write into the Bill a clause to pick up what the Government has announced in its second reading speech will be an integral part of the whole package involving the application of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait oil and gas, being a grant to Victoria of $60m-$30m a year for each of the first two years after the commencement of the application of this resource rent tax to Bass Strait oil and gas. The effective date of commencement is 1 July 1990; in other words, this legislation is retrospective. The decision was announced in the Budget last year.
