The Bill does not provide specifically for this grant to ease the initial impact on Victorian gas prices. This is not in the legislation; it is simply in the Minister's second reading speech. The actions of the Victorian Government have bankrupted the State of Victoria over recent years. There is no more classic example of that than the disclosure in this place yesterday that the Victorian Government has had to come cap in hand to the Federal Government to get a loan for just a few thousand dollars to help it meet its superannuation and other pay-out obligations to 10 retrenched Victorian meat industry inspectors. That it had to come to the Commonwealth to get a loan for an amount like that is the clearest, most stark example of just how bankrupt the State of Victoria is under the Kirner Government.

Quite frankly, we do not trust the Victorian Government to act in the way that this Parliament might wish and expect it to do so. Therefore, this amendment seeks to insert a clause in the Act which would ensure that the purposes for which this grant was being paid, namely, to minimise the transitional pressure on gas prices to Victorian users, would be achieved. We have had considerable debate on this matter both in the committee stage through the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and in this chamber when the Bill was debated on 6 June.

Despite the Government's explanation of the strength of its opposition to this amendment, I still do not accept the reasons that have been given. But the situation has changed, at least to some extent, since our intention to insert this clause in the Bill was first brought forward to the Senate. Since then there have been changes. I refer the honourable senators to page 134 of the Hansard of the Finance and Public Administration Committee, in which Senator McMullan said that this grant was not necessarily going to be an untied grant and that this is not a matter about which a final decision has been made. In other words, at that stage the question of the conditionality that we wanted attached to the grant was left pretty well up in the air. That raised our concerns even more.

Despite the changes that have occurred since then, we still do not accept as sufficient the Government's stated objections to the Senate amendment. Having said that, we are pleased to note the Government's assurances that what we are seeking to achieve by this amendment will in fact be achieved. In that context, I refer particularly to the statement by the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, in the other place on 6 June when the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill was returned to the House of Representatives from the Senate. At page 5031 of Hansard, he said:

The Government is on the public record-and I will now put it on the public record again-that the $60m is being provided to the Victorian Government to minimise any transitional pressures on gas. The payment to Victoria will be made on the condition that $60m is to be used to minimise any transitional pressure on gas.
Then I note particularly that the Minister went on to say:
The Opposition has the Government's assurance that such a condition will be stipulated in the exchange of letters which will occur, as is normal for the special once-off appropriations to the States.

In other words, there is a degree of tying and conditionality attaching to the grant, which was not obvious when the Bill was debated in the Committee of this place. Indeed, the House of Representatives has repeated much the same assurance in the official list of reasons that it has prepared and transmitted to the Senate disagreeing with this amendment of the Senate. Of the three reasons given, the second reason is the important one in this context. The reason states:

The Government's decision to provide a special grant of $30m for each of the first two years of application of Resource Rent Tax, will be made through an Appropriation to be brought before the Parliament in the Budget Session. The safeguards provided by the standard provisions of the Appropriation process deal appropriately with any concerns related to the disbursement of the special grant.

The Opposition will not again press its amendment. Nevertheless, we still believe that the Bill would be, from the point of view of Victorian users of gas in particular, a better Bill if the clause that we have been seeking were included. Nevertheless, at the same time I acknowledge the completely unequivocal assurances given by the Government that this grant will be made conditional on its use by the Victorian Government for the purposes for which this Parliament will be appropriating it, namely, specifically and entirely to help minimise the impact on gas prices of the application of the resource rent tax to Bass Strait gas.

Therefore, on that basis, on behalf of the Opposition I note the reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing with that amendment. I welcome the acceptance of the other House of the key Opposition amendment. We will not divide again on this issue, given what is now on the public record on both sides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In looking at this situation, it is useful to return to the context in which this amendment, which has been rejected by the House of Representatives, arose. Both the Government and the LiberalNational Party coalition opposed an amendment moved by the Australian Democrats which would have ensured that increases in gas prices would have been carried totally, without any pass-on effect, by the producers. It would have enabled contractual arrangements which provided otherwise to be interpreted in a way which would have made it impossible for that pass-on to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats' amendment was put forward in the knowledge and the full consciousness of the difficult economic situation in Victoria for domestic gas users and, perhaps equally importantly, for our Victorian business community, which is struggling to maintain employment. We know that the Victorian economy is in a parlous state. We have had representations, as indeed has the coalition, from companies which are unable to bear the additional cost impost without laying off workers. That applies in particular to cement companies situated primarily in Geelong, which is one of the hardest hit areas.

In addition, we have had representations from companies using ethane, which is one of the raw materials that goes into the production of plastics. These companies operate in the international market and thereby have an opportunity to contribute to our export income, but they felt strongly that their competitiveness would be severely damaged. It is to be noted too that, in the proposed distribution of the $30m per annum compensation to Victoria, apparently the users of ethane were not going to be considered. So it was in this context that the Democrats moved the amendment. It was rejected by the Opposition-it decided to desert the business community in Victoria by opposing our amendment-and the Government.

As a very much second-rate and threadbare alternative, we then supported the amendment put forward by the Opposition, which sought to ensure that the $30m per annum for two years was in fact applied in compensation for the price increases, thereby halving notionally the price increase on gas. We do not accept the Government's arguments that this particular provision has nothing to do with the Bill before the Senate and as it went to the House of Representatives.

I note with some amusement that, on this occasion, the Opposition is prepared to trust two socialist governments and their assurances that they will apply funds in a particular manner. We are not quite as trusting. We believe that it would have been better to pursue this amendment and to ensure that this grant becomes a tied grant. This is what the amendment sought to do. There is ample time for the House of Representatives to accept yet another amendment from the Senate, but unfortunately the Opposition has gone to water and it is not prepared to press the point. It is prepared to trust two socialist governments. I trust that Senator Kemp, in particular, takes note of the fact that he is prepared to trust them; the Australian Democrats are not.

Since the numbers are on the other side, I will not waste the Committee's time by pushing this to a division, but I wish to put on record very strongly the position of the Australian Democrats on this issue. We continue to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Short, the Liberal Party senator from Victoria, has given a very wide and adequate coverage of the issues involved in relation to the petroleum resource rent tax (RRT). I will do no more than highlight a few outstanding issues that I would like the Government to acknowledge in preparing its safeguard statement, which is to be built into the appropriate appropriation processes during the Budget session.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal-National Party coalition rejects reasons (1) and (3) given by the House of Representatives for opposing Senate amendment No. 1 to the Petroleum Resource Rent Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. However, we take heart at the assurances given in reason (2), namely:

The Government's decision to provide a special grant of $30 million for each of the first two years of application of the Resource Rent Tax, will be made through an Appropriation to be brought in during the Budget Session. The safeguards provided by the standard provisions of the Appropriate process deal appropriately with any concerns related to the disbursement of the special grant.

The Liberal-National Party coalition has sent very direct and clear signals to the Government of the need to ensure that those safeguards are adequate and will cover all users. We do not accept the reason that the amendment was superfluous, because its main purpose was to provide that signal to ensure the adequacy of the processes that will be applied in the August Budget. If we have done no more than that, we will have achieved our purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the support of the Australian Democrats. However, I draw the attention of the Government to the need to ensure that within those safeguards an acknowledgment is made of the problem of what we refer to as the joint costs, particularly as the RRT can be passed on, which the Government now acknowledges. There seemed to be some doubt earlier on in Government circles as to whether it could be passed on. In the committee stage we examined the consequences of that passing on. Those consequences will be quite detrimental to many significant industries in Victoria. We regret that.

SPEECH.PARA: But, as part of the safety mechanisms, we point out the difficulty in the apportionment of what is known as joint costs between oil and gas. We ask the Government to ensure that the producers allocate their costs so as not to maximise the pass-on effects of the RRT, which they might otherwise do for the producers' benefit and to the detriment of the end users. If there is a failure to acknowledge that, a situation could arise whereby there is an increase in the proportion of the tax paid by customers relative to the proportion that the producers would bear themselves to the detriment of those users.

I mention again-and I think it is worth repeating-that there was a strong view within relevant industry circles that the Government had not understood the potential pass-on effects of the RRT. We condemn the Government's inadequate consultation, both with the users and with the Victorian Government. This is an important matter which affects the tariff regime because it is an add-on cost to industry. This is at a time when tariffs are coming down, particularly for users. They are faced with increasing costs as a result of an RRT. We do not have an appropriate or full RRT; in fact, we have a sham of an RRT where not all costs are acknowledged, where the tax rate is artificially high and higher than the alleged amount because of the multiplier effect, which has now been acknowledged, again in hindsight.

I draw the Government's attention further to the effects that the RRT will have because of the cost impact on certain industries, particularly some environment and pollution related industries. Members of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration were most disturbed to hear that a paper recycling operation in Victoria now may become so marginal as to warrant closure. There were also suggestions that a major cement producer might substitute coal for gas with adverse environmental effects. We hope that the Government will ensure that some of the $60m will be applied so that the detrimental consequences in these particular industries do not arise.

Senator Campbell, Senator Kemp and I, supported by Senator Short, mentioned in our minority report that, when setting secondary taxes, governments must be very conscious of the need to avoid losses of competitive advantage in the secondary and tertiary sectors, particularly for those industries where Australia should have a natural advantage-and that applies to natural gas, oil, iron ore and so on. If we allow an inappropriate design, as we have in the circumstances of the resource rent tax, we may find a bias in the pass-on cost to the producers which is created in favour of the export industries rather than further processing within Australia.

That was the central concern of our minority report. That was the amendment, initiated by the concern of my colleague Senator Short, which went down to the House of Representatives and was rejected. As a Senate we now have limited powers. However, we are putting great reliance on the strength of the safeguards that we trust will be built into the provisions within the appropriation process to ensure that the concerns relating to disbursement of the special grant are brought in adequately and that that grant is distributed fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the comments which have been made by my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Watson, and to make a brief comment on some of the matters which were raised by Senator Spindler. First, I strongly endorse the view put forward by Senator Short that the Government-and we are pleased to see this-has agreed to a very important amendment which will require it at the end of 1992 to come back and report to this chamber on just how this very complex and rushed legislation will work out in practice. We have received many assurances from the Government about the consequences of this and about their alleged minimal impact on gas prices in Victoria. This report will allow us to see just how effective the Bill has been in meeting the Government's stated objective.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short was quite right to stress the importance of this amendment. It is also important because the arrangements, and particularly the compensation arrangement that the Government has made, apply only for two years-up to the end of 1991-92. As a consequence, after that period we then have to look at the compensation which will be given to Victoria through the general purpose revenue sharing grants with the States. Whereas the debate has concentrated particularly on the effects of the resource rent tax over the next two years, I think that in the longer context this resource rent tax could have very profound effects, especially if it is used as a method by the Commonwealth Government to further squeeze Victoria. As a Victorian senator-and I am sure my colleagues will also be very concerned about this-I will be very interested in any comments Senator McMullan can make on what happens post 1991-92 on this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had your chance.

—I will come to Senator Spindler in a moment. Secondly, it was a great pity that our proposed amendment was not carried. That would have tied into the Bill the $30m a year compensation which was promised by the Government and would have given at least some assurances to the gas users in Victoria that that money would be used for the purpose previously stated. I underline Senator Short's comments about this matter: this Government has a very big credibility problem. The problem in Victoria is that the State Government there, as Senator Short said, is virtually bankrupt-a government which Senator Spindler, I am pleased to record in the Senate, used to boast was elected on the preferences of the Australian Democrats. I notice that Senator Spindler was very loath today to acknowledge his role in getting the Cain-Kirner Government into office.

—I raise a point of order. Madam Temporary Chairman, I wish to draw your attention to the fact that Senator Kemp is misusing a debate on resource rent tax to parade his Party's inability to come to terms with electoral reform in Victoria which led to its losing the election. With respect, he should be requested to keep to the topic of the Bill.
—There is no point of order. I am sure Senator Kemp is relating his remarks to the Bill in question.

—Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman. There was clearly no point of order, as Senator Spindler knew, but he chose to make a rather cheap political shot in a matter which, I might say, is directly related to this Bill. Senator Spindler is the man who, even more so than this Government-and this is saying something-has proposed a massive tax package which would have major consequences on people in Victoria and elsewhere. I am coming to Senator Spindler soon. But the point I was trying to make before Senator Spindler made his spurious point of order was that this Government does have a major credibility problem. It has that because of the endless broken promises which this Government has made on major election matters.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is not a major election matter, although, if the Bill does have some of the serious consequences that some people have projected, it may well become a major election matter. The Government does have serious problems and those problems have been even more underlined in the way some Ministers have twisted and turned when asked whether they could endorse Mr Hawke's view that promises made in an election are quite disposable, and that the means justify the ends.

Senator Short has also drawn attention not only to the Commonwealth Government's problems but also the Victorian Government's problems in relation to the parlous state of the Victorian economy. So, I record those two points and I think it is a pity that the amendment we proposed was not accepted by the Government because I believe, in view of the record of both the Commonwealth Government and the Victorian Government, it would have provided at least some further assurances to gas users in Victoria that the compensation money would have been used for its stated purpose.

The final point I wish to make relates to Senator Spindler. Senator Spindler gets up in this Parliament, as he did today, and tries to pretend in some ways that the Democrats are the friends of business, particularly small business. Senator Spindler in his alternative tax package proposed additional taxes of some $7 billion on top of the Government's already high taxing policies. How on earth does he expect the vast variety of additional taxes that he has proposed to impact on business, small and big, and on Australian families, particularly those in Victoria?

The reality is that he has shown not the slightest bit of concern for those people when he has proposed this very large tax package which invites this Government, which is strapped for revenue, to bring in a wide range of new taxes. As he and his colleagues will be held in part responsible for the performance of the Cain-Kirner Government in Victoria, I can well believe that if the people are socked with a whole range of new taxes he and his colleagues will also be blamed for that because of the way in which they have invited the Government to bring in new taxes. Let me underline the hypocrisy of their proposal, in their alternative Budget, for an additional tax on petrol--

TALK.START.PARA: —Great for small business.

—That is, as Senator Macdonald says, great for small business. The Democrats have proposed an additional tax on road transport; again, great for small business, great for people in rural areas. They have proposed additional company taxes. For Senator Spindler to come into this Parliament and talk about his concerns about the pass-on effects of the resource rent tax (RRT)-we have concerns too, but it is astonishing coming from him when he has proposed a vast range of new taxes which will directly impact on Victorian industry-is the greatest act of hypocrisy that I have seen in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Spindler looked at his polls, he would find that the rating of the Australian Democrats has fallen from 11 per cent at the last election to 7 per cent today, and I believe that he, with Senator McLean, must take a major responsibility for that because Victorians, and Australians generally, are worried about the policies the Democrats are pursuing-particularly Senator Spindler's very high tax policies which will have a major impact on business. I wish to conclude these comments by again drawing the Minister's attention to the period after 1991-92, and I wonder whether he could give us some assurances on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a matter on which we are all about to agree, this has been a rather remarkable debate. Nevertheless, I appreciate the consideration that this Bill has been given. This is the third time we have dealt with it, and the honourable senators who have spoken today have all been part of those three deliberations. I have appreciated the manner in which the debate has been conducted overall. We have had our disagreements from time to time, but I think it has been a constructive consideration. With regard to the matter we have before us at the moment concerning the amendment with which the Government did not agree in the House of Representatives, with which I am proposing the Senate should not persist and in which I note the agreement of the other senators, I think there has been a common objective and a disagreement about process.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this process-which has now been made more explicit by me and, more importantly, by the responsible Minister in the House of Representatives-was always the best process. To the extent that people are satisfied that it is now more certain and more clear to them, and therefore to others who may be affected by the legislation, I am happy that more clear assurances have been given. I welcome the fact that the legislation is now going to be passed in the manner as agreed by the House of Representatives in response to our amendments.

I note the comments that have been made by honourable senators. I want to respond to a particular question asked by Senator Kemp, although matters were raised at various times which people have asked the Government to take into consideration. I note those remarks and will ensure that they are considered. Senator Kemp asked me a question, to which I cannot give a broad and detailed answer, about post 1991-92 revenue sharing.

The public record on this matter contains a joint statement by the then Treasurer and the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) of 21 August 1990 indicating that revenue sharing beyond that time will be considered in the context of the general resource rent tax revenue sharing discussions. Those negotiations obviously have not started because the legislation has not passed yet, but I expect that over the next few months-we have got quite a bit of time because it is not a pressing timetable-we will be taking steps to initiate those discussions. Of course, I cannot give any indication about their outcome but, as indicated by Mr Keating and Mr Griffiths, the negotiations will be undertaken within a reasonable timeframe to ensure that we can get an outcome well before the deadline. I cannot say any more than that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table an erratum to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this occasion to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 concurrently with the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991. Once again, we are debating a multifaceted Bill covering a wide range of taxation issues such as an extension of the normal Australian taxation requirements to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and also amendments, firstly, to previously enacted foreign income legislation; secondly, to the method of taxation of income derived overseas by Australian residents; thirdly, to thin capitalisation requirements-by that we mean the gearing arrangements between capital and equity-and, finally, by allowing primary producers a deduction for capital expenditure on fences used primarily to prevent land degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, other changes in the Bill, some of which relate to the tax file number rules, accession arrangements for certain law enforcement agencies and the self assessment provisions for company and superannuation funds. In addition, amendments have been made to the securities lending arrangements. I shall be dealing with each of these changes in the course of my evaluation.

Before discussing the various components of this Bill, I would like to congratulate the Government on its new format of the explanatory memorandum. This is a significant reform and a significant change. I am pleased to say that the Opposition has been very much at the forefront of encouraging the changes that have taken place in this updated and new explanatory memorandum. The new simplified version is a great advancement on the previous format. Originally, I was very critical of the large number of both editing and presentation errors in the document before us. In fact, five or six pages of my original notes on this debate detailed those errors. I note that the latest corrigendum tabled by Senator Tate acknowledges those problems.

However, full marks must go to the Government and the Australian Taxation Office for their preparedness to discuss these problems and to issue a corrigendum alerting this chamber to the difficulties. May I say, though, that a great number of the problems would have been avoided if more time had been given to the original drafting of the legislation. I understand that the Australian Taxation Office is carrying out an ongoing project to improve the quality of its explanatory memoranda to ensure that they meet the needs of the target audience.

Through the courtesy of the Treasurer's office, I have had the opportunity to talk with the taxation officers involved in the project. They tell me that one of their objectives has been to produce explanatory memoranda which are more readable, more certain and easier to understand. I believe that with this explanatory memorandum they have achieved their objective, although there are inevitably going to be some teething problems.

I understand also that the Taxation Office is undertaking another project designed to improve the way that it goes about developing its new tax legislation. I welcome that because it is an issue that I have been harping on, if I can use that word, for almost 12 months. In particular, the Taxation Office will be reviewing the existing working relationship with other government agencies involved in this process. The Opposition endorses this initiative taken by the Taxation Office. However, as with so many previous taxation Bills that have come before the chamber, the time given for consultation with industry-which is another issue concerning the drafted legislation-is unfortunately very short. The House of Representatives was given a little over two weeks while the Senate had about twice that time.

While I have drawn attention to the need for a consultative committee, perhaps there should also be a fourth person added to this task force in drafting taxation legislation. To that team-which includes the Treasury people who are involved in developing the concept, the taxation officers who have to put it into a practical form and the parliamentary draftsman-should be added a fourth person who has the facility of drafting legislation in plain English. Although the first three mentioned officers understand the technical implications of the legislation, given the wide application of taxation law, it is necessary to ensure that the law is expressed in the simplest language and in a non-technical fashion wherever possible.

There seems to be an attitude of rush prevailing, from the original drafting of the Bill to having it passed by the Parliament. That is always regrettable. I am thankful that this country, therefore, has a Senate, a House of review, with the possibility of deferral to a committee, where both the technical and industrial hazards of the legislation can be highlighted and hopefully corrected.

I commend the Government at this point for its cooperative attitude and willingness to discuss the problems the Opposition has seen. That is one of the more constructive features that has developed since the appointment of Senator McMullan to this office. However, I feel strongly that more time should be given from the date the legislation is tabled until it is fully debated and passed. In this democratic country industry organisations and people who will be affected should be allowed time to reflect and then to raise their concerns. Trust in a government is destroyed when delay in terms of the operative date of a Bill appears to prevail. In the past, that situation has occurred all too frequently.

Further, I think it is of interest to note that many of the proposed amendments were contemplated and pre-empted by the previous Treasurer as long ago as August last year. The foreign income legislation had a series of proposed changes foreshadowed by the former Treasurer on 30 December last. Let me take these proposed amendments as an example. When the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990 was debated last October the coalition made it abundantly clear that further changes were required. Today we have the first of those changes, seven months after it was announced, with only four weeks to examine the legislation and to check that it corresponds to the original intent.

I note that in setting out the counter schemes or devices to get around the intention stated last year involving transfer arrangements, there has been created a possible and presumably unintended distortion. Indeed, the practice that it is sought to circumvent might well have been successfully tackled under part IVa of the principal Act. All too frequently we are finding technical corrections where greater reliance should be placed by the Government on the application of part IVa. It is surprising that so few cases involving part IVa have come before the courts. That might be a reflection of the degree of its success. I signal to those listening to this debate that part IVa was an initiative of the Liberal-National Party coalition when in office.

Alternatively, a more specific amendment could be proposed to avoid taxing ineffective transactions, as will flow from the amendments proposed. All too frequently, this Government goes to inordinate lengths to collect the last few cents in every dollar. In so doing, it fails to recognise the huge costs involved in setting up what I might term `sham' or `anti-avoidance' transactions. If it was content to collect perhaps 98 per cent of the revenue then some of the technical detail could be eliminated from income tax law.

One outcome of the problems involved with foreign income is that more power inevitably tends to be given to the Commissioner. Once again, we find that the Commissioner is issuing rulings to clarify obscurities in the drafting of legislation. I refer the chamber to an article in the June issue of Charter Magazine, the official journal of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, entitled `The Commissioner Rules, OK', which outlines the results of that rushed legislation.

The majority of the major changes proposed in this Bill are welcomed, so long as they correspond to the original intent. Including the citizens of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands into the mainstream of Australian taxpayers is a case in point. I will leave the detailing of this change to my colleague Senator Tambling, who has a close interest in these islands as part of his constituency of the Northern Territory. Further, the tax concessions applying to other Australians living in remote Australia and its Territories will apply to relevant income and consequential taxes. The coalition also welcomes the move not to tax termination payments retrospectively. This Government has not always been so fair in its views regarding retrospectivity. I welcome the change and I hope it continues.

The thin capitalisation amendments are also welcome as far as they go. However, because of the haste involved in the original drafting of the Bill, the coalition had a number of concerns. I am pleased to say that the Government has heeded these in our negotiations and discussions outside this chamber and is introducing a number of amendments. One of these amendments will affect the securities lending arrangements and another will affect the deductibility that will now be allowed for expenses incurred in new fencing undertaken to prevent land degradation. I take this opportunity of congratulating, in particular, Peter Cochrane from John Kerin's office. He was particularly helpful in acknowledging and rectifying a number of the difficulties that were outlined in the negotiations in relation to the land degradation issues. I believe that this spirit of cooperation leads to far better goodwill and much better legislation as a consequence.

I hear another whisper-I would like to have it confirmed-that there will be another amendment affecting mine site rehabilitation. I have been informed that this could possibly be ready for the Budget session. With regard to the amendment being proposed on the securities issue, the coalition welcomes this because it picks up perhaps 90 per cent of our concerns. I point out the fundamental weaknesses as they stand at present, despite the amendment the Government intends to introduce during the committee stage of this debate to pick up an earlier weakness relating to a still earlier problem.

There appears to be a fundamental deficiency in the proposed new section 26bc (3) (c) in that it is a requirement that the specified events occur during the borrowing period in order for a lender to obtain relief under the section. In practice, this often will not be the case as distributions are often made some time after the closing date of the books. If the delivery of the security takes place before the relevant distribution is actually paid or made, then the requirements of the section unfortunately will not be met. It should be sufficient that the distribution, the issue, et cetera, is received by the borrower by reason of his being the holder of the security on the day the books are closed in respect of the payment of the distribution issue.

Proposed subsections 26bc (9c), (9d) and (9e) are also affected by the fundamental problem with proposed new section 26bc (3) (c) in that the conditions of these proposed subsections are impossible to satisfy where the borrowing period is brought to an end before the time for exercising the right or option of issuing the bonus share arises. Also, given that the maximum period of borrowing is now to be extended by this Bill, and there is a requirement that the replacement securities be identical securities, there is now a greater probability that the section cannot be complied with as a result of circumstances such as reductions of capital, calls on shares and conversions of convertible notes into shares during the lending period, resulting in an impossibility of replacing the security with an identical security. This is what these amendments fail to pick up. It would appear that in these circumstances an equivalent security should be acceptable. That would solve the problem.

I also have in my possession a detailed list of some of the fundamental weaknesses we perceive in the revised amendments affecting security funding and cum dividends. Because of the length of these and the shortness of time for debate, I have negotiated with Senator McMullan for these to be incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard these concerns regarding securities lending and cum dividend sale arrangements-matters of concern for which we will not be pressing for amendments but which we believe deserve the Government's attention at a subsequent time.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows--
Re: (1) Securities Lending; and
Re: (2) ``Cum dividend'' sale amendments
1. Introductory Comments

1.1 The amendments upon which I would like to comment under this heading are outlined in the Explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill in Chapter 16, which is headed ``Securities Lending Arrangements''.
1.2 The stated purpose of the amendments is ``to extend the taxation relief available for securities lending arrangements''.

1.3 If that was the effect of the amendments originally proposed by the Government, then it would have been a commendable result, notwithstanding that the introduction of the amendments was not foreshadowed by any Government announcement or preceded by any consultation with industry experts.
1.4 However, the amendments in question purport to do much more than their stated purpose in 2 respects:
(a) First, they are intended to transfer shareholder status in a securities lending arrangement.

(b) Secondly, and perhaps more significantly they are also intended to transfer shareholder status when shares or units listed on the Stock Exchange are sold ``cum dividend'' and the purchaser is not registered as the shareholder or unitholder in sufficient time to receive the dividend or distribution. These sales have nothing whatsoever to do with securities lending arrangements.

1.5 In both cases, dividend statements in the approved form are to be given and there are penalties if a person gives incorrect information in a statement required to be given under the proposed new provisions.
1.6 In addition, the transfer of shareholder status has certain consequences under the tax file number provisions, as they are to be amended by the Bill.

1.7 It appears that the proposed amendments have not been the subject of widespread informed public comment or analysis. However, detailed comments provided to the Government by two industry experts indicated the following:

(a) First, that there were a large number of major flaws in the drafting of the proposed amendments to section 26bc, which unwittingly would completely defeat the Government's stated intention of extending the taxation relief available for securities lending.
(b) Secondly, that, in addition, those amendments failed to deal at all (or at least dealt inadequately) with a number of situations which commonly arise.
(c) Thirdly, that the proposed provisions relating to ``cum dividend'' contracts might be based on several fundamental misconceptions regarding the effect of such contracts.
(d) Fourthly, that there might also be a number of serious deficiencies in the drafting of those provisions.
(e) Fifthly, that the ``cum dividend'' contract amendments might be incapable of working smoothly in practice and that this could be demonstrated by a number of practical examples.
1.8 Notwithstanding the seriousness of these concerns, the Government brought down the guillotine in the Lower House.
1.9 I will now comment on the Transfer of Shareholder Status provisions, before briefly turning to the amendments to the securities lending provisions contained in section 26bc.
2. ``Transfer of Shareholder Status'' amendments
2.1 One industry expert has expressed 2 paramount concerns regarding the ``Transfer of Shareholder Status'' provisions:
(a) First, that the Government has not articulated any policy reason for implementing the intended changes. For example:
(i) is the existing law inadequate or uncertain in its operation as regards the entitlement to dividends and franking credits?

(ii) Alternatively, does the way the existing law operates open up opportunities for tax avoidance or minimisation and, if so, could the Government explain what the perceived abuses are perceived to be, as is customary when anti-avoidance legislation is introduced into the Parliament?

(iii) Alternatively, is the existing position perceived as unsatisfactory in some way or other by institutional investors or individual investors who deal in the ordinary course on the stock exchange or by borrowers or lenders in securities lending arrangements and, if so, what are those perceived unsatisfactory results?
(iv) Alternatively, will the amendments assist the Stock Exchange in its quite proper moves to speed up the settlement of stock exchange transactions?

The bland statements in the Explanatory memorandum are singularly unhelpful in stating any policy reason for introducing the amendments. This is particularly lamentable in the light of the fact that they will impose increased paper work obligations on brokers and clients, will operate arbitrarily and capriciously and (as will become apparent in a moment) have unfair consequences as far as the quoting of tax file numbers is concerned.

(b) Secondly, the expert has stated, in a written opinion provided to the Government before the Bill was passed by the Lower House, that in his opinion the purported statement of relevant principles in the Explanatory Memorandum, upon which the specific amending provisions are based, is plainly wrong and misconceived. While the Government has acted on certain comments contained in the expert opinions provided to it, it has not seen fit either to address this fundamental concern nor to explain to this House why it believes that the expert concern is misplaced. Surely, in the interests of the orderly conduct of the stock market, an issue of such fundamental importance ought to be capable of achieving almost uniform professional and industry acceptance before it becomes the lynch pin of provisions which purport to have the far reaching effect of the Transfer of Shareholder Status provisions contained in the Bill.

2.2 I will now be more specific. Perhaps the fundamental concern expressed in one expert opinion provided to the Government is that a vendor of shares in a stock market transaction would not normally be under an obligation to transfer to the purchaser any particular shares which the vendor holds. In the case of shares in listed companies, damages for breach of contract would normally be regarded as an adequate remedy and therefore the remedy of specific performance would not be available. If that expert opinion provided to the Taxation Office is correct, then section 160aqua would not normally apply to a ``cum dividend contract'', which is completely at odds with the intention of the Government. I suggest that this possible deficiency might be able to be cured by the addition in proposed section 160aqua(1) (b) (i) of the words ``or an identical share'' after the words ``the share'' where they first appear.

2.3 In addition, the provisions also do not deal with short sales, which are permitted by law under certain circumstances. A short sale is one where, at the time of contracting to sell certain shares, the vendor doesn't own any of the share contracted to be sold. A purchaser may now know whether or not the contract of sale to him is a short sale, and yet even the intended result under the provisions would be different, depending upon whether or not a short sale is involved.

2.4 A similar fundamental concern exists in relation to the drafting of section 160aqua(1) (b) (ii), as it is proposed to be amended by the Government. The wording of the new provision assumes that a borrower under a securities lending arrangement can be under a legal obligation to pay a particular dividend to the lender. This assumption is completely at odds with the normal right of the borrower under such arrangements to deal with the borrowed securities in any way it wishes, including by disposing of them to a third party. Again, if the professional opinion regarding this provision is correct, the amending provisions will have no application to the transactions which they intend to embrace. I suggest that this possible deficiency might be able to be cured by the addition in proposed section 160aqu(1) (b) (ii) (a) of the words ``an amount equal to the amount of'' before the words ``the dividend''.

2.5 Perhaps the only explanation for the continued existence of these uncertainties, despite the fact that they are fundamental to the whole of the transfer of shareholder status provisions, is that the Government and its advisers are unable to come up with a workable set of legislative criteria for specifying the circumstances in which the provisions are to apply. For example, does the Government intend that a tracing test apply, so that you look to individual shares and see what happens to them, or is a numerical test sufficient, in that one should only look to the number of shares held by the vendor under a cum dividend sale or the borrower under a securities lending arrangement?

2.6 The submissions to Government have also raised the prospect that the provisions could theoretically require a person to give 2 dividend statements to different parties in respect of the same dividend. The proposed amendments give no guidance as to how this potential double jeopardy is to be resolved. Yet at the same time, the failure by a taxpayer to give the correct information constitutes an offence, which is punishable by a monetary penalty.

2.7 It is completely unacceptable for the Government to leave the resolution of all these matters to be determined in practice by the arbitrary rules of the stock exchange, which neither the Government nor this House has an opportunity to review.
2.8 But that is not the end of the possible deficiencies in these provisions:

(a) First, one of the expert opinions provided to the Government also pointed out that the provisions would not apply at all in the normal situation which commonly occurs where a vendor under a ``cum dividend'' sale has not provided the relevant scrip to his broker before the book's closing date and the broker has to borrow shares from a third party in order to complete the sale contract before the book's closing date. Professional opinion provided to the Opposition is that the further amendments proposed by the Government may not overcome this result, notwithstanding that they are apparently intended to do so. According to a leading text in this area, ``Stock Markets and the Securities Industry: Law and Practice'' by Professor Robert Baxt and others, 3rd edition 1988 at paragraph 806, conventional legal analysis of stock exchange transactions distinguishes four different contracts involved in a normal stock exchange transaction. The contract between the vendor and its broker is separate from the contract between the brokers themselves and from any contract between the vendor and the buyer. The doubt as to the operation of proposed section 160aqua(1) (b) (i) arises primarily because, once the stock exchange contract is completed, by the selling broker delivering scrip to the buying broker, which is then registered in the name of the buyer, the obligation of the vendor to its broker arises under the broker's right of indemnity, which is an incident of the separate contract between the vendor and its broker, and not under the contract for the sale of the share, entered into between the two brokers as agents for their respective undisclosed principals, which is the contract which most closely fits the description in proposed section 160aqua(1) (b) (i). The submissions originally provided to the Government also indicated that the provisions would not apply in a number of other situations which could be engineered by relevant parties, for example by transferring scrip to affiliates and so on. Professional opinion provided to the Opposition is that these methods of avoiding the operation of the provisions entirely remain unaffected. Is there any logical reason for permitting the application of the provisions to be avoided in this way or is it to be left to the ASX to provide in its business rules as to what the consequences of such avoidance are to be?

(b) Secondly, proposed section 160aquc also appears superfluous. It assumes that there was a ``cum dividend'' contract entered into in the ordinary course of trading on the stock exchange but one party to the contract did not have a securities dealer acting for him or her. I understand that these 2 propositions are inconsistent with one another in that the only transactions which can be said to be entered into in the ordinary course of trading on the stock exchange are so-called on market transactions in which each party to the transaction must have a broker acting for it. This irregularity was also appointed out to the Government and yet the Government has chosen to ignore it.

(c) Thirdly, proposed new subsection 221yhzk(5), which is the one situation in the draft Bill where the Government has seen fit to deny the stock exchange the power to regulate matters, is capable of operating quite unfairly in practice. This unfairness can affect the ordinary individual investor as much as the institutional investor who might be thought to be more capable of looking after its own interests. In essence, the provisions can compel a purchaser under a ``cum dividend'' contract and a lender under a securities lending arrangement to accept a lesser dividend or monetary adjustment than they might reasonably have expected, in circumstances where they have no means of knowing whether or not the vendor under the contract or the borrower has provided a tax file number to the Taxation Office. In other words, the purchaser or the lender, as the case may be, is entirely at the mercy of the other party to the relevant transaction. It is arbitrary and capricious to penalise the purchaser or the lender in a situation such as this where the result is entirely outside his control, particularly where the purchaser or the lender is an existing shareholder in the relevant company and has previously provided its own tax file number to the company. A much fairer result would be to compel the vendor/purchaser to pay or adjust on the basis of the gross dividend payable by the company and to retain any tax credit arising out of the fact that the vendor/borrower had failed to provide its tax file number to the company. This result would also be consistent with the ASX business rules and current market practice for similar situations, such as where withholding tax would be applicable. This has also been drawn this to Government's attention, but to no avail. The Government has failed to articulate any reason whatsoever, let alone a plausible or justifiable one, for such heavy handed, arbitrary and capricious interference in the normal contractual position between a vendor and purchaser or a lender and a borrower.

2.9 In summary then, the Government has not articulated any reason why the transfer of shareholder status provisions are an integral part of the amendments intended to extend the taxation relief available for securities lending arrangements or are otherwise desirable from a revenue standpoint.
2.10 Further, some serious concerns have been expressed by industry experts, which have not been addressed in the further amendments proposed by the Government in this House.
2.11 Further, the proposed amendments will apply, if at all, in an arbitrary and capricious way.

2.12 For all these reasons these provisions in the Bill should not be proclaimed until there has been a closer study of their potential impact and consultation with the stock exchange and any other industry experts or professional associations which might wish to put in a submission to the Government, directed at ensuring that any amendments of this kind:
* recognise the range of circumstances which can occur,
* are capable of implementation in practice, and
* operate fairly as between all the different parties involved in each transaction at which the provisions are aimed.
3. Securities Lending Amendments
3.1 I will now turn to the securities lending amendments.

3.2 The amendments introduced in the Senate to the securities lending provisions indicate that, on reflection, the Government accepts that much of the criticism directed at the original drafting of those provisions was well founded.

3.3 The orderly conduct of the stock market requires that there be liquidity in terms of the availability of scrip. This is in order that transactions entered into in the ordinary course of the stock market can be settled quickly. In addition, the options market, which provides a facility to institutional investors to effectively hedge their portfolios, depends to a large extent on liquidity being available in the market place. The need for this liquidity has been recognised by the revenue authorities in both the United States and the United Kingdom and is now the subject of specific legislative relief in both jurisdictions. In this Bill the Government has attempted to extend similar relief in Australia. However, were it not for the initiative taken by industry experts, the result could have been exactly the opposite to that intended by the Government, with the result that, once the impact of the new provisions became widely known, there would be insufficient liquidity in the market for the orderly conduct of the stock market, the settlement of stock exchange transactions could take longer and the options market could have come to a standstill.

3.4 Fortunately, the further amendments now proposed go a long way towards achieving the stated effect of the proposed amendments, which is to extend the taxation relief available for securities lending arrangements, despite the fact that the amendments originally proposed would not have achieved any such effect.

3.5 Probably the major practical situation which is not dealt with by the Bill is the situation where a security is lent under a securities lending arrangement, a right or option in respect of that security arises while the loan is still on foot and the lender directs the borrower to exercise the right or option. In that situation, there seems to be no logical reason why the return of a security identical to that the subject of the exercise of the right or option or an identical right or option should not qualify for the relief.
3.6 Splits and consolidations of shares, as well as partly paid shares, are also not covered by the relief, though each of these situations could occur in practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These issues are of particular concern to the operations of the Stock Exchange, and rightly so. The Stock Exchange, unfortunately, has not consulted with the Opposition on this issue as it prefers to deal with government. However, on advice received by the Government, it concerns me that the Stock Exchange may not be following a strictly legalistic approach to what it believes to be a more efficient movement of documents and entitlements. The Liberal-National Party coalition is of the view, based on legal advice, that this procedure may not be in accordance with the Bill as it has been debated today, plus the amendments. However, given the volume and technical nature of the concerns, I have sought the leave of the Senate for those sorts of issues to be evaluated by the authorities at a subsequent time. Unless some technical changes are made to the legislation, I believe that in future a court challenge could well occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to another important part of the Bill, which sets out the arrangements for capital expenditure on land degradation measures. Specifically, the Bill proposes to allow primary producers and rural businesses-and that is the extension, which we on this side welcome-to deduct the expenses involved in erecting fences separating different classes of land, thereby preventing land degradation by livestock. Unfortunately, the Bill does not give an explanation of what `other' businesses are; they could be all sorts of businesses. I think my colleague in the other place Mr Ian McLachlan indicated one sort of unsavoury business that could erect a fence and claim a deduction. However, I believe that this provision is far too open-ended, despite the substantiation requirements, because it tends to give very much a free kick to the big entrepreneurs in land-such as the Kerry Packers, who have cash-in the bigger States to erect a lot of internal fencing at the cost of the taxpayers, whereas primary producers and others on smaller allotments, certainly in the more built-up areas, do not have the same freedom in terms of their ability to write off such expenses.

Because it is necessary to have a land management plan-and we acknowledge that as a significant improvement to a whole farm plan-in providing a substantiation, it is necessary to be able to claim 100 per cent deductibility for erecting fences that separate different classes of land and so prevent land degradation by livestock. A farmer can now prepare his own plan, but it must be approved by an appropriate authority which has the skills required to undertake that exercise. In order to be eligible for deductibility, the land management plan, with the principle purpose of preventing degradation of land, may be prepared by the farmer but must be authorised by an authorised body. The Government has introduced this change since the Bill was brought on in the lower House, and the coalition again thanks the Government for listening to the majority of its requests in this area.

However, a dilemma has been raised. The Bill introduces what I refer to as direct cross-compliance arrangements. The Government believes that these are necessary to ensure that deductible expenditure is being used for the purpose for which it was intended. At the same time, the direct cross-compliance arrangements introduce significant compliance costs, but these have been minimised as a result of the Government amendment to be moved later concerning the administration of the new tax regime. One of the difficulties that I see about these cross-compliance arrangements is that they tend to run somewhat counter to the self-assessment concept of putting the onus of proof for adequate substantiation on the taxpayer. I am very much in favour of ensuring a high degree of adequacy and compliance in terms of the necessary documentation to support substantiation.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission this morning threw out key elements of the waterfront industry proposal personally negotiated by the Prime Minister, can the Minister explain where this decision leaves the Government's waterfront reform program? Will the Prime Minister now be using his `newly reconfirmed' leadership skills to involve himself personally again in the issue by reconvening the parties and seeking to renegotiate a new package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have often cautioned senators not to get too excited about counting chickens before they are hatched and so on. I do so again because the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission has just been released. The Government will need to study it. On a preliminary reading of the decision, there have to be mixed feelings about the outcome. For example, the Government regrets that the Commission has decided not to endorse at this point the second and third tranches of the 6.12 per cent increase in the waterfront reform package which would underpin productivity increases of a very much greater order.

ANSWER.PARA: It is obvious that there now needs to be further consultation between employers and unions in relation to the complexities of the decision and to examine what future steps may be necessary to meet the needs of all parties for waterfront reform. The Government will have to be involved in that process. Whether the Prime Minister is personally involved is a matter for him to determine after he has studied the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: could Senator Button inform the Senate whether the Government intends to support the umpire's decision?
—In the early part of my answer, I said that the Government has not fully studied the decision yet.
—If it suits the Government; it doesn't even believe in the principles any more.

—Senator Campbell will understand-as a senator with the more logical mind than Senator Alston, I suspect-that it would be silly for the Government to make a pronouncement on that until further consideration has been given to the details of the decision.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to an overnight announcement in Pretoria and I ask: what are the implications of the repeal of the South African Population Registration Act for the reform process and for Australia's policy towards South Africa? What is the assessment of the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been widely expected and foreshadowed, the South African Parliament voted yesterday to repeal at last the Population Registration Act. While no further classifications will be made on the basis of race, the existing population register, which does assign all South Africans to one of four main groups, will remain in force until the Constitution has been replaced. Until such time, it cannot be entirely removed for electoral and other reasons and that, I think, is well understood.

ANSWER.PARA: The other so-called pillars of apartheid-the Separate Amenities Act, the Group Areas Act and the land Acts-have now all been repealed. But, of course, it is the case that until such time as there is a new Constitution in place giving the vote to all South Africans, apartheid will remain in place and the battle against it will not have been won.

That is not to belittle the actions that have already been taken by the South African Government which, as I and the Prime Minister have made clear on a number of occasions, the Australian Government very much applauds. In meetings with President de Klerk and others during my visit to South Africa I certainly made it very clear that Australia is fully supportive of the course of action that the Government has embarked upon to dismantle apartheid. I also urged the South African Government to take quick and effective action to overcome the remaining problems or obstacles standing in the way of the formal commencement of negotiations including, in particular, the full and final release of all political prisoners, the indemnification-in order to enable them to return-of all remaining exiles, and the addressing of the appalling problem of internecine violence in the townships.

Those obstacles are, in my judgment, on their way to being cleared, but they must be cleared before the first phase of sanctions can be lifted in accordance with present Commonwealth and Australian policy. I certainly hope, expect and continue to urge that significant progress will continue to be made thereafter to ensure that the process does not stop with the removal simply of these pieces of legislation-important as that achievement is-but does genuinely result in the final destruction of the abhorrent regime of apartheid.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to figures just released by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development showing that Australia's average rate of economic growth from 1980 to 1989, when adjusted for population growth, was the fifth lowest in the 24-member nation OECD and that only Iceland, New Zealand, Greece and the Netherlands recorded lower per capita growth rates per head of population. Does the Minister agree with these figures? Would he also agree that if 1990 were included Australia's economic growth ranking for the decade would be even lower? In light of that, could he explain to the Senate the reasons for Australia's dismal economic performance during the life of the Hawke Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the figures in front of me, but my recollection is that the rate of growth of the Australian economy throughout the 1980s was double what it was in the 1970s.
—Not when adjusted for population.

—Senator Short knows that is true. We have had abysmally low rates of growth in Australia since about 1960 compared with many other countries. Of course, more importantly, we had low growth rates compared with the larger trading partners with which we now conduct something like 70 per cent of our trade, as distinct from 20 or 25 years ago when much more of our trade was with Europe and North America.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I saw these figures which were published by the OECD in a newspaper somewhere. I have not studied them at any length and I certainly have not made the calculation in respect of the calendar year 1990. I think if the financial year 1989-90 were included the position would be considerably better. Senator Short picks his datum point in order to devise an argument, but that is really all he is doing.

If Senator Short seeks to establish the point that in the 1980s Australia had a relatively low growth rate compared with many other countries, that is a matter which I would certainly agree with without going back to the figures. But the fact of the matter is that there are peculiar circumstances pertaining to the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Labor Government.
—No, because of its very considerable trade exposure-it is a very highly traded economy.
—That is not right either.

—Senator Short asks questions about the recession all of the time. The fundamental problem, which his side agreed with in 1990, was that the economy was overheated and, as a result, it was bringing in a much higher level of imports than the country could stand. That is something which Senator Short argued because it suited him to argue it at that time. It now suits him to put forward another argument in the form of a question. I do not have much disagreement with Senator Short about the figures; what conclusions can be drawn from them is a totally different matter.

—Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. In light of his answer, which did not in any way refute the figures I quoted, do they not simply prove that this Government's much trumpeted achievement of economic growth and employment creation was yet another untruth told to the Australian electorate at the last election?

—That is hardly a question. It is just a piece of political sloganeering to which I do not particularly need to respond. If the honourable senator wishes to argue the question about employment growth and new jobs created, he can direct to me later at Question Time or later this week a sharp question-if he is capable of that-about this issue, and I will give him an answer-
—We will do that later too.
—Okay. That is a promise. The honourable senator can do that at the time. But his supplementary question is scarcely a question at all. I do not think I need respond beyond that point.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to another overnight announcement, the appointment of Sir Ninian Stephen as chairperson of the Northern Ireland peace talks. What is the Government's reaction to that appointment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is delighted with the confirmation now of Sir Ninian Stephen's choice as the chairman of the talks proposed to be held between all parties to the Northern Ireland conflict situation. The Australian Government has long supported a dialogue between those parties addressing the issue of some devolved administration for Northern Ireland since the idea was first suggested by the United Kingdom Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, Mr Peter Brooke, in May last year.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have already said on the public record, I cannot think of a more distinguished, dignified, astute and charming statesman to handle that job than Sir Ninian. I have no doubt, and I am sure all honourable senators agree with me, that if there is ever to be a man with the personal attributes and demeanour to bring together the disparate elements involved, it is Sir Ninian. I am sure that all Australians are very proud that Sir Ninian has been selected as chairman and will join with me in hoping that the talks will lead to a peaceful solution to the vexed and indeed tragic situation in Northern Ireland.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce may be aware of a decentralised manufacturing operation of McMillan Pty Ltd in the city of Echuca, in my home State of Victoria, which produces gas cylinders in a modern and efficient, purpose-built facility that was officially opened, I believe on his behalf, some six months ago by Minister Blewett. Is he aware that this Echuca operation is now at risk because of imports of competing products from Thailand? I remind the Minister that, in accordance with Australian standards, every portable liquid petroleum gas (LPG) cylinder manufactured in Australia is subjected to rigorous individual and group inspection by means of pressure testing, radiography and random destructive testing, and that materials and personnel used in fabrication must be certificated and qualified. Full type testing of all designs is also required. Can he give absolute assurance that all portable LPG cylinders imported into Australia have been subjected to the same inspection and control regime, and can he verify that every such cylinder fully conforms with the relevant Australian standards? How does he defend the Government's industry and trade policies when they put at risk small decentralised operations like this in which local people have invested alongside the manufacturer to support growth in their community and more balanced development for the country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a number of questions which Senator Powell asked me. She ended by asking me to defend policies which really are not related to the question. I will give her an answer to the substance of her question, and I think she will see that. I am not directly aware of the problems of the company to which she refers, but it is alleged by her in her question that those problems stem from LPG cylinders imported from Thailand. Certainly, I will ask my Department to make some inquiries of the company immediately to see what its position is.

ANSWER.PARA: All portable LPG cylinders are subjected to the same testing procedures, irrespective of whether they are manufactured in Australia or elsewhere and are imported. Responsibility for testing LPG cylinders rests with the State and Territory governments and is covered by the dangerous goods regulations of each of those jurisdictions. I can read out the relevant Australian standards, but I do not think I need to. I have those standards here, and I can provide them to Senator Powell later.

In the case of imported LPG cylinders, design approval to Australian standards, or an equivalent international standard, has to be sought from the relevant State government authority under which the cylinders are imported and sold. If a design is improved, the imported cylinders are required to be examined and tested as required by Australian standards at a test station. Testing includes a prescribed number from each consignment being selected at random by the testing authority. That is the same as for locally produced cylinders. They are also subjected to destructive testing at a National Australia Testing Authority registered laboratory.

In light of this, I do not believe there is unfair competition from imported LPG cylinders due to differential testing and inspection requirements. There may be other aspects of alleged unfair competition which the company may address to my Department when it gets in touch with it about this issue; but it is not on the basis of testing. I add the general warning that sometimes companies faced with competition find reasons for their loss of market share which are not related only to competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the Minister provide me with information about testing during the course of production, because part of the requirement in this country refers to materials used in the fabrication, and to certification and qualification of the personnel involved. Would the Minister, when he does get the information from his Department, undertake to give that information to me in the Senate at a later stage?
—There can be no question of Australian authorities supervising processes of production in other countries, whether it be Thailand or anywhere else. But they are required to manufacture-
—Yes, but doesn't that have some relationship to standards that are--

—Stop mumbling, Senator. They are required to manufacture according to international design standards, and when they are imported to Australia they are required to meet all the other standards which are applied to Australian manufactured cylinders. Last Friday, I was at the largest producer of these products in Australia, and it was certainly not making any complaint.
—They are not a small, decentralised operation.

—Precisely; it is not a small, decentralised operation. Perhaps that is why a small, decentralised operation finds it hard, in a competitive world, to compete with a very big operation within Australia; but it has nothing to do with standards.

—Did the Minister for Social Security see a report on 12 June 1991 in the Australian alleging that unemployment beneficiaries employed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the forthcoming census would lose their unemployment benefit? What does the Minister propose to do about the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think something needs to be done about the situation, but I am not certain that it ought to occur at the social security end. The Social Security Act requires that any income earned by beneficiaries be taken into account in the payment period in which it is earned, irrespective of when it is received. That is done to minimise the loss of unemployment benefit, particularly for those who earn small amounts in casual employment from time to time. It enables them to take full advantage of the income test free area and, at the same time, protects taxpayers and makes sure that full account is taken of substantial casual earnings.

ANSWER.PARA: To illustrate that point, it is worth noting two examples. If a single adult beneficiary obtains a part time job paying $50 a week for six weeks, under current legislation that beneficiary would lose $60 for the whole period. To go to the alternative suggested in that same article, taking that into account at the time it is paid, the beneficiary would lose a total of $200. That is obviously not in the interests of either taxpayers or the beneficiary in that we are urging that people maintain periods of work whenever possible.

At the other end of the scale, if a person were to earn substantial amounts of money from casual work the loss can vary dramatically. For example, if a person were to work in full time casual work for three weeks earning $300 a week, that person would lose $477. If that individual were paid $900 one-off at the end of three weeks he or she would lose only $277, and that would leave open a very big area for unscrupulous people to exploit to their benefit.

Having said that, obviously I am of the view that there should be no change in the way the Social Security Act treats the money that is earned. But it is obvious that some employers, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) included, have to take into account those arrangements. We have been urging it to do so for several years. Each time a census approaches there is the same argument about the way in which census collections are made.

I am informed that, as a result of discussions with my Department, the ABS has come to an alternative payment arrangement for those who will be conducting the census that will, I hope, remove the kind of controversy we have seen in the last few days. Certainly the way in which Social Security treats earned income will remain the same. It is fair and just both to benefit recipients and to taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Resources to the claim that the Jawoyn Aboriginal people are opposed to mining of Coronation Hill because it is contained within their Bula sickness country. Is it a fact that Aboriginal Exploration and Development Pty Ltd has recently entered into a joint venture agreement with Poseidon Exploration Ltd for the purpose of exploration and mining on land claimed to be Jawoyn traditional country? I see Senator Collins nodding. Will the Minister confirm that one of these licences, numbered EL6354, covers some of the area regarded as sickness country? Is the Minister aware that the Northern Land Council has agreed to the granting of these exploration licences? Finally, what is the difference between the area of the sickness country contained in EL6354 and that contained in the area occupied by Coronation Hill?
—My only knowledge of--
—Do you know the answer to this one?

—Does Senator Walters want an answer or not? My only knowledge of this matter is what I have read in newspapers; that is, a distinction has been drawn between the sickness country, which is part of the conservation zone, and the area over which leases had recently been granted by the Jawoyn people to the company to which Senator Crichton-Browne refers. I will get a full brief on the questions Senator Crichton-Browne raised and give him an answer in due course.
—I ask a supplementary question because I did not hear Senator Bolkus. Is he conceding that both areas are in the sickness country?

—In answer to the first question Senator Crichton-Browne asked I said that my understanding was based very much on what I have read in the media. I do not have a brief on this. I did say that, from what I have read and understand, there is very much a distinction between the territory over which the leases have been granted in recent days by the Jawoyn Association, through, I believe, the Northern Land Council as its representative, and the area that is now subject to discussion in respect of the conservation zone. I will get more information for Senator Crichton-Browne and give it to him as soon as I can.
