—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister provide any recent evidence to support the view that the African National Congress (ANC) is the most representative of the black political organisations in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Until the holding of a free and fair election in South Africa it will not be possible to determine with any certainty the popularity of the various political groups in South Africa, but most political commentators in South Africa, on the basis of previous polling evidence, anecdotal material and analytical research, have taken the view that the ANC is by far the most representative black organisation. That view is endorsed and reinforced by the most recent published poll on the subject, which just happened to come out a couple of days ago, over the weekend, by the well-respected market research company Markinor. According to the Markinor poll, 71 per cent of urban black South Africans would vote for the ANC; 3 per cent for Inkatha; 4 per cent for the National Party; and 4 per cent for the Pan-Africanist Congress, the PAC. For choice of leader, Nelson Mandela was first preference for 65 per cent of urban blacks. De Klerk received 13 per cent; PAC leader Makwetu received 4 per cent and Inkatha's Chief Buthelezi 3 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: I will describe the nature of the Markinor poll. It included 1,300 blacks and 800 whites in the predominantly urban areas of Johannesburg, Pretoria, Durban, Port Elizabeth, East London and Cape Town. Unlike most previous polls, respondents were given a secret ballot, which is clearly a far superior method to previous methods used. Of course, it is the case that it cannot be assumed that those statistics would be repeated if rural blacks were taken into account, and in particular it is obviously the case that Inkatha has almost saturation support as far as blacks in rural Natal are concerned. Equally clearly, on analytical and other evidence, that is not so for the other provinces of South Africa. Given the concentration of black people in those urban metropoles that were the subject of this survey, this clearly amounts to compelling recent further evidence for the view that the ANC is the most widespread supported black organisation.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just repeat the figures because clearly they have not quite sunk in. Among urban black South Africans in the huge metropolitan areas of Johannesburg, Pretoria, Durban, Port Elizabeth, East London and Cape Town, a sample of 1,300 black people by a highly respected marketing organisation conducting a secret ballot method produced the following results: Inkatha, 3 per cent; National Party, 4 per cent; PAC, 4 per cent; ANC, 71 per cent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am glad that he has so much information today. Yesterday, when answering a question from Senator Hill, the Minister said that the assistance being given under the special assistance program for South Africa and Namibia and the special program of assistance for South Africa is `quintessentially, classically, development assistance'. Can the Minister give any quantitative assessment of the benefits from the sum of approximately $17m that has been spent since 1986-87? For example, what percentage of these moneys has been spent in the disadvantaged rural black Africa areas, and is it a fact that, prior to the review by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau last year in relation to scholarships, they were awarded without guidelines either as to academic qualifications or any means testing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to give a much fuller answer in writing to the question about how those previous moneys have been disbursed over recent years and the nature of the returns that have been received in terms of people trained, people educated and people otherwise assisted. The money in question is spread across an extraordinary variety of self-help programs, scholarships for formal education, training programs for less formal education, institution building support activity of one kind or another, and rehabilitation activity of one kind or another, particularly in relation to people coming back to the country from exile abroad. The money has been primarily concentrated in the urban rather than the rural areas.
—Where the minority of blacks live.

—Where an extraordinary amount of human misery exists at the moment, Senator Baume. If the honourable senator could shift his eyes away from his prejudiced perception of how this country has been administered in the past and try to focus for a moment on the enormous store of human misery that is concentrated in those townships that stretch endlessly across the landscape; where innumerable people have been coming in from the rural areas of Ciskei and Transkei and elsewhere in recent times; where the population has been exploding with dramatic intensity in recent times; where housing has not been supplied on anything like the scale necessary to meet the needs of that burgeoning population; where educational resources have not been supplied on anything like the scale--
—And what are they like in the rural areas?

—In the rural area with KwaZulu and with the support of the South African Government there has been a much greater allocation of resources in those particular homelands on a selective basis. It is those blacks not living in some of those homeland areas where the major problems are concentrated.

ANSWER.PARA: But do not tell me for a moment that the homelands are the source of all good things so far as the supply of material resources is concerned. In the Bophuthatswana area in particular, if one looks at the townships spreading and coming into the Johannesburg-Pretoria area from there, the misery is just as extensive, just as intensive, and that is combined with the situation where there is an absolute minimum amount of employment opportunities to go with the situation thus created.

The scale of the misery that exists for just about all of the 27 million or 28 million black people in South Africa has to be seen, has to be physically experienced, to even begin to be understood. I confess that I had no idea of the immensity of the trauma, the immensity of the disaster, that has been wrought for so many human beings by a disgustingly immoral regime, which honourable senators opposite have consistently supported through their party for decades. Honourable senators opposite have consistently refused to support the overthrow by way of an effective sanctions regime. Do not give me that hypocrisy; do not give me that humbug--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President--
—Order!
—Let us have a little bit of support for the overturn of a regime which desperately needs it.
—Order! Resume your seat!

—Mr President, we are entitled in this place to rational discussion. We are not entitled and, indeed, do not deserve that sort of tired and emotional prejudice. I ask you to invite the Minister not simply to resort to cheap abuse of this side of the House. I invite you to rule him out of order and ask him to apologise to all those on this side whom he smeared in the same way that he has attempted to smear anyone who has disputed the propriety of his actions in recent days.
—Order! There is no point of order and I am not going to allow a debate to occur over it.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I shall resist the temptation to debate the Minister's answer-we accept that conditions have not been as they should be. What we are asking for is real information about the money that has been spent. Clearly, the Minister is not able to give this information. How can the Minister then justify yesterday telling the Senate that the money spent under the programs I quoted is `quintessentially, classically, development assistance' without being able to back up those statements? Why are we then not entitled to conclude that the money has been spent as patronage in support of a political group and not to relieve the very things that the Minister is speaking about?

—I was entitled to conclude that and Senator Reid is entitled to conclude that because the money has been expended from the Budget under the clear definition of overseas development assistance within the criteria formulated under the Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. If the money was spent otherwise than in accordance with those formal criteria for development assistance, it would be appropriate for the Auditor-General to have drawn attention to that, and no doubt he would have. It would also have been perfectly appropriate and possible for Senator Reid to have drawn attention to it in Budget Estimates committees, which she has never done. I said that I would provide further information as to the way in which the money has been spent but its classification as classic development assistance is not in doubt.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the Minister's answer to question No. 561 from Senator Vallentine, in which he stated that `the possibility of sales of Australian uranium to Indonesia at an appropriate time in the future has been discussed informally between officials'. I ask the Minister: is he aware that in April this year Charles Savage, an adviser to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, wrote to Greenpeace Australia saying that `the Australian Government has not entered into or commenced negotiations on any agreement to sell Australian uranium to Indonesia, or to facilitate such sales by any other organisation'? Can the Minister explain the apparent contradiction between the two statements and clarify the Government's policy on uranium sales to Indonesia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say, with all due respect to Senator Coulter, that the nature of the question just demonstrates how far Senator Coulter is from understanding how the real world actually operates in terms of the difference between discussions, negotiations and agreements. I am aware of Mr Savage's letter to Greenpeace Australia, and there is simply no contradiction between this and my reply to Senator Vallentine.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Savage, in his reply, was referring to a possible nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement, which was the subject of discussions between officials of the two governments in late 1990. Such an agreement would not provide for commercial transfers of Australian uranium to Indonesia.

There was also informal discussion, not including anything in the nature of negotiations toward an agreement, of the possibility that Indonesia might be at some stage interested in obtaining uranium from Australia at an appropriate time in the future for its proposed nuclear power industry. Government policy in relation to uranium sales of course requires, among other things, the conclusion of a bilateral safeguards agreement. We are so many steps away from the kind of transaction that Senator Coulter has in mind that it is simply nonsensical to suggest that there is any subterranean agenda in this respect at work. The issue has been informally canvassed, but absolutely no more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In earlier times, I understand that Indonesia was contemplating building a Candu reactor using unenriched uranium. Can the Minister give any indication as to what type of reactor Indonesia is now contemplating and, if it is requiring enriched uranium, where Australia's uranium may be enriched for supply to Indonesia?
—I will take that question on notice and endeavour to give Senator Coulter an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask: had Cabinet approved the unprecedented payment of Australian taxpayers' money to the African National Congress? If not, who made the decision and when was the decision made?

—It was the subject of some discussion, as I recall, in either the Cabinet or the Expenditure Review Committee. I need to check my recollection of that. I know that it is on the agenda for formal endorsement in a budgetary context. It is clearly my understanding and the subject of clear discussion between the Prime Minister and me that the money in question will under no circumstances be diverted from the existing aid budget, but will involve a supplementary addition to that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which really asks for clarification. I take it that, if it is for ratification by Cabinet, it was not approved by Cabinet. I therefore ask again: who made the decision to make the gift, and when was the decision made?
—I have nothing that I can usefully add to my previous answer.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the Senate of the percentage of DDT and dieldrin found in livestock and other parts of the food chain throughout Australia in the past year? What action has the Government taken to reduce the amount of chemicals found in food and livestock in this country? Can the claim made recently in the Age that Victorian food is among the cleanest and safest to eat in the world be supported?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer available for Senator Zakharov. Based on preliminary results from the national residue survey for 1990, the percentage of animals tested in which the residues of DDT and dieldrin were found was extremely low at less than one per cent. Of these samples, only five in 10,000 showed levels in excess of the relevant food standard. For dairy products, 1.76 per cent of samples showed residues of DDT and 2.03 per cent of samples showed residues of dieldrin.

ANSWER.PARA: About 0.25 per cent of samples showed residues in excess of maximum residue limits. For grains, 0.46 per cent of samples showed residues of DDT and 0.15 per cent of samples showed residues of dieldrin. Some 0.15 per cent of these samples are above the maximum residue limit. Also for fresh fruit and vegetables, 5.83 per cent of samples showed residues of DDT and 0.97 per cent of samples showed residues of dieldrin. Of these samples, less than 0.1 per cent were above the maximum residue limit.

The second part of Senator Zakharov's question goes to what action the Government has been taking to ensure that food is safe. Since the 1960s, the Commonwealth Government's national residue survey has tested a variety of foods for chemical residues. In response to the detection of residues of organochlorin chemicals in meat shipped to the United States of America in 1987, the survey was intensified. As well as that, a market basket survey is also conducted by the Department of Community Services and Health which focuses on the food obtainable at the retail level.

I would also note that the use of DDT has been prohibited and the use of dieldrin for agricultural purposes has been banned in Australia. An additional extensive testing program for organochlorins was implemented by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS). This program covers all meat species and has the objective of progressively establishing that individual properties throughout Australia are cleared of organochlorin residue problems.

More than one million tests have been performed to date. Some 4,000 properties out of 140,000 tested still require further testing. These properties are mainly those where previous agricultural and other practices have left residues in the general environment. The AQIS program has resulted in the residue violation rate in meat reducing from 0.4 per cent to less than 0.1 per cent. This rate is one of the lowest in the world. The AQIS also conducts other testing programs to identify and eliminate potential problems with chemical and other residues in food products. The national antibacterial residue minimisation program, for example, is an AQIS State program designed to heighten awareness among producers in the antibacterial residue issue by a system of abattoir and laboratory testing and the trace back of positive results to the property of origin.

As I said in respect to this last program, but it can be said in respect to others, many of them are run in conjunction with State authorities and include extension to education for primary producers, suppliers and users on correct chemical application and withholding periods. It is fair to say from this information, and from the information that the Government has available to it, that food produced in Australia-not just Victoria-is amongst the safest in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that in February this year the African National Congress (ANC) paid 27 million rand for a new headquarters building in central Johannesburg? What percentage of Australian financial assistance provided under the previous and present special assistance program to South Africans and Namibians was provided to the ANC? What assurance can the Minister give that none of that money, or any other money from Australian taxpayers, was used by the ANC in the purchase of its headquarters building? What guarantees can the Minister give the Australian people that his latest grant to the ANC will not be put to purposes other than those intended?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the sum of money that may have been paid by the ANC for its new building in Johannesburg, or indeed whether it had to pay any money at all. Certainly, no money that has been provided by way of South African development assistance by Australia has gone directly to the ANC, other than the amount I announced last week for the establishment of an economic planning department; namely $83,000. I am absolutely certain that no money that has been previously identified for the programs, in consultation with the ANC, has been devoted to that particular purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also certain and can give an absolute assurance that there is no question of any money that has presently been supplied directly-that is, the $83,000-or to programs that have been developed in association with or in consultation with the ANC being used for this purpose. It would be utterly at odds with the defined purpose of these particular moneys. Auditing procedures would make perfectly clear the confirmation of that, should that ever be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In a previous answer, the Minister advised the Senate that he could not tell where the $17m went. He now proceeds to tell the Senate that none of the money has been allocated. Can he give a definitive answer to the Senate?

—With the utmost respect, I said that I would give a further detailed written answer as to the precise allocation of the moneys that have been identified for that particular South African program in the past. I know perfectly well what general criteria in terms of overseas development assistance have been applied in defining and describing those programs. I equally clearly know perfectly well what the limits of those moneys are so far as totally extraneous purposes are concerned of the kind that Senator Boswell has described. I can answer that question with complete confidence without necessarily being aware of where every dollar of the other moneys has been allocated-without taking that on notice.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What is the Government doing about unscrupulous practices by lending bodies in regard to loan guarantees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The deregulation of the banking industry has certainly brought many lending practices into the spotlight. As the recession has been having some effect in the community, it is quite true that the practice of lending bodies to seek guarantors for loans granted to other borrowers is tending to increase. There is no doubt that there is sometimes too much of an emphasis on the part of those banks and lending institutions on getting security for the loan rather than explaining the effect of obtaining the guarantee from those persons who are under the influence, in many instances, of the borrower and who, to their own disadvantage, agree to act as guarantors.

ANSWER.PARA: There are many examples of those who, by reason of their age, business inexperience, lack of facility in English or close personal relationship with the borrower, find themselves under some sort of pressure to act as guarantors in these situations. There is much evidence in the community that this unconscionable practice of obtaining such guarantees has been leading to great distress in many instances. In the early 1980s the High Court of Australia developed an equitable principle to relieve an aged immigrant couple of their guarantee obligations to a bank because they were at a disadvantage and the bank had taken no steps to make sure that they were properly informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did one recently.

—I think Senator Panizza is referring to when the National Australia Bank was involved in a case where an invalid pensioner couple provided a guarantee on behalf of their son. In fact, the bank moved in to take their home as security against the non-payment of the loan by the son. The Trade Practices Commission has come to a settlement with the National Australia Bank in that case. The settlement terms involve the Trade Practices Commission assisting the National Australia Bank to review its procedures for obtaining loan guarantees. A more general inquiry into these matters is also being conducted by the Trade Practices Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, through the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs, is also working on a number of related fronts in relation to this issue: for example, by seeking protection for co-borrowers and guarantors in State credit legislation, by providing assistance to a law reform inquiry on personal property securities and by, of course, keeping some monitoring eye on the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms such as the banking ombudsman scheme provides. The banking ombudsman has recently signalled an intention to work with the banks on a broader exercise to the same effect. I hope that the whole lending industry can be involved in such a project.

I believe that the principle that lenders should not act in an unconscionable manner and take advantage of those who act as guarantors who may be lacking in a complete understanding of the sort of commitment they are making is a matter that ought to be of concern in the community. I believe that the Trade Practices Commission is taking a very good stand and role in relation to lending institutions that are involved in seeking such guarantees. I certainly hope that the financial community, as I believe is the case, reforms its practices and ensures that its personnel have sufficient training to enable them to use the guarantee system in a fair manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and refers to grants made to projects nominated by the African National Congress (ANC). I refer the Minister to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau review of the special program of assistance to South Africans and Namibians, which looked at arrangements for funding projects identified by the ANC, including the $15m promised for the next three years-or at least we think it has been promised for the next three years. This review made a number of references to inadequate reporting on the use of Australian funds in the four years to July 1990. Are there any cases where grants have been made to ANC-nominated groups for which reports as required by government financial procedures have not been received? Have further repayments ever been made, despite the absence of proper reports from ANC-nominated groups? If the Minister cannot give categorical assurances on these points, how can he assert that funds could not have been diverted for naked political purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to seek further information on the particular allocation of these moneys. It is perfectly common when one is disbursing an aid budget of $1.3 billion to scores of countries around the region and the world, to scores of international institutions and to scores of non-government organisations, that even with the most rigorous auditing procedures in the world sometimes there are time lapses involved in getting reports and in the phasing of subsequent grants. There is no reason to assume that there is any particular issue here so far as these grants are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat: there is no question of any of these moneys being allocated to purposes other than development assistance properly so broadly defined, and I find it inconceivable that any money could have been applied to the purpose of the building, which is the specific question I was asked. As to anything else implied in the question, Senator Kemp will just have to curb his racing hormones and wait for my written answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. For the Minister's interest, the information is actually in a report issued by his Department; perhaps he may care to read that report. My supplementary question is this: is it not a fact that there is a practice whereby financial statements from projects are audited by the African National Congress itself rather than by independent auditors?
—I will take that further question on notice. I have already undertaken to give a response on the subject of auditing procedures; that reply is on its way.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs: is he aware that under proposed National Food Authority legislation, food authorities will be required to harmonise Australian domestic food standards with international food standards? Does this mean that the level of protection currently afforded to Australian consumers will be reduced as a result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the matter raised by Senator Sherry is of considerable concern to honourable senators, particularly Senator Boswell, who has taken an interest in it. The National Food Authority, in taking into account the standards that ought to be set to ensure that food marketed in Australia is of an adequate standard for public health and safety, will be able to take into account international food standards, but very much as a last matter. The National Food Authority will have regard to the following criteria: the protection of public health and safety as an absolute first priority; the provision of adequate information to enable consumers to make informed choices; the promotion of fair trading in food; promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry; and the promotion of consistency with international food standards. If the harmonisation of Australian food standards with international food standards were to create any danger at all to the health and safety of those who consume food in Australia--
—That's right. We should lead the world.

—We should lead the world in many instances; it would be good to reinforce that, because that would create in Australia's international trading favour a very favourable impression of our high standards in relation to the food products we market. But there is no doubt that, if harmonisation would lead to any risk to public health and safety, the Australian standard would prevail in that instance.

ANSWER.PARA: There will, of course, be increasing pressure at an international level-and I think Senator Button has been adverting to this-under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements to harmonise with the international standards. But, once again, certainly, if Australia can show that its standard is defensible on the scientific grounds that are required in order to ensure public health and safety, the Australian standard can stand in the international arena. I believe that Australia should continue to adopt standards which are more stringent than recognised international standards, as it does in many instances. This can have a very positive effect in the international marketplace in creating a very favourable-and justifiably favourable-impression of the safety and health standards of Australian foods.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the article in yesterday's Australian headed `Defiance of IRC ``should be contempt''. Is he aware that, in a discussion paper on the Federal Government's right to strike proposals, the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) said that unions ignoring Australian Industrial Relations Commission orders prohibiting industrial action should be liable for contempt of court? Does the Government support this proposal by the Confederation of Australian Industry? If not, why not?

—I have not read that piece in the Australian. I did see a piece in the Australian Financial Review this morning which suggested that there was some considerable disagreement amongst employer organisations about these issues. The Government has not responded to the CAI position on this matter at present, so I cannot make any further comment than that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does Senator Button himself believe that, when the Industrial Relations Commission makes a decision, unions should be able to defy it and abuse the law, operating outside the Commission?

—I take it that Senator Crane is addressing this question to me as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations or something; I do not know. As he is asking me personally, I believe that the decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission should be followed on the sorts of matters which he has raised-that is, matters which do not have general economic implications-by the parties to disputes which have come before the Commission.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. In the light of recent concern about child-care, can the Minister say what progress has been made with the Government's strategy to increase the provision of child-care places? Can he outline the support offered to community groups which run these services? What measures are in place to assist working parents to afford child-care places?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government has fulfilled its commitment to provide for a huge expansion in relation to child-care places in Australia.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I suggest that, as the Minister proposes to read his answer from a circular passed to him by the questioner, Senator Crowley, you should rule any answer as such out of order and an insult to the Senate.
—Order! There is no point of order. However, I must say to the Minister that that was rather blatant.

—Mr President, I apologise to the Senate for not having the figures before me. The fact is that this is a matter which has been of concern to many honourable senators. I had shown Senator Crowley a sheet giving these statistics and she has now returned that sheet to me-it is as simple as that. I resent the inference that I am trying to mislead the Senate in any way.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the Government will have increased the numbers of funded community based non-profit child-care places from 46,000 in 1983 to around 130,200 at the end of June. They were the figures that I was looking for and I believe they are a matter of great pride which we can justifiably refer to in the context of Senator Crowley's question. In order to make sure that efficiency and quality are the norm in relation to Commonwealth funded children's services, there have been grants of over $5m to various organisations to ensure the support of those organisations-particularly to support the financial and management training needs of the management committees of child-care services.

In relation to affordability, it is quite clear that families with gross weekly incomes of $399 or less, for example, may pay as little as $15 per week for full time care for one child and only $17 for two or more children. They were the precise figures I was looking for in order to demonstrate that a significant subsidy is now available to parents in the community, especially to those with more than one child in care, to enable them to participate in the work force. Approximately 125,000 families benefit from this assistance.

I was simply trying to get some precise figures to make the point that this Government has offered to community groups and, indeed, to the general community, the provision of child-care places in a way which certainly fulfils its commitment in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that you request the Minister to table the document from which he has just read.
—I am very happy to, Mr President.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In looking at the schedule of special purpose flights for July to December 1990, my attention was drawn particularly to some flights which took place in October last year. They were duplicate flights-that is, two on each occasion-for Mr Mandela, who is described as the Deputy President of the African National Congress (ANC), and his party. I draw honourable senators' attention to the fact that these flights included a flight by two aeroplanes from Canberra to Darwin to Canberra on 22 October; a flight on 24 October from Canberra to Sydney by two aeroplanes; a flight on 25 October from Canberra to Sydney to Melbourne to Canberra by two aeroplanes; and a flight on 26 October, from Canberra to Melbourne to Sydney to Canberra, again, by two aeroplanes.

We are talking about aircraft which cost the Royal Australian Air Force at least $1,500 per hour to operate. According to the report, these flights were authorised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). One questions the use of these flights when one recognises that this was not in fact a head of state who was being so honoured; it was the deputy head of a political party in a country with which we have maintained merely an arms-length arrangement for many years.

We have a policy of only selectively allowing people from South Africa to come to this country and those we do allow in obviously are treated like royalty. One questions the justification for the Prime Minister's authorisation of those flights. In the short time that I have had to examine this schedule, it would seem that, at a very minimum, those flights have cost the Australian taxpayer $50,000.

That may seem to be just chickenfeed to the Government because we have been looking at millions of dollars being handed to the ANC over the last few years. The Opposition is particularly concerned-as it has demonstrated in Question Time today and again yesterday-about the expenditure of taxpayers' money in this carefree and careless fashion. The answers of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to us today clearly have not satisfied the Opposition in terms of the accountability, the manner in which the decisions were taken and the supervision or otherwise of the expenditure.

This Minister-he is an emotional, ill-disciplined Minister-went to that country and undid any good his visit might have achieved had he been of a different personality. He came back here and tried to convince us that he has suddenly seen the desperation of the situation in South Africa. Some of us on this side have visited that country and know full well the degradation in which many Africans live. We condemn that. We do not see any justification for the conditions under which one part of that sad country lives.

However, the Minister might do well to visit other African countries to see that South Africa is not alone in the dreadful conditions under which black Africans live. He has a very selective emotion or reaction. If he has taxpayers' money to be spreading around Africa, perhaps he should look in a very much more careful way at how it is spent. There are other countries which need it just as desperately as the black Africans in South Africa.

The Opposition is very concerned at the manner in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of a country in deep recession has gone to South Africa and handed around money which has not been decided upon by the Cabinet. There has clearly been a deal done between the Minister and the Prime Minister. Once again the Prime Minister has authorised expenditure of Australian taxpayers' dollars for no just and proper reason. Yet the Minister went there selectively handing out money and has exacerbated the political situation in that country. The political situation in South Africa has caused horrors and countless numbers of deaths of black Africans, one against the other. By their very actions-the handing over of $17m in the last couple of years-the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister of this country are meddling in the internal affairs of another country in a way which could never be countenanced in our own country. It is appalling that they could find any justification whatsoever for the selective use of Australian money in the internal affairs of another country. Many of my colleagues have drawn attention to this matter over recent days, and I add my voice to theirs. These aircraft flights are yet another example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to refer to the schedule of special purpose flights for the period July to December 1990. In this six-month period there is some very interesting reading, particularly the special trip of Mr Mandela to which Senator Newman has just referred. However, I would like to draw attention to the use of the flights by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications, the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Snowdon, as opposed to flights for ministerial purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early part of July and September of last year on at least four occasions Mr Snowdon used the jet for transport purposes, which attracted some national significance. On 13 July last year the aircraft was required to fly from Canberra to Townsville to Tennant Creek, and then back to Richmond. This enabled Mr Snowdon to attend as an official of a dog show in Tennant Creek. We ascertained that the cost of the flight at that time was very considerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring! Boring!

—It may be boring, but it is taxpayers' money and that is important. Senator Ray acknowledged at the time that in the four-month period over $100,000 of taxpayers' funds were expended on four flights and on only one occasion was Mr Snowdon accompanied. It is blatant arrogance and hypocrisy for anyone to argue that taxpayers' money should be used in this area, where a Parliamentary Secretary can run around with an open chequebook and obviously an open travel warrant. It highlights a number of the guidelines that need to be reviewed, particularly the use of VIP aircraft. As I said, Mr Snowdon used the jet for transport on at least four occasions, but in the same period I note that he also used VIP flights on at least five other occasions when he was accompanied by other Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently in this Parliament we have also seen tabled the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services, which showed that for the period of the full year of 1990-91 Mr Snowdon spent $40,491 on phone calls from his electorate office and that in the nine months subsequent to that, to March 1991, he spent a further $43,762. The overtime in his office for the same period for the full year was $54,021, and for the subsequent nine months into this year it was $47,903.

The extravagance of this type of expenditure on phone calls and overtime of the order of $500 per working day in an electorate office-particularly during the period of a Federal election campaign in early 1990, and in a Northern Territory election campaign in September-October 1990, when the Northern Territory President of the Australian Labor Party was on the personal staff of Mr Snowdon in the Darwin office- highlights the arrogance, extravagance and hypocrisy to which this Government is prepared to resort to secure its own election.

If the Government is going to talk about disclosure with regard to Federal election campaigns, the disclosure of members, Ministers and senators must also be out in the open. We cannot allow this type of hypocrisy to continue. The matter was highlighted, particularly with regard to the special purpose flights, in the editorial of the Australian at the same time. It said:
If the rules covering the expenditure of public funds by MPs are not tight enough to keep members of Parliament on a short lead, they should be redrafted.

As a backbencher, Mr Snowdon is not entitled to use a VIP jet. But he is also the Secretary of Transport and Communications in the super-ministry controlled by the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley. In that second role he is entitled to use a VIP jet while on official business.
But the Secretary of the Tennant Creek Show Society has said Mr Snowdon was invited to the show in his capacity as a Territory dignitary and not as a ministerial secretary.
It seems MPs need a more effective watchdog, capable of sinking its fangs into their self-importance.
Certainly, attending dog shows at taxpayers' expense ought not to be a prerogative available to any Federal member of parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to draw attention to the Schedule of Special Purpose Flights. I particularly draw the attention of the Senate to the flights of Mr Keating, the former Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister. He has made an average of one return flight a week out of Canberra using the VIP service. I was under the impression that there was a fairly frequent airline service out of Canberra; obviously, that is inappropriate for a backbencher of Mr Keating's status.

SPEECH.PARA: I note also that on six of those occasions Mr Keating decided that he would like to have leading members of the Canberra press gallery as his accompanying passengers. I have no complaint about Ministers regarding it as useful or sensible to offer opportunities for the press gallery to travel with them. As I understand, there is recompense from the proprietors of those media organisations to the Government for the cost of those seats. However, it does seem curious to note that Mr Keating seems to use this facility more than his predecessor.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to have worked, doesn't it?

—As the interjection from Senator Crichton-Browne says, it does seem to have worked. Maybe the reason for the extraordinarily strong support from the media for Mr Keating's recent unsuccessful bid to dethrone Mr Hawke has emerged from the close and personal relationships no doubt built up on these numerous flights between Canberra and other capital cities that Mr Keating has provided for members of the press gallery.

SPEECH.PARA: One would expect that after the Budget there may be a couple of occasions on which the Gallery may find a great deal of merit in travelling interstate with the Treasurer in order to judge the response to the speeches that the former Treasurer gave-particularly last year-indicating that there would not be a recession and that there would be a soft landing. No doubt there was a requirement for the Treasurer to spread that kind of sweetness and light-which turned out to be totally false, of course-to members of the Press Gallery, and this gave him adequate opportunity for doing so.

The fact is that a large number of these trips do not appear to have any relationship with Budget time. For example, on 4 October Mr Keating and various members of the Press Gallery flew to Sydney and back.

TALK.START.PARA: —To watch the footie?

—I do not know why it was vitally necessary for that visit to take place. No doubt Mr Keating will have an explanation. On 14 July, which was not Budget time, he flew Canberra-Melbourne-Canberra. As I pointed out, these are flights at times at which there is the provision of normal commercial services. On 27 July Mr Keating, along with various members of the Press Gallery, flew Canberra-Melbourne-Canberra. We see from this a clear pattern of Mr Keating regarding the VIP flights as his normal method of transport rather than the method of transport that should be used when commercial flights are not available.
—Senator, you can't say that without comparing it with his commercial flights, can you?

—As Senator Button says, I cannot say it without comparing it with his commercial flights, and we look forward to seeing the list of his commercial flights. Unless Mr Keating was taking more than a once-a-week return flight, on average, it would take a lot of travelling by him out of what artificially became his home base of Canberra to make up this number. Might I say that, now that Mr Keating no longer has access to these special purpose flights, it will be interesting to see whether he moves his home base back to Sydney so that his future travel will no longer be covered by the fiddle that was done by this Government to allow him to get living-away-from-home expenses while living at home in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 30 of 1990-91 entitled, Department of Social Security-Age Pension Sub-program-Income and Assets Testing -Real Estate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Auditor-General's Report No. 30 of 1990-91 entitled, Department of Social Security-Age Pension Sub-program-Income and Assets Testing-Real Estate, has only been available to us in our offices for an hour or two, but I could not resist the opportunity to speak on it. It is an indictment, yet again, of the running of the Department of Social Security (DSS), and especially of Senator Richardson's claims that there is no fat left in the system. This Auditor-General's report illustrates, yet again-as did the Auditor-General's report on the Telecom concessions-that, in fact, there is fat in the system.

The report's summary of findings indicates that the total value of pensioner real estate, excluding the principal home, exceeds $3.9 billion, of which 49 per cent by number and 39 per cent by value was valued by the pensioner and accepted by Social Security. The Australian Valuation Office values real estate if the pensioner's total assets are within $20,000 of or exceed the assets test threshold, or if the Department of Social Security believes the pensioner's own estimate to be significantly understated. Valuation reviews occur only if the total assets come within $20,000 of the assets threshold or when an annual review of the Australian Valuation Office's original valuation is undertaken. In 1990, a joint DSS audit office study found that 85 per cent of pensioner valued real estate was understated. The average undervaluation was $61,224. We are not talking about small amounts of money. Senator Button looked across the chamber: 85 per cent of pensioner valued real estate was understated by, on average, $61,224.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I was admiring your new jacket. That is the average?
—We like the cut of your jib, too!
—Thank you very much. I think, given how late we were last night, one needs colours to camouflage the face.
—No, not in your case; in mine.

—You said that. The Australian National Audit Office estimates that, by reviewing those pensioners whose assets were valued within $40,000 of the assets test threshold, potential net annual savings of $6.8m would be achieved. This is in a section where Senator Richardson tells us there is no fat. I am sure Senator Walsh will be interested in these figures; I wish he was there on the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC) to do something about it. The Audit Office found that, on average, it takes between 90 and 120 days to get an Australian Valuation Office valuation undertaken. The report indicated that there was considerable scope for improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no cross-matching of property value and property rental disclosures to DSS. The Audit Office's review found that many rental disclosures did not reflect the value of these properties. The Audit Office found that many properties identified by the evaluation by DSS were not evaluated by the Australian Valuation Office due to the pressures within DSS offices. Given the Government's policies and given our level of unemployment, I presume those pressures will increase even more. It does not give me much hope that that problem will be alleviated.

The Auditor-General recommended that the DSS should adopt more efficient real estate valuation review procedures, including a more effective valuation review algorithm that would take into account significant undervaluation of real estate by pensioners. The Auditor-General also recommended that DSS should make a special effort to review the large number of pensioner cases with non-recorded real estate values; that the Department should amend procedures to require staff to seek further information from pensioners disclosing real estate values of less than $10,000; that the DSS should adopt performance standards for obtaining Australian Valuation Office valuations, monitor and follow up outstanding valuations; and that, in consultation with the Australian Valuation Office, the DSS should conduct a pilot study to assess the adequacy of rental disclosures relative to property values.

In responding, the Department of Social Security claimed that it is in the process of reviewing the assets test valuation process with a view to providing advice to the Government in the near future. The DSS claims that it is the Government's role to amend the assets tests algorithm. The Department of Social Security claims that assessing the adequacy of rental disclosures relative to property values is not relevant to the current provisions of the Social Security Act. It contends that its responsibilities under the Act extend no further than getting rental income information from its clients. The Department also advised that it is in the process of introducing electronic data transfer of valuation requests and results with the Australian Valuation Office.

It seems to me that that is an area where reform could take place. The Department says that it is not its responsibility, but the Government ought to be looking into the issues-and they are very serious issues-that the Auditor-General has related here. I would not want to see pensioners deprived of any benefits to which they are rightly due. If a large number of pensioners are receiving benefits at the expense of others, that should be considered very carefully as well as the fact that taxpayers' money is going into an area where the Government could tighten up.

If it were possible, I would derive great satisfaction by clipping this audit report to the submission from the Minister for Social Security to the Expenditure Review Committee. I think it would be quite good reading for the ERC. In the same vein as DSS's highly inefficient telephone rental concessional scheme, which I mentioned earlier, this is yet another example of the excess fat that still needs to be cut from Senator Richardson's portfolio. Despite our urgings, the Minister has not had the courage to recognise the existence of these inefficiencies. Thankfully, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has had the commonsense to reject Senator Richardson's fairly pathetic pleas that there is no fat left in his portfolio and that he should be exempted from expenditure cuts. I think this report demonstrates quite clearly that some measures can still be taken in this Department. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 31 of 1990-91-Department of Community Services and Health-Nursing Homes Payment System.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have not had time to go through the Auditor-General's report on the Department of Community Services and Health entitled Nursing Homes Payment System thoroughly. It is quite a technical report. My attention has been drawn to page 8 of the report where security and access is referred to. In December last year, we had presented in this place a resident rights' agreement, which was an appallingly drafted document, with some tens of amendments from this side of the chamber, amendments from the Australian Democrats and 40 or 50 amendments from the Government before it even saw the light of day, before it even arrived in the Senate. We addressed those issues. We were told that there was a great deal of urgency about addressing the rights of residents in nursing homes-and we all agreed with that.

We have seen this matter languishing, and we have yet to see its implementation. Although Minister Staples was talking about residents' rights, about putting enormous pressures on the proprietors of nursing homes, we have seen that he does not have his own house in order. We have seen the rights of residents infringed from the point of view of the Department of Community Services and Health. It is all very well to throw stones, but one should not live in a glasshouse if one does it. Minister Staples' Department has been guilty of not respecting the rights of individuals. I do not care how old or how frail a citizen is, his or her rights are as important as those of every other citizen.

The Auditor-General's report refers to the Australian National Audit Office observing a number of deficiencies related to the security aspects of computer operations of the nursing homes payment system (NHPS). These included: lack of restrictions on user access to parts of the database and specific functions of the NHPS which contains information on all residents in all nursing homes in all States. Every resident of every nursing home in every State of Australia is on this computer, and we are told there is a lack of restriction on users. In addition, procedures to ensure that users who leave the Department or cease to work in the nursing homes area have access rights removed were not being observed and required some modification; and procedures for changing and verifying new pass words required some enhancement to improve security.

I repeat that we ought to get our own house in order before we cast aspersions on others. It would have paid the Minister to have looked very carefully at this when he was advocating so strongly-and we all supported them-the rights of nursing home residents in their residential accommodation. Their rights should also be preserved in terms of the information that is kept on them by government departments. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
