DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991INCOME TAX (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuation of my earlier remarks in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I signal that there are likely to be further changes to allow tax deductibility of expenses incurred in the rehabilitation of exploration, mining and quarrying operations. I certainly hope that this is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I point out that the present Bill insists that the site be restored to the condition it was in before mining commenced. The Bill does not allow, for example, for an improvement to occur to the site, and I believe that this point does need addressing. A quarry should not necessarily be refilled. For example, it would be more environmentally viable as a landscaped, man-made lake. The Bill as it stands unfortunately does not allow this. I ask Senator Button, through his Australian Taxation Office responsibilities, to address this issue.

It is a pity that it is only the mining industry that has received this incentive to protect the environment. Many other industries have occasion to abuse the environment, yet these industries will not be treated in the same manner. Thus, in the introduction of these tax incentives to the mining and quarrying industries we have introduced a major anomaly to the taxation laws or, in common parlance, we no longer have a level playing field.

In addition, we should note that Australia's record in providing tax incentives to promote sensible behaviour towards the environment is not good and we are at a competitive disadvantage when compared to the rest of the world. Therefore, I again urge Senator Button, through his tax responsibilities in this chamber, to examine this matter a little more closely.

Further, I point out to the Government that the legislation as presently drafted does not adequately cover the situation of offshore platform decommissioning activities and, as a consequence, does not truly reflect the announcements made in the Budget statements of August 1990. The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association pointed out that it also has concerns with the definition of `site' for the purposes of division 10ab deductions; the priority for deductions under division 10ab; the eligibility of the taxpayer for division 10ab deductions; and restrictions on section 51 deductibility. Unfortunately, time does not allow me to detail those concerns. However, during the committee stage I hope that there will be some more time to explore these matters at length.

There is one final section of the Bill about which I have some concerns. Section 23af has been altered to recognise some of the problems highlighted by the industries concerned, particularly volunteers abroad, and I welcome the changes made. I acknowledge that the legislation originally gave tax exemption to approved overseas projects so that firms could be more competitive for projects in markets where tax was not paid by local firms.

The Government's legislation extends a full exemption from projects of 12 months or longer to projects of 91 days or longer. I understand that the industry welcomes this extension, but it should be pointed out that most projects now typically require very short inputs from consultants because of the world recession. Hence, on projects under 91 days there is still no tax relief because firms and individuals cannot take advantage of section 23af to extend our key competitors' benefit from similar schemes in their countries.

Furthermore, I have been informed that, with regard to section 23ag and the extensions of exemption that apply here, it has become apparent that at least one government agency proposes effectively to remove the tax component from the billing rate paid. In other words, the agency proposed to act as a de facto tax office and deny consulting firms and their individual employees the benefits that would otherwise accrue from this legislation. Here we have a classic case of one department not talking to the other, of one department taking advantage of a tax recognition that is appropriately given by this Government. An example of this is the exemption from tax in both countries. The Tax Office knows that this is going on, but it is unable or unwilling to do anything about it. I again ask the Minister to address this issue.

It is of vital concern that we have a viable and vibrant consulting industry working in the growing Pacific Basin area, where Australia's influence can be acknowledged. I believe that the tax laws of this country need to change to recognise our responsible involvement in areas outside this country.

Finally, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 also extends access to tax information provided by the Australian Taxation Office. I remind the Government that care needs to be exercised when widening the scope for access to this type of information by Federal and State bodies. The coalition is not entirely satisfied that due caution has been exercised in deciding on this measure because both the second reading speech of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) and the explanatory memorandum to this Bill are quite silent in this regard.

Allied with this Bill is the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991, which provides legislative authority for the entry into force of a comprehensive double taxation agreement between Australia and the Republic of Hungary and Australia and the Republic of Kiribati. Australia already has comprehensive double taxation agreements with 27 other countries. The addition of the republics of Hungary and Kiribati will take the number to 29.

As the name suggests, double taxation agreements are designed to avoid double taxation of income tax flowing between Australia and the respective treaty partners to prevent fiscal evasion of the tax covered by the agreements. Under the terms of the agreement, income from real property may be taxed in full by the country in which the property is situated. Business profits are be taxed only in the country of residence of the recipient country unless they are derived by a resident of one country through a branch or permanent establishment in the other country. Profits from the international operations of ships and aircraft are generally taxed only on the country of residence of the operator. Dividends, interest and royalties may be taxed in the country of source, but there are generally limits to tax that the source country may charge on such income flowing to residents of the other country.

I note that one of the three major recommendations of a House of Representatives committee examining the question of withholding taxes was to refer the withholding tax system and our international tax treaties to the Industry Commission for a comprehensive review. I await the outcome of that review before commenting further. Australia's agreement with Kiribati provides for tax-sparing credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax foregone by Kiribati under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. This means that, where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from one of the nominated development incentives and is subject to Australian tax, a tax credit is to be allowed by Australia as if the Kiribati foregone tax had been paid. Therefore, in conclusion, the coalition welcomes these Bills, particularly the changes that the Government has proposed and has undertaken to execute. At the same time we urge the Government to examine closely the other matters we have raised during this important debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 cognately with the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1991. The latter Bill deals with the comprehensive double tax agreements which have been signed with the Republic of Hungary and the Republic of Kiribati. The Australian Democrats welcome these double tax agreements and will support the Bill without amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) are varied and numerous. It is the first omnibus income tax Bill of the year. It contains measures to extend the income tax to the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands; further modifications to the foreign income tax rules, including the treatment of foreign employment income; further adjustments to the thin capitalisation rules; environmental expenditure on land degradation and mine site rehabilitation; the tax file number requirements for investments; the taxation implications of securities lending arrangements; the simplification of social security legislation; company and superannuation fund self-assessment; the provision of secret information to various crime detection bodies; and a minor amendment to the gift provisions, changing retrospectively the reference to the Royal College of Nursing Australia and reflecting that body's change of name. Following the recent and welcome transitional arrangements applying to small business for the payment of income tax instalments, there are also some technical amendments relating to the payment by instalment of tax by companies and superannuation funds with income exceeding $20,000.

I turn to the tax deductibility provisions for expenditure on measures to combat land degradation. The Government announced in last year's Budget that the existing tax concessions dealing with land degradation will be improved as from that time, namely, 21 August 1990. The old provision in section 75d had two problems: it applied only to primary producers, hence not covering all rural land, and it applied only to fencing which was directed to preventing further deterioration of land which had already suffered some degradation. The proposed new provision will extend the tax deduction to any taxpayer earning an income from rural land, excluding from mining or quarrying operations, and will thereby include enterprises such as sawmills, riding schools, abattoirs and so on. Furthermore, preventative fencing will be deductible after 21 August 1990 if it is erected pursuant to an approved land management plan. An approved plan is one prepared by an officer of a land conservation agency or by an approved farm consultant. The Government has made some recent adjustments to this legislation following negotiations, and my colleague Senator Robert Bell will deal with this particular issue.

I now turn to certain mine site rehabilitation expenses which will also qualify for tax deductibility where they are incurred on or after 1 July 1991. Most of the expenditure is capital in nature and hence is not deductible under the general deduction provisions. The second difficulty with the current legislation is that, where expenditure is not related to producing assessable income, it is consequently not deductible under the general deduction provisions. The third difficulty is the special concessional deduction provision, which does apply to capital expenditure but is limited to expenses connected with the process of extracting minerals. Thus post-mining rehabilitation expenses do not qualify at this stage. Basically the Bill proposes to remedy the existing situation by treating rehabilitation as an integral part of the mining process. This is, of course, a correct assumption, because in many cases the miner must agree to undertake such rehabilitation to obtain the mining right in the first place.

An outright deduction will be allowed on rehabilitation-related activities incurred after 1 July 1991. The deduction will apply only to expenditure to return the site to the pre-mining condition, not to all and any improvements. Generally this limitation is reasonable. However, a total exclusion may be inappropriate in some situations. An example would be a situation where a quarry has been excavated but cannot be returned to its previous state but rather turned into a lake. Where that facility is established with related amenities, such work and such expenditure should be allowable. We will not be moving any amendments to vary the Bill at this stage, as we understand that the Minister may be making an announcement during this debate about the Government's intention to further review this particular matter, but we feel that this should be addressed in the near future.

The new provisions will not alter the deductibility provisions which currently operate, and the concession is limited to rehabilitating the mine site only. Thus the costs of rehabilitating an area which is connected with the mining operation but is not on site will not qualify. We have some concern that this limitation will provide an incentive for mining companies not to repair areas damaged by mining activities which are not on-site. Should any serious examples come to light, we intend to take some action later in the year on this matter.

I now turn to the taxation of pensions, benefits and allowances paid under social security and veterans legislation, which is now being totally rewritten to simplify the legislation and to align the tax legislation to the new format of the benefit-providing legislation. This is, of course, extremely welcome. No substantive changes are being made to the taxation of any of the pensions and benefits. However, the new provisions run to more than 20 pages of legislation, even though the provision being replaced is only a couple of pages in length. This is an interesting comment when the objective is to simplify and clarify legislation.

I turn to the extension of the tax regime to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Currently residents of these islands are subject to Australian income tax only on income derived from sources in mainland Australia or Christmas Island. The Cocos Malay people have voted to integrate fully with Australia, and this involves assuming responsibility under our taxation system and obtaining rights under the social security and Medicare systems. From 1 July 1991 all income and capital gains will be subject to tax. However, to phase in the impact of entry to the tax system, a rebate will apply to individuals which will ensure that previously exempt income will be subject to only 50 per cent of the normal tax burden for the 1991-92 year.

Fringe benefits will also be brought into the tax system and a 50 per cent exemption will apply for the 1991-92 year to ease the transition. The Medicare levy will apply at the full rate from 1 July 1991. The precedent for a Territory entering the taxation system in this manner is Christmas Island. The individuals there were subject to a four-year phasing-in, whereas companies were immediately liable to full company taxation. The Democrats welcome this gradual phasing-in of tax liabilities, which seems a constructive way to go about the task. We note that there is still no wholesale sales tax on either Christmas or the Cocos Islands but apparently that is a matter which is currently under review.

I now turn to the security lending arrangements which occur when a person lends securities to another person-the borrower-under an agreement which requires the borrower to return either the borrowed security or identical securities. In the absence of special provisions, such a transaction would trigger the capital gains tax provisions. But the Bill and previous provisions ensure that this is not the case.

The Bill proposes to broaden the current exemption in a number of respects: firstly, to increase the eligible borrowing period from less than three months to less than 12 months; secondly, to extend the coverage from securities issued only by listed companies to those issued by all public companies; thirdly, the lender will be entitled to the indexation benefits which accrue on the securities which are the subject of the arrangement, and that seems only fair; and, fourthly, the concession will now be available where distributions, either monetary or scrip, are paid during the period of the loan-in other words, where there is only a part-lending arrangement.

Why was it necessary to extend the lending period from three months to 12 months? I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, to explain during the committee stage, or earlier, why the Government is proposing to lengthen this borrowing period in this way. On the face of it, this is a very long period to temporarily lend securities, and I would be interested in the reasons.

I now turn to the provision to extend the existing range of bodies to which the Commissioner of Taxation may disclose otherwise secret information. The disclosure is only allowed where the Commissioner is satisfied that the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been or is being committed, or to the making of a proceeds of crime order. The three additional bodies in this legislation are: the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and the New South Wales Crimes Commission.

Existing agencies which can receive information include all police forces, the National Crime Authority, the Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions. While being extremely conscious of the civil liberties of Australian citizens and the need for privacy, I believe that in these particular circumstances-provided the safeguards remain in place-the extension to provide information to these bodies is fully justified.

I turn now to the tax file number system which was introduced to limit the amount of tax evasion which occurs. The system has been extended to the social security system and to other income support systems. The Bill makes a number of provisions. The main alteration will ensure that the correct tax file number is quoted where investments are made via one or more interposed entities, such as through trust arrangements. We have no problem with the Government's proposals in this matter.

The current system of multiple quotation of tax file numbers where investments are made by interposed entities, such as solicitors, gives rise to double counting of income and consequent assessing errors. The avoidance of these errors is a sound objective and the Government's proposed system of investment body remitter numbers appears to be a workable system to overcome these problems.

The explanatory memorandum detailing these provisions is, however, deficient in a number of respects. We support the laudable inclusion of flow charts to assist in the understanding of legislation. However, all three diagrams explaining these amendments contain errors. On page 129 the interposed entity is shown as having to quote a tax file number to the investor instead of the reverse. The diagrams on pages 131 and 135 also contain errors concerning which bodies must quote tax file numbers or investment body remitter numbers.

Given their potential legal status, these documents must be absolutely accurate and these mistakes are unfortunate. Having said that, I acknowledge that the Government is trying to make explanatory memoranda more accessible to the lay person as part of the simplification of the legislation process. The new format, by not concentrating on clause by clause analysis, is definitely easier for the non-expert to follow.

The Bill also proposes to delete the tax file number requirements from deferred interest investments. The second reading speech states that it is proposed that new rules will be introduced in the Budget Session to deal with these deferred interest securities, and these are certainly required.

I now turn to some matters related to the withholding tax. The recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-the Martin committee- entitled Follow the Yellow Brick Road dealt with another problem concerning tax file numbers and the withholding tax. Recommendation 8 of the report suggests that the tax file number system be modified to incorporate non-resident verification procedures, which should require persons depositing funds in Australian financial institutions to provide proof that they are non-residents before they are eligible to have tax deducted at the interest withholding tax rate of 10 per cent. If adequate proof is not provided, tax should be withheld at the top marginal rate.

The problem identified is where a genuine non-resident establishes an account in a financial institution but deposits are made and controlled by residents, or where the non-resident is operating as a secret trustee for a resident. The Government must act to implement this and other anti-avoidance recommendations made by the Committee. As I have indicated by press release, the Government will have the full support of the Australian Democrats in these matters. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment during the committee stage on one of the main provisions recommended by the Martin committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will need some exemptions in the trust domain where there are beneficiaries as a result of debt.

—I will deal with that later. The Bill also proposes to amend the thin capitalisation provisions. These provisions exist to limit the possibility of shifting Australian source income overseas by converting the income into interest by over-gearing the foreign controlled business. Excess interest is precluded from tax deductibility, thereby preserving the Australian company tax base.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed to amend retrospectively the provisions from 1 July 1987 by excluding certain types of debt from the definition of foreign debt. The debt instruments to be excluded are debentures which benefit from the section 128f withholding tax exemption where the debentures are purchased by a foreign controller for the purpose of overseas distribution. They may only be retained for 30 days.

As the Senate is aware, the Australian Democrats do not support the section 128f exemption as we consider it to be an incentive for Australian businesses to borrow offshore. Consequently, we are critical of this decision which further promotes offshore borrowing by Australian companies.

I now turn to the treatment of foreign employment income and fringe benefits, which is also altered under this Bill. Under the current law, an Australian resident working overseas on certain approved projects, either as an employee or as a contractor, may be entitled to a full exemption from Australian tax where the foreign service is 12 months old or longer, or a partial exemption for periods between three months and 12 months.

Recognition of shortcomings led to the Government's announcement last year of proposed reform of these provisions in the context of income tax simplification. The anomaly, which meant that the meagre allowance paid to missionaries and aid workers could be liable to Australian taxation, was brought to the attention of the Senate some time ago, and I commend the Government for finally addressing the problem.

The amendments propose to relax retrospectively-that is, from 1 July 1990-the exemption criteria in two respects. They will reduce from 12 months to three months the length of time foreign service must be performed to qualify for an exemption and extend the exemption to foreign earnings which are currently exempt in the country of source except in specified circumstances. This will assist foreign aid workers and missionaries, but will not allow double taxation treaties to be abused by people performing duties in foreign jurisdictions and avoiding tax when in a position to do so.

However, I have received a representation to the effect that at least one government agency is proposing to negate, at least partially, the effect of this exemption on Australian residents' income by reducing the payments made to professionals consulting on foreign aid projects-that is, the tax exemption for the consulting engineer, which will be clawed back by lower contract payments. If so, this may tend to discourage Australian firms from competing for these contracts, which is presumably not the Government's aim, and may require some further attention.

The foreign source income provisions are also amended by the Bill in a number of respects. Firstly, the Government has decided to weaken further the accruals regime by exempting from the tax any dividends paid out of profits which have been subject to an accruals tax by another listed country. The move is consistent with the earlier decision to take into account whether or not foreign income of a controlled foreign entity has been subject to a foreign accruals tax regime.

The Australian Democrats believe that this unilateral concession granted by the Australian Government should have been considered on a case by case approach, possibly through renegotiation of appropriate double taxation agreements. The issue should be one of tax sharing between the Australian Government and foreign governments concerned-this is, quite often, the United States and the United Kingdom-and not a total abdication of Australia's rights, as has occurred in this case.

Secondly, the Government is proposing to remove the interest charge on distributions which qualify for concessional tax treatment, pursuant to the rebate available under section 102aan. The interest charge is a measure to deny the taxpayer any advantage which would arise from a delayed trust distribution. Section 102aan is a concessional provision which limits tax payable to 10 per cent in the case of distributions made to wind up non-resident trusts. In this case the Government has decided that, in order to maximise the winding-up of non-resident trusts, it is worth while to grant an exemption from the interest charge. It is understandable that the Government wishes to end the use of foreign trusts by Australian residents.

The Australian Democrats agree with this aim. However the granting of a concessional rate of tax of only 10 per cent is surely enough of an incentive to attract these supposedly legitimate investments back into the Australian tax net. Why should we also remove the interest charge? The Government claims that the interest charge was never meant to apply to these concessional arrangements and only arises because of the delay in the implementation of the accrual system. Perhaps we should look around for other incentives, such as the Order of Australia.

I return to the provisions of the Bill. Further amendments are made to tax benefits provided by a controlled foreign company (CFC) to a shareholder through a third party. They are basically of an anti-avoidance nature and are supported. Similarly, the proposal to require record-keeping in circumstances where sections 457 or 459a apply is reasonable and is not opposed.

There are also two different amendments affecting the bad debt provisions. The first involves a technical problem in the structure of section 63d (1), which refers to the amount calculated pursuant to a formula when the formula only provides a proportion. The reference is being made compatible by the substitution of the word `proportion' for `amount'. The second amendment in this area concerns bad debts incurred by a CFC engaged in the business of moneylending. Where the bad debts are attributable to business carried on through listed country branches, a deduction will not be allowed where the debt is written off and an apportionment procedure will be allowed.

I turn to another matter which I believe the Government should seriously consider rectifying. If necessary, I believe that it could also be dealt with by the Select Committee on Superannuation, which has just been established. I have had representations from a Mr Williams in Queensland detailing the problem he is experiencing with superannuation funds that are not prepared to assist him in receiving the tax exemption on deposits which consist of interest-bearing deposits to the extent of 90 per cent. This provision was obtained by the Democrats as an exemption from the superannuation tax of 15 per cent on amounts deposited as at 25 May 1988 in those funds where income consists of at least 90 per cent interest. The exemption is granted by section 290a of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The rationale was that the imputation system cannot benefit these funds, and hence they should be exempted from income tax. Mr Williams has been involved in a long and largely unsuccessful battle with one of his superannuation funds, which to this day has refused to claim this particular exemption, which the fund is obliged to pass on to the depositor under the terms of the legislation.

Apparently, one of these funds, the Five Arrows approved deposit fund, which is administered by Rothschild Australia, has agreed to examine the matter and to take some action to rectify the situation. However, the other fund, the Colonial Mutual approved deposit fund, has so far refused to carry out what I believe is its obligation on behalf of depositors. If funds are negligent in this manner, I believe that the Government should take some action to provide relief.

Finally, I turn to a matter on which I will be moving a second reading amendment-that is, tax exemption for progress associations. Attention has been drawn to this matter by the Valentine Progress Association, which is providing community facilities at the expense of members of its community. The Association's Treasurer, Mr Lyn Godfrey, has provided financial statements substantiating that the work done by the Progress Association benefits the community activities of a large number of organisations and individuals of that community.

I believe that it is a worthwhile network in our community. This Association happens to be in New South Wales and is near Newcastle. I think the Government should seriously look at the definition applied to progress associations and, to the extent that they are providing valuable community services, it should look at tax exemption. In respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the decision of the Commissioner of Taxation to not extend income tax exemption to progress associations will have a severe effect on many rural local communities where progress associations provide low-cost community facilities, and calls on the Government to legislate to exempt such associations from income tax''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The omnibus Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is composed mostly of proposed amendments that were contemplated by the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, as long ago as August last year. The Bill contains a very wide range of amendments to taxation laws. The particular interest to me involves the extension of normal mainland taxation arrangements to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. These provisions implement the memorandum of understanding signed between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the island community on 7 March 1991 and is part of the process of integrating the Cocos community with mainland Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Late last year, I had occasion to receive representations from a number of people who were concerned about the changes being imposed, particularly on the Malay people, Australian residents who live on Cocos (Keeling) Islands. At that time I received representation, in particular, from an educator and lady with anthropological interests, Ms Pauline Bunce. At the time I made that information freely available to the appropriate portfolio Minister-the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Simmons.

Honourable senators may recall that at the time the implementation of the memorandum of understanding was delayed from signature from December last year until March of this year. I am now well aware that Ms Bunce, who has recently been back to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, still shares the concerns that she made at that particular time about the process of consultation between Australia and the Malay community on the islands. In fact, I will quote in part from a letter that Ms Bunce wrote to the Minister dated 27 April 1991:

It is my personal opinion, based on a long-standing close relationship with these people that there are serious and recurring signs of social disintegration within the community and that grave fears are held for their future.
Further in the same letter in talking about the process and the memorandum Ms Bunce says:

. . . despite the public distribution of Malay and English versions of this document through people's post office boxes, I found widespread ignorance of the document's very existence, let alone the nature of its contents. Apart from your speech given at a social gathering earlier this year, there has been no other public discussion of this document. There has been no open question-and-answer meeting, no house-to-house visiting and only vague responses to questions asked of Council members. There has been no meaningful ``consultation'' with the wider community at all.

The overwhelming majority of the ninety-six Home Island households are non-literate and non-English-speaking. As far as I could ascertain, most have discarded their copies of the Memorandum as ``just another bundle of paper'' in their postbox. They cannot remember ever receiving it-although I have been assured by the Council Secretary that they did.
People are now discovering the ramifications of this agreement one at a time, as and when they happen. People say that so many things are happening ``without warning''.

Most villagers did not know that their leaders had even gone to Canberra to sign this life-changing document. The first that many of them knew was when they saw these men on television ``signing something with Bob Hawke.'' One of the leaders had told some friends that he was going to Canberra to ``sign a contract''. They had interpreted his comment to mean a work-contract. The other told people he was going ``to sign'' . . . without any further details.

I spoke with several Council and Cooperative committee members as well as the Council Secretary, and it is my firmly-held belief that even these people do not fully understand the ramifications of this document in terms of their own families' future circumstances.

That letter raises some very serious issues that must be of continuing concern to this Parliament and particularly to the Government. The Cocos (Keeling) Islands have been tax-free since their acquisition by Australia in 1985. At the time of the Act of Self-Determination in 1984, the Commonwealth indicated it would review their tax-free status and the Cocos Malay community has always accepted this position. Under the changeover to mainland standards, the Cocos Malay will receive full mainland wages, as well as the full range of government services, benefits and grants assistance. Accordingly, the community has agreed that it should pay the same taxes and charges as mainland communities taking account of the remote area rebates, et cetera, as currently allowed on the mainland. Although wages have commenced incrementing towards mainland rates from 1 July 1990, it has been agreed that Commonwealth taxes will not commence phasing in until 1991. This will assist the community to maintain full employment.

The Cocos (Keeling) Islands will remain excise and duty free for the time being, which may also assist tourism development. For residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, this will mean that they will no longer qualify for exemption from tax on income derived in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island or from sources outside Australia. The transitional arrangements for the phasing in of personal income tax will see the tax liability of individuals and certain trustees on income that was previously exempt from tax, reduced by 50 per cent during the 1991-92 income year.

Full tax will first apply to such income from the commencement of the 1992-93 income year. Full rates of company taxation will also apply to previously exempted income and capital gains of Cocos (Keeling) resident companies in the 1991-92 financial year. Capital gains tax rules will now apply to all assets disposed of on or after 1 July 1991 by residents of Cocos (Keeling) Islands. However, in respect of previously exempt assets, only the gain which has accrued on or after 1 July 1991 will be subject to capital gains tax.

A consequential effect of the proposed amendment is that in 1991-92 and in later income years residents of Norfolk Island will be liable to tax on income or capital gains derived from sources in the territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands in the same way as they are presently liable to tax on income gains from sources in mainland Australia. That may not mean a lot to many people but I am sure that it will to tax accountants and to people who have used these facilities in the past.

Fringe benefit taxation rules already apply to benefits provided to employees in the territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands. However, fringe benefits tax is not payable where the employee's salary or wage is exempt from taxation. Accordingly, under the existing law, few fringe benefits paid to employees in the territory are subject to fringe benefit taxation because the remuneration received by employees is usually exempt from tax.

To be consistent with the proposed introduction of new arrangements for taxation of income derived by genuine residents of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, the Bill proposes measures which will phase in the imposition of fringe benefit provided from 1 July 1991 to employees in the territory. The introduction of fringe benefit taxation will be phased in over a period which will largely mirror the changes for personal income tax. Considering the fact that the normal fringe benefits year runs from 1 April to 31 March, the Bill proposes that the fringe benefits tax be phased in over the period 1 July 1991 to 31 March 1992, with full fringe benefits to apply from 1 April 1992 onwards.

The revenue, according to the Minister, Senator Button, is estimated at $260,000 in 1991-92 and $750,000 in 1992-93. It must be remembered that this will be offset by the introduction of the full range of assistance and welfare measures available on the mainland. The move is welcomed by the Opposition and we will not be opposing these provisions. However, I would also draw to the Senate's attention an important report tabled recently in the House of Representatives entitled Islands in the Sun which addresses many of the issues of legal regimes in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean and also Norfolk Island in the Pacific Ocean.

In looking at the potential and the future of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, we need to be aware that these islands will, because of the taxation measures in the explanatory memorandum, undergo very considerable sociological change in the next few years. To a large extent, the community is dependant at the moment on welfare and government provisions. It will be necessary to ensure that work is created in those communities. Probably the only way in which this will adequately happen and come into effect will be through the development of tourism and environmental projects, creating jobs in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

The report Islands in the Sun recommends that a number of government services ought in future to be provided from Western Australia, particularly in the fields of education and health. As those changes take place, it will be important to watch the changes that will happen in the sociology of the largely Malay community on Cocos and Christmas Islands. I believe that is the very point that Pauline Bunce is making and the concerns that she has and that she has put to me and to the Minister, Mr Simmons, in the past.

As far as Australia is concerned, the infrastructure which we provide on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is most important, particularly in the areas of defence and quarantine. We must acknowledge that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are Australia's defence carrier in the Indian Ocean. We ought not to walk away from the important defence and strategic implications that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands have for all of us. At the same time, the quarantine facilities on the islands are an important primary industry facility. As I said earlier, we must ensure that the community on the islands receive meaningful work and investment opportunities, whether it is in tourism or in the government infrastructure projects.

The most important aspect that we should be looking at is that there are people living on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. It is our responsibility to ensure that the impositions that we impose on their lifestyle and on their economy are properly under surveillance and under consideration at all times by this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I would like to deal with clause 30 of the Bill, which refers to the changes in land degradation. In doing so, I read from the explanatory memorandum to highlight what is happening in this particular area:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will amend the tax laws in two ways. Firstly, a deduction for these capital expenditures is also to be available to all taxpayers who carry on a business using rural land in Australia.

Secondly, the Bill also provides a deduction for expenses to both primary producers and taxpayers who carry on business using rural land in Australia, where fences are erected primarily and principally to prevent degradation of the land whether or not that particular area is already degraded.
Currently, the law only allows the capital cost of fences where they are erected primarily and principally to prevent further land degradation in already degraded areas.

In other words, the Bill is saying that there will be deductions of expenditure on prevention of land degradation for all rural businesses. The Bill also says that the business must derive its income from the land but that the business does not have to own the land.

A point that I wish to raise in this debate-I will be pursuing it in the committee stage; this decision was made last August and we now have the legislation before us-concerns what happens on those particular properties where work has been carried out in terms of land degradation without having the definition which was required in front of them for the approval of whole farm plans. Of course, that is to be amended now-I will speak on that in a moment-to a land management plan. I believe that there should be some mechanism put in place which will allow those rural businesses or farmers who are operating on the land to be able to make the claim for the work that has gone in during that period. It is virtually close to one year in practical working terms-it would be one year for most of the businesses-since this change to the taxation system has been in place.

I move to the amendments which I, along with my colleague Senator Watson will pursue-the honourable member for Barker, Mr McLachlan, has pursued them also-concerning the changes from a whole farm plan to a land management plan. We welcome this change because the whole arrangements are made much more practical and will lead to a much better utilisation of this particular amendment to the taxation law. The reason it improves the situation significantly is primarily that putting together a farm plan is a very costly and expensive business. In many instances, one does not need a whole farm plan to tackle the problem of land degradation. It also allows for the larger holdings, in particular, to be carried out in stages.

The other important point with regard to this amendment relates to the approval of those plans. It has now been extended to go beyond the landcare consultancy agencies to include farm consultants. While this is welcomed for those people who will be able to approve land management plans, one must ask the question: why is it necessary to put this red tape in place? I believe it will be far more effective if it is done by the farmer himself. In most instances-I will not claim all-farmers have a much greater and intricate knowledge of the detail of the land types, water flows, wind directions and all the things that are important in combating land degradation. I pose the question: why could this not have been dealt with through self-assessment?

In the couple of minutes remaining, I would like to highlight the importance of this particular area in my own State and outline what has occurred there in the last 12 months. If we compare the national soil conservation report of 1989-90 to the situation we find ourselves in now, we find that at the end of 1989-90, 70 per cent of land users were involved in landcare district programs, or soil conservation committees as they are called in Western Australia. Today, close to 80 per cent of land users are involved. In June of last year there were 109 landcare district committees (LCDCs); today, there are 130. Seventy-five per cent of the agricultural land was covered by committees at 30 June last year; today, over 85 per cent of agricultural land is covered.

On 30 June, 80 per cent of the pastoral lands were covered with landcare districts. Today, almost 100 per cent of the lands are covered. In other words, Western Australia has a very small way to go towards putting the land care infrastructure of the people necessary in place for total conservation management of rural land use. It has been estimated that the $350,000 of funding from the Federal Government spent in this area, with the community contribution that has gone into that through self-help programs, is worth in excess of $1m. It has been a very effective investment in terms of conservation.

I touch on a couple of other points relating to the landcare committees. Over 1,500 people are now involved in the committees, 89 of those committees having women actively participating as committee members. A total of 120 women are involved in the LCDCs. Four women chair the committees. There are 46 secretaries, seven shire representatives, including three from the Western Australian Farmers Federation and three from the Pastoralists and Graziers Association. Fifty of the women involved are land users and 11 are Department of Agriculture officers.

I welcome these amendments because I believe that they will give much greater scope and incentive to tackling land degradation problems. However, I re-emphasise my concern, firstly, that virtually 12 months have slipped past since the decision was made, and I believe that those people who have continued to carry on with soil conservation measures aimed at reducing land degradation should not be disadvantaged because the mechanism for approving farm plans has only now been put in place. Secondly, I am concerned about the red tape that has been put around this subject. I believe that in the vast majority of cases-I am talking in excess of 95 per cent-the land users, particularly the pastoralists and farmers, would have a much more intricate knowledge than others of the land degradation problems and would know more about fence positioning, tree planting, drainage and so on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 gives effect to a number of changes to taxation laws. I do not intend to canvass all these changes but rather to address some remarks to clause 30 of the Bill, which will change section 75d of the principal Act. Anyone with rural property would be familiar with this section, which deals with allowable deductions for expenditure on the prevention of land degradation. Taxation deductions for farmers can hardly be said to have been consistent over the past few years. In fact, it seems that in just about every Budget-depending on whether an election is waxing or waning-successive governments either give or take away deductions for various farming activities. Perhaps because this is the Decade of Landcare or perhaps because it is a relatively cheap offering to the rural sector, the Government has decided to give something back to the farmers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I will summarise briefly the proposed changes in the part of the Bill I am most interested in at this stage. Under the existing law, a deduction is available for certain capital expenditures that prevent or combat land degradation. This deduction is limited to taxpayers who carry on a business of primary production using land in Australia. However, this Bill proposes to amend the taxation laws in two ways. First, a deduction for those capital expenses will also be available to all taxpayers who carry on a business on rural land in Australia. Secondly, a deduction will be provided for the expenses of both primary producers and taxpayers who carry on a business using rural land in Australia where fences are erected primarily and principally to prevent-that is the operative word-degradation of the land, whether or not an area is already degraded. Currently the law allows a deduction for the capital cost of fences only where they are erected primarily and principally to prevent further land degradation in already degraded areas.

The Opposition-in particular members of the National Party of Australia, who have a special interest in rural constituencies-welcomes this commitment by the Federal Government. It will cost only $2.7m in 1990-91; $4.2m in 1991-92; and about $5m in 1992-93. That is a small price to pay for protecting a vital asset-the soil and the land of Australia. Given the prevailing attitude of this Government to the rural sector, it is a pleasant change to see-at least in this legislation-that it is prepared to acknowledge that farmers ought to be encouraged and assisted in their endeavours to protect our greatest natural resource, the soil. Most things stem from the soil, and I think that has not been acknowledged as often as it should have been in the past.

Having said that, I add that the Government is now so out of touch with rural Australia that it did not bother to consult on or consider how these taxation deductions ought to be established. In the view of the Opposition and of most, if not all, rural organisations, the Government's original proposition was totally unworkable and unaffordable, especially in these impossibly bad economic times. The original legislation proposed that farmers should submit a whole farm plan, duly designed or approved by a farm consultant or other appropriately qualified person. Senator Watson, who led this debate for the Opposition, did a lot of good work behind the scenes and obviously there was some good reciprocal work by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin). Perhaps Senator Watson would have achieved even more had the former Minister not been shifted from that portfolio to take on the position of Treasurer. Be that as it may, I believe Senator Watson has achieved through his endeavours a lot for country people in making this Bill more workable.

What Senator Watson worked for and what he sensibly and successfully suggested was that the term `whole farm' was too wide-reaching and that a more appropriate term was `land management plan', which may or may not involve the whole farm. In the present economic climate I think it is unlikely that farmers with large holdings could afford to undertake land care programs involving their entire operations. The Government has actually accepted that change to the Bill.

In recent years the Government has acknowledged the importance of sound soil management and has promoted, if more in word than in deed, land care groups across Australia. In his speech a few moments ago Senator Crane alluded to that. I believe that my support for and interest and involvement in soil conservation are well known. For too long soil conservation has been a much neglected environmental issue. It has never attracted the media hype and passionate emotions of the tree huggers and whale watchers. In fact, it could probably be said that it is just not a sexy subject, as is hugging trees and walking through the forests. Even now, despite wide media coverage and raised public consciousness, I do not believe there is enough understanding about soil erosion. I do not believe that the average Australian appreciates the significance of what soil erosion costs in terms of lost production, lost opportunities and lost soil.

Australia remains dependent on the productivity of its rural sector and will do so for many decades to come, yet it continues to expect its farmers to produce export commodities in an economic climate that defies belief. This legislation will provide some little taxation relief to those farmers lucky enough to have any income whatsoever this year. I wonder whether the legislation could have gone a little further and provided tax credits, if you like, for soil conservation works, whether fencing or other works, that could have been carried forward for future years when people in the rural communities might have had a taxable income and would have received the benefit of doing that work to protect our soil and our country.

However, this year the impact for many will be minimal or non-existent. Given that so many of our wheat and wool farmers are being forced out of those industries, there will be few farmers in these commodities purchasing fencing or other materials or undertaking earthworks to contain the land degradation problems. For those farmers tax deductibility is irrelevant. The reality of eligibility for tax deductions is that one has to be able to afford to spend the money in the first place in order to attract the tax benefit. For the thousands of farmers with negative incomes this year, tax deductibility for any expenditure is not a consideration. At the moment no money is available to buy fertiliser, to replace stock, or even to provide for pasture regeneration. Certainly there is no money for frills such as planting trees, gully erosion control and so on.

Land management, while an essential element of any sound farming enterprise, has become an expendable luxury. So while the intentions of the Bill are sound, in reality the Bill is quite meaningless and of little consequence in this year. What it gives in the form of a very small inducement the Government has already taken away in crippling interest rates, lost export markets, nil to slow labour market reform, no impression whatsoever on waterfront reform, and soaring cost structures that have seen the decimation of our rural towns and communities. Indeed, this Government will be remembered in history as the most destructive of rural Australia. Today we can acknowledge, however, the very small plus made by this Bill, but in a long list of things that the Federal Labor Government has taken from Australia it is a very small reversal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

I understand that some comments were made by both the Opposition and the Democrats concerning mine site rehabilitation. In responding to that, I refer to a letter which I sent to that Association earlier this week, which read in part:

It was, of course, indicated in the 1990-91 Budget announcement that the removal of oil platforms would be covered by this amendment and the Government considers it sufficiently clear that such outlays are encompassed by the general understanding of mine site rehabilitation.

References to `restoration of a site . . . to, or to a reasonable approximation of, the pre-mining condition of the site' are intended to limit the application of the provisions to rehabilitation ensuring they do not apply to improvements. TALK.START.PARA: —For example, a quarry could be converted into a lake, with appropriate landscaping.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that Senator Watson has incorporated some further matters on securities lending and I thank him for discussing that with me earlier. All I can say about that at the moment is that we will consider these comments during our further deliberations on the legislation. I do not want to respond specifically at the moment. I think I have addressed the priority points that I wanted to raise in the time available. If there are some matters of particular detail to which honourable senators wish to have a second reading response, I will deal with them at the committee stage.

I want to say something about the question raised by Senator Spindler concerning the tax status of progress associations. I do not want to get into a situation with regard to this matter-any more than I did with regard to mine site rehabilitation-of becoming a court of appeal for individual taxpayers. I will not attempt to give interpretations of circumstances when I do not know all the facts relating to individual taxpayers. But in the Newcastle region, particularly, there has been some misunderstanding of the situation with regard to bodies such as progress associations.

I want to put these points clearly: various non-profit community organisations-sometimes described as progress associations-generally are exempt from income tax under the Income Tax Assessment Act. These are organisations which conduct activities such as maintaining local sports grounds, school of arts halls and so on. The exemption would not apply to bodies which conduct significant political or lobbying activities.

`Progress association' is a phrase which covers a multitude of different organisations and I, of course, do not know the circumstance of the one referred to. But in general, what we would normally call `progress associations'-those of which I am aware, such as community associations-would be exempt as a result of recent amendments.

I understand that there has been some misunderstanding because of the wording of a pamphlet which was distributed by the Newcastle branch of the Tax Office, but that has been withdrawn. It was substantially over-general. The points I have made on this matter can be applied generally. Their application in every circumstance will depend on the facts of the case but a more comprehensive explanatory document will be emerging from the national office shortly. I can assure the Senate that, in general, bodies which we normally call `progress associations'-those non-profit community organisations-would be exempt from income tax under the Income Tax Assessment Act unless there are particular and special circumstances with regard to any particular association. With those comments, I thank the Senate for its general support for the legislation and I commend it to the chamber.

TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I table the supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to the Government amendments to be moved to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. After clause 4, page 2, insert the following clause
``Repeal of Section 64a
`4a. Section 64a of the Principal Act is repealed.'.''.

Essentially, the purpose of the amendment is to insert after clause 4 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 a clause, the purpose of which is to repeal section 64a of the principal Act. According to the training guarantee legislation, employers would not be liable to pay the higher education contribution scheme (HECS) charge in relation to persons attending institutions for training purposes under that scheme. However, an anomaly exists because under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 there is no exemption from that charge.

This anomaly was raised by the Australian Democrats in the committee stage during the debate on the Training Guarantee Bill 1990. At that time the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) gave the Democrats his assurance that this anomaly would be corrected. He said that it could not be done in the context of the present training legislation but would have to be done as an amendment to a taxation law. Hence, we are discussing this change now.

The taxation anomaly also means that HECS fees paid for public courses are not deductible compared with charges for private courses. Therefore, this component of training expenditure represents a disincentive for employers to seek out training in public institutions compared with private providers. In this chamber on 31 May 1990, Senator Bolkus said that the Government was:
. . . prepared to look at the tax treatment of employer payments to HECS to ensure that public institutions are not put at a disadvantage.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a chart which sets out the tax distortion of education choices. This document was prepared by the Parliamentary Library last year when the original legislation was passed.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Tax distortion of education choices:
Company
A
B
C
D
Profit ($) ...
Less Training ($) Expense ...
Taxable Income ($) ...
Less Company Tax ($) ...
Less Fringe ($) Benefit Tax ...
Dist Income ($) ...
Assumptions:
1. Company Tax rate (CTR) 39%
2. Fringe Benefits Tax rate (FBTR) 47%
3. Only the actual course fees are paid by the company-all books, travel etc expenses are borne by the trainee.
4. The HECS fee is $1,800.
5. The private institution training fee is also $1,800.
6. A is a taxable company incurring a private training expense.
7. B is a taxable company incurring a HEC's expense.
8. C is a non-taxable company incurring a private expense.
9. D is a non-taxable company incurring a HEC's expense.
Conclusion:
There is an after tax advantage to both taxable and non-taxable employers if they send their employees to non HECS institutions.
For taxable companies the difference arises because of subsection 51 (6) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which denies a tax deduction for any HEC's payment.
This reduces the distributable income of the HECS paying company by HECS x CTR = $1,800 x .39 = $702.
This can only be altered by an amendment repealing subsection 51 (6).

For non-taxable companies the difference arises because of subsection 64a of the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 which excludes all taxable companies from Fringe Benefit Tax in respect of HECS payments but does not operate where employers are exempt from income tax.
This reduces the distributable income of the HECS paying company by HECS x FBTR = $1,800 x .47 = $846.

This view of the operation of section 64A was given by the Commissioner of Taxation in Income Tax Ruling MT2046. Although of no legal effect the Ruling is, in my opinion, correct and definitely indicates the Commissioner's practice on this matter. Withdrawal of the Ruling is a possibility-this recently occurred with former Ruling MT2035 however this occurred after a conflicting Court decision and a concerted campaign for its withdrawal.
Consequently amendment of the Fringe Benefit Tax Assessment Act seems the only viable option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will read briefly from page 1 of a document prepared by the Parliamentary Research Service which refers to this matter. I think it may illuminate the issue for those who are trying to understand what I am on about. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Higher Education Contribution (HECS) payable under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 is not an allowable deduction for income tax purposes under section 51 (6) of the Assessment Act . . . The non-deductibility applies even to an employer in respect of HECS paid on behalf of an employee. HECS also do not form part of expenses of self-education under section 82a (2) . . . Thus HECS cannot form part of self-education expenses under section 51 or expenses of self-education under section 82a.

Under section 26(1) (d) of the Training Guarantee Act 1990 payment of fees, HECs and payments in reduction of HECs debts in relation to eligible training programs would be eligible training expenditure if paid by an employer.

Therefore, they are tax deductible. It is immediately apparent that that is an anomaly which can be removed by the amendment we are now proposing. Under section 51(7) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the training guarantee charge is not an allowable deduction for income tax purposes. The law requires an amendment to allow HECs paid by an employer in relation to an eligible training program as a deduction for income tax purposes. That is essentially the nature of the amendment we are proposing.

To facilitate that amendment and also to make sure it does not bring about a complication with fringe benefits tax, I refer to clause 28, and I will speak for another 60 or 70 words on that. I mention clause 28 as it deals with fringe benefits. We would amend section 51(6) with the effect that it applies except to the extent that the amounts referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) are paid by an employer in relation to an eligible training program to qualify as eligible training expenditure for the purposes of the Training Guarantee Act. That would follow through.

An amendment would also be necessary to section 64a of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 so that the deduction allowed under the proposed proviso of the Income Tax Assessment Act is not treated as a fringe benefit for the purposes of that Act. I think it would be fairly straightforward, when the next clause comes through, to insert that provision. I will leave it at that. The chart which has been incorporated explains the differences. It does not have a lot to do with the actual principle which I think is straightforward. There is an anomaly in an employer or an employee seeking to obtain taxation deductibility for the expenses of the higher education contribution scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty hard act to improve upon. I would like to say something briefly about the substance of the argument. I share the procedural concerns that Senator Watson has expressed, and that would have been sufficient for us to oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson stated that there was an anomaly in respect of taxation deductibility. Items of expenditure which are treated differently by different aspects of tax legislation do not necessarily constitute an anomaly. Something may be exempt in one circumstance and not in another for perfectly valid reasons of proper public policy. I think, fairly put, that is a circumstance which we have now.

There has not been, and is not, an intention on behalf of the Government to align the higher education contribution scheme (HECS) and the Income Tax Assessment Act in any manner that would make the treatment of all expenditures the same. We do not treat capital equipment the same. It is our view that it is not appropriate for HECS expenditure to be deductible in the way that is outlined.

For the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act it is our view that the deductibility of such expenditure should be assessed against the standard criterion in the Act and not by way of any special provision. That is, and remains, our view. It has always been our view and we intend to persist with it. For those reasons, and in addition to the views expressed by Senator Watson, we will not be supporting the amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter was raised with me on several occasions by organisations seeking the sort of modification that we have now made. I will refer to these amendments as Government amendments; there will be subsequent amendments which I will refer to as Government further amendments, for the sake of what might laughingly be called simplicity. These amendments relate to some minor alterations-and there will be others in this package-to the changes to securities lending arrangements proposed by the Bill. They are the result of further representations to the Government.

The amendments were developed in consultation with the Australian Stock Exchange. They do not change the substance of the Bill and have no effect on the revenue. The Stock Exchange is satisfied that the proposed amendments deal with the concerns that it expressed about the practical operations of some of the provisions relating to securities lending arrangements and that they will facilitate the implementation of an improved settlement system. The transfer of franked dividends provisions will not take effect until at least 1 August 1991. This will allow the Stock Exchange more time to put new rules and procedures in place. Full details of the amendments are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: 1. After clause 26, page 38, insert the following clause:
``26a. After subsection 31(1) of the Principal Act, the following subsections are inserted:

This amendment is to be inserted after clause 26. My attention has been drawn to two typographical errors in the circulated document. It should read `After clause 26, page 38' rather than 28; and it should read `add the following clause: 26a' instead of 27a. In moving this amendment, I return to 1988 when the Government, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, passed the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1988 which, amongst other things, imposed a tax on the income from gold mining. The previous exemption had existed since the 1920s--

TALK.START.PARA: —From 1924, actually.

—I thank Senator Panizza-1924. It had been a distortion in the tax system for decades after the initial reason for its inception-the exchange rate policy of the United Kingdom-had ceased to be relevant. The tax exemption was to be ended only for income derived after 1 January 1991. It was mainly to honour the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before the 1987 election that the exemption should remain for the whole of the next term of Government. The grubby story of political donations connected with the gold mining exemption, both to the Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party, has now been revealed-and it will be interesting to see where the revelations end. This delay is estimated by Treasury to have cost approximately $300m per annum. In fact, a new gold rush started as miners sought to take advantage of the window of opportunity which the continued exemption provided.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter which was not mentioned in the debate on the legislation in either House was the question of the valuation of transitional stocks. Under ordinary income tax law, taxpayers have the option of valuing their trading stock at the end of each year by any one of three methods: cost, market price or replacement value. To ensure that unfair manipulation does not occur, the value chosen at the end of one year must also be used at the beginning of the subsequent year.

The situation with respect to stocks of gold is quite unique. The gold companies have the choice to value stock under the three methods I have mentioned, although tax is only payable in the subsequent period; that is, from 1 January 1991 and not in the previous period up to 31 December 1990. Consequently, there is an incentive to value stocks held at 31 December 1990 at as high a value as possible, as this then maximises the amount of the income arising from transitional stocks which benefit from the exemption. Clearly, this has provided an incentive to extract as much as possible before 1 January 1991, and the figures available attest to the fact that this has occurred. As I said, there has been a veritable gold rush to extract and stockpile as much gold ore as possible. The value of gold produced in the March 1991 quarter, the first tax- able quarter, fell 15 per cent from the last exempt quarter and this decline in production was worth $145m.

My amendment seeks to tax the value of the transitional stocks which would otherwise escape income tax by limiting the valuation of transitional stocks held on 31 December 1990 to the cost formula of the gold producer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be agreeing to this Australian Democrats amendment moved by Senator Spindler. The process of tacking unrelated measures onto an omnibus tax Bill is not an unfamiliar device in the Senate; it is frequently used by the Australian Democrats. It is not a device that as an Opposition the Liberal and National parties welcome. Changes of this nature are best brought about by private members' Bills with the proper explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, we have seen today the hurried introduction of an amendment resulting in a great deal of confusion with a number of errors. Clause 26 of course is not a related provision; it is an interpretation provision concerning eligible termination payments and annuities. The Australian Democrats incorrectly put page 28 when it should have been page 38. Clause 27a should have been clause 26a. To expect parliamentarians to accept changes of this nature involving inaccuracies of this sort of magnitude is just not acceptable. It is an issue that should have been raised by way of a private members' Bill or it was an oversight on the part of the Democrats in examining, I think, tax Bill No. 5. Proposed subsection 31 on page 28, for example, refers to payments to veterans. No wonder the honourable senator is confused because this makes very little reference to veterans and the transitional provisions relating to payments to them.

Basically, this amendment is about denying an option that is acknowledged income tax law for valuation of trading stock. What this amendment seeks to do is to limit the ability of the gold mining industry, an industry whose income tax status has changed, and to deny it the opportunity of applying a valuation other than cost price. It is a measure that brings about an uneven playing field to transitory provisions. It is certainly not a provision that the Opposition welcomes. It is a direct attack on the mining industry, at a time of economic recession. Already, we are finding enough problems with the Australian Taxation Office's ability to change the basis of valuations.

I refer to a question directed to Senator Button. The Australian Taxation Office, in the prevailing recessed conditions, is now denying primary producers the right to change the basis of valuation of livestock from cost to market price under a section 33 discretion. Yet here we are introducing a further limitation by virtue of a new clause 26a when we already have a problem under section 33 of the Income Tax Assessment Tax.

For the purpose of pursuing this line, this extraordinary refusal, which impacts most severely on the sheep and wool producers of this country, is based on the grounds that a general fluctuation in livestock prices where the market movement is occasioned by widely prevailing economic circumstances is not sufficient to warrant a change in the manner in which the taxation of livestock is assessed. I submit that such a decision is uncaring, unreasonable and destructive and will have a deleterious effect at a time when the wool and sheep industry is in such a depressed condition.

I mention this because, in circumstances where we are having trouble with section 33a, the Democrats have the temerity to attack another very vital industry-one which was a prime income earner in terms of the balance of payments. There is a further attack on its viability and cash flow by virtue of the unnatural clause 26a to be introduced into the Income Tax Assessment Act. On behalf of the Opposition, we will not be agreeing to this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take exception to the remarks made by our colleague Senator Spindler, even though I was not the originator of that abusive remark and naturally do not condone it. —I want to comment on Senator Spindler's stockpile. I have already dealt with the idea of stockpiling.
—It is not his stockpile; it is yours.

—It is my stockpile; that is right. Dealing with the stockpile figures Senator Spindler mentioned-one company has 70,000 ounces of gold and another has one million tonnes of ore stockpiled, I think he said-as a representative of the mining industry and one who was brought up in the goldfields, which is also an agricultural area, I would be happy if there were 10 times this amount of ore in the stockpile because we would be getting 10 times that amount in foreign income in the next few months. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that this little conflagration may in some marginal way distort public perception of what I believe is a major and proper reform of the tax system-that is, the introduction of provisions to ensure that income from the mining of gold is taxed in the same manner as other income on the fairly fundamental principle that income is income and ought to be taxed accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: I will say a couple of things about the amendment before indicating why I am opposed to it. Firstly, we need to reject these sorts of tawdry little allegations of deals. They are easy to throw around. They do not enhance the debate about issues on their merits; they merely reinforce the perceptions that, firstly, debate in this place sometimes is not what it ought to be and, secondly, if anybody were to believe them, it would lower that person's assessment of the political process in a manner that is not helpful. I have to reject it absolutely. It is entirely contrary to the evidence, and it seems remarkable to me that anybody would suggest that the government that remedied a longstanding anomaly was a government that did a deal with the gold industry. That seems to me to be absurd. I am not making the reverse allegation about the Opposition; I am simply saying that it is a remarkable allegation. It is not unique; it has been made before, but repetition does not make something which is remarkable acceptable.

I wish briefly to talk about the reason why I oppose this amendment, and why the Government will be opposing it. It is simply that in dealing with a longstanding anomaly reasonable transitional arrangements had to be introduced. As I understand it, those reasonable transitional arrangements were similar to those which applied in the past when moves were made to tax previously exempt activities-for example, the changes with regard to superannuation and with regard to the foreign tax credit system. When we are establishing that income previously exempt is to become taxable we need to make arrangements which are firstly predictable so that people can make arrangements and, secondly, equitable, so that income is taxed as far as possible in the same manner as the income of other taxpayers is taxed. That is what these transitional arrangements provide. I can understand people saying that we should have made different transitional arrangements several years ago. I do not agree with that, but I can understand it. That would be a debate which could reasonably have been had at the time. But having established these arrangements appropriately-that is, on the same basis as in other industries-and even if they were not, although I believe they are, it is now not the time to be disrupting them for a very important industry which is going through a transition which in my view it should have, but which nevertheless it needs time to adjust to. These transitional arrangements are appropriate and I therefore oppose the amendment.
Amendment negatived.
