These further amendments propose a minor change to the provision dealing with land degradation proposed by the Bill and result from representations made to the Government. The amendments will ensure that a tax deduction is also available where a taxpayer undertakes a land management plan of the area on which fences are erected to prevent land degradation, rather than a plan of the whole area on which a primary production or a rural business is being conducted. TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the amendments. (2) In this section:

`Designated arrangement' means circumstances which lead the Commissioner to reasonably believe that interest derived by a non-resident from an Australian source is the subject of a scheme to avoid or otherwise minimise tax;
`relevant agent' means the person specified in a notice issued pursuant to paragraph (1) (b), where either section 255 or 257 apply to that person.''.

This amendment relates to yet another of the perpetual problems of tax avoidance that the Committee and the Australian community have to cope with. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, chaired by Mr Stephen Martin, has released its final report on international profit shifting entitled Follow the Yellow Brick Road. The report is comprehensive and attacks many roads most prominent in the system of converting Australian source income into an interest stream paid to non-residents, and Australian income tax is thereby limited to the withholding tax rate of 10 per cent. Even the gold miners would welcome that, I am sure.

I have pursued this matter in the Senate before, and it has been vigorously pursued by others in the community, such as Melbourne tax academic Barbara Smith. I believe that the most important recommendation of the report is recommendation No. 2, which proposes that the Commissioner of Taxation be provided with a discretionary power to impose the top marginal rate of tax on interest income earned by non-residents instead of the 10 per cent interest withholding tax rate in cases where the Commissioner is of the opinion, and has reason to believe, that the interest income derived by a non-resident from an Australian source relates to an artificial arrangement established by an Australian interest for tax avoidance purposes.

The increased rate shall apply until the non-resident who derives the interest income is able to verify that the interest payment is not related to a tax avoidance arrangement-that is, the Martin Committee is recommending a system of tax payment at the time of derivation of the interest to ensure that avoidance arrangements are stopped as they occur. This is the current system which applies to bearer bonds held by people who are not known to the Tax Office. Tax is deducted from the interest payments on these bonds at the maximum marginal rate. However, to be fair to the taxpayer, this deduction does not constitute a final liability. The tax may be credited against the income of the recipient of the interest, and any overpayment is refundable.

The Australian Democrats believe that this is a good model to use to implement recommendation No. 2 of the Martin Committee report. This foreign loans rort is widespread and would be largely nullified by this amendment if it is passed today. The structure of the amendment is simple. Where the Commissioner of Taxation is of the opinion that there is a tax avoidance arrangement operating, he or she may instruct the person paying the interest that he or she must deduct withholding tax at the rate which is applicable as though the interest paid were paid in respect of a bearer bond to a person unknown to the Commissioner.

The measure is urgent in order to plug an acknowledged loophole, which even the Tax Office admits is costing hundreds of millions of dollars per year. I repeat again that it does not impose a final taxation liability, but effects an efficient method of tax collection to enable avoidance schemes to be foiled as they occur-not after the horse has bolted. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) whether he could clarify the following concerns in article 2 (1) (b) of the schedule which refers to profit taxes in Hungary. The meaning of the term is far from clear, given other definitions in the schedule. For example, article 2 (1) (a) stipulates the inclusion of both income tax and petroleum resource rent tax for these purposes. This is a new concept. Article 13 refers to gains from the alienation of property, which presumably is just another way of describing capital gains tax. The terms `income tax' and `capital gains tax' strike me as being mutually exclusive, if only because all over the world such taxes are separate and separable. It seems that where article 23 refers to income, profits or gains, capital gains tax could be included twice. Because it appears in the agreement with Hungary and includes more than just income tax, some further explanations are required.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, what about the taxes that are levied in Hungary and not in Australia, and vice versa? Hungary imposes a tax on assets of the individual where the value of assets exceeds a stipulated threshold, irrespective of whether those assets earn income. Is such a tax embraced in this Bill?

What about death duties? Hungary levies death duties. Are only taxes required by central governments of each country affected by the measures we have under discussion? For example, municipal taxes in Hungary raise revenue to finance some services which in Australia are financed from Canberra. Are these to be included? I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to put on the record that there is no reciprocity for state and municipal taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson raised quite a wide-ranging number of issues. I will respond to them as best I can.
—Or take them on notice.

—I think I can do it now. I will try to respond to them concisely and as best as I can. If there is some part I have not covered, we may deal with that subsequently. Firstly, there was the question about profit taxes. Hungary has a uniform profits tax which is levied on everyone carrying on business activities in Hungary. It is similar to the tax paid by business enterprises and companies in Australia. The Hungarian branch of a foreign entrepreneur is also subject to this tax. The agreement applies to all substantially identical taxes in each country. The name of the taxes vary from one country to another.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson also referred to alienation of profit, property and capital gains tax. The term `alienation of property' in article 13 refers to capital gains resulting from the sale or exchange of property. Most countries which tax capital gains do so when an alienation takes place. This article allocates the taxing rights.

Senator Watson then talked about article 23. Article 23 simply allocates the source for the purpose of the other articles mentioned in it. This is necessary for the purpose of Australian law because Australian tax law does not contain statutory source rules. Australia gives effect to the agreement through its domestic legislation. For a non-resident to be taxable in Australia, the non-resident must have income profits or gains from an Australian source. This article deems that income to have an Australian source. It precludes any conflict arising for domestic purposes and preserves our right to tax that income.

Senator Watson also referred to taxes which exist in Hungary and not in Australia, or vice versa-specifically, death duties and the assets tax. These and other taxes are not income taxes; therefore, they are not the subject of this agreement. It is specifically stated in article 2 of this Bill and all Australia's double tax agreements that the agreement applies only to taxes imposed under the Federal laws of Australia. This is to ensure that an agreement does not bind the States. The agreement applies only to Federal taxes and the corresponding taxes in the treaty partner country which are mentioned in the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for that very comprehensive answer. Therefore, the reciprocity is that only federal taxes in Hungary apply rather than the equivalent state taxes, even though some of those taxes fund federally the sorts of things that they fund here in Australia. In relation to article 23, can we have an assurance that under that formula mechanism there will be no situation where it is included twice as a result of capital gains?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am confident, on looking at it myself-Senator Watson will be confident to hear that I am also assured by others that it is definite-that there will not be a double tax situation. There seems to be no doubt about that. I am also advised that this Bill relates only to federal taxes in Hungary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight in the first reading debate of Supply Bill (No. 1) 1991-92. This gives me the opportunity to speak on any issue that concerns me, as the Senate would be aware.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate knows, for at least the past seven years-and many years before that-I have had a major concern regarding the amount of violence and pornography allowed in videos. I have always believed that the two cannot be divorced from each other. As a result, in November 1988 I presented a private member's Bill to the Senate which was aimed at reducing the amount of violence and pornography allowed in videos.

I would like to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to read parts of a judgment of a case-the Crown v. Darryl John Phillips-which was brought down by Judge Mathews on 21 May this year. I would like to read parts of that judgment into the Hansard record and bring to the Senate's attention my concerns in this area. Judge Mathews said:
On 24 April 1991 Darryl John Phillips was convicted by a jury of murdering Irene Julie Glanville at The Rock near Wagga on 27 February 1990.
It was an appallingly violent, tragic and above all senseless killing. Indeed the background circumstances when they unfolded at the trial were as sad as any I have ever encountered.

The prisoner had never met Mrs Glanville before. She had lived for a number of years with her husband and young children at a property called ``Timbarra'' just out of The Rock. Mr Glanville was a school teacher and was thus away from home during the day. By 1990 their two oldest children were of school age and also went into town each week day with their father. Thus it was that Mrs Glanville was at home alone with her two youngest children on 27 February. Those children were aged three and a half and twenty months respectively.

About eighteen months before 27 February the prisoner's father, Trevor Phillips, had bought another property at The Rock called ``Pleasant View'' which adjoined the Glanville property. He moved down there with his son, Darryl, who was then sixteen years old, and his daughter, Michelle who was two years younger. Mr Phillips was employed as a boilermaker and Michelle was still at school. The prisoner had left school but had been able to gain only sporadic employment in the Wagga area; accordingly he also was alone at the property most week days.

The prisoner, as I say, had never met Mrs Glanville before. He had met her husband on two or three occasions over the previous months when he had called at the Glanville home apparently for the purpose of discussing some straying sheep. There was some suggestion in the Crown case that the straying sheep were only a pretext, and that these visits were in fact designed to try and find Mrs Glanville at home alone. However, in my view there is insufficient material to support this proposition.

27 February 1990, a Tuesday, commenced like any other week day on both properties. Mr Phillips and Michelle left in the morning, as did Mr Glanville and the two older Glanville children. At about 9.30 that morning the prisoner watched a video he had hired from a Wagga Wagga video shop. It was called ``Nightmare at Shadow Woods''. I shall say something more about this video shortly: it was shown in court during the course of the trial. Suffice it to say for the moment that it was an unpleasant, violent film in which the major character was a psychopath who roamed the area with a large knife killing a number of people in extremely ghoulish circumstances.

Having watched this film the prisoner took a knife, known as a butterfly knife, and walked across the paddocks to the Glanville home. He went to the front door and spoke to Mrs Glanville about some stray sheep which he said he had penned. She wrote a note to her husband telling him to ring the Phillips home after 7pm. This note was later found by Mr Glanville and given to the police.

The prisoner and Mrs Glanville had a short further conversation and then parted on friendly terms. The prisoner apparently left but did not return home. Instead he waited outside the Glanville home and about five minutes later removed the flyscreen from a bedroom window and climbed in. He encountered Mrs Glanville in a hallway. She ran towards the kitchen in an unsuccessful attempt to reach the telephone. It was later found dangling off its hook. She was clearly no match for the frenzied strength of the prisoner. He stabbed her again and again. Even when she was on the ground he continued stabbing her. She was later found to have sustained eighteen stab wounds. A number of them according to the medical evidence must have been inflicted with very considerable force. One of the wounds had passed through the right ventricle of Mrs Glanville's heart. That alone would have been sufficient to kill her. Nevertheless, according to the medical evidence there was probably a lapse of some fifteen to thirty minutes before she died.

Her two young children were sitting at the kitchen table watching it all and screaming. They were still sitting [in] the same place in the presence of their dead mother when Mr Glanville arrived home with the two older children about four hours later.

In the meantime the prisoner had walked back across the paddock to the Phillips home. There he had showered and put all his clothes, including his shoes, into the washing machine. He cut the knife into small pieces using a chisel and hammer, and then concealed the pieces in mice holes in a shed on the property. In other words he took a number of very precise steps in order to obliterate any sign of involvement in Mrs Glanville's killing.
The judge's report goes on at some length to deal with the evidence taken. She refers to the disturbed state of mind of the prisoner and the evidence given by both the Crown and the defence and says:
In the result I am compelled to find that the prisoner was significantly more disturbed than Dr Milton's assessment would indicate.
Dr Milton was a witness for the Crown. The judge goes on to say:

Certainly he was not so disturbed as to reduce his culpability from murder to manslaughter under s 23A. I must also conclude, in accordance with the jury's verdict, that there was probably no organic basis for his disturbance. Nevertheless, the evidence given at the trial clearly indicates to me that the prisoner was a very disturbed young man, both before and after he committed this offence.
The judge then goes on to talk about the video that the young man had watched just before committing the crime. She says:

It is not so easy to absolve a system which allows for such a violent and unmeritorious film as ``Nightmare at Shadow Woods'' to be viewed indiscriminately by members of the community regardless of their underlying problems or susceptibilities. It was a film with no discernible artistic material at all. As far as I could see it was nothing more than a vehicle for depicting gratuitous, mindless and ghoulish violence.
That video is rated `M'. She goes on to say:
Dr Milton considered that the film acted as a trigger for the prisoner, transforming fantasies about violence into an intention to inflict actual violence. Dr Westmore-
for the defence-

also thought that the film acted as a trigger in that it was a disturbing agent in the prisoner's already disturbed brain. So that whichever version one were to accept, the viewing of this film had a real part to play in the tragedy which followed. Certainly the prisoner was already a vulnerable and disturbed person, but it is precisely such a person which is likely to be adversely affected by watching a film such as this.

I am not in a position to suggest any measures which might have been taken to prevent this tragedy, or which might be taken to prevent a similar one in the future. Clearly, a free and open society requires that there be freedom of communication. On the other hand, I cannot help wondering what benefits society can derive from having such a mindlessly violent film as this generally available to be viewed by anyone, no matter how disturbed he or she may be. The potentially devastating effects can be seen in the events of 27 February.

I read that into the Hansard because we are told so often-and I was told during the debate on my private member's Bill-that the judgments that have been brought down and the police evidence we have been given are just circumstantial. They are excuses for crimes that have been committed. That is not how Judge Mathews has seen it. The Crown, the defence, the judge herself and the jury felt that that video, which is M-rated and available to all those aged 15 years and over, played a part in that very tragic crime-a crime that has destroyed the lives of a whole family.

I have spoken in this place so often regarding this sort of thing that people have become sick of hearing me. People have said that I am too tied up with this issue and too involved. I plead with honourable senators to read the judge's verdict for themselves. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) is in the chamber because I appeal to him, too, to let us do something-to play just a small part in something that so many of us believe may stop such a mindless and senseless crime being committed again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill, together with its companion bills, Supply Bill (No 2) 1991-92 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92, is a routine machinery measure. It seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing services of the Government during the period 1 July 1991 to 30 November 1991, by which date it is expected that the appropriation Bills, which will form part of the Budget for 1991-92, will have been enacted.

Supply Bill (No 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $12,062 million for the ordinary annual services of the Government. This is $1,364 million, or about 12.75 per cent, greater than the equivalent amounts provided in the Supply Act (No 1) 1990-91.
This increase reflects a combination of factors including:
* price and cost increases and the impact of exchange rate variations;

* the inclusion of those ordinary annual services of government items which appeared in Supply Bill (No. 2) in 1990-91 because they had not previously been included in the annual Appropriation Bills; and
* the full year effect of new and enhanced programs which have commenced since the introduction of the previous Supply Bill (No. 1).
Examples of these increases include :
Attorney-Generals
* $26 million for the first full year of operations of the Australian Securities Commission.
Community Services and Health

* $33 million for Residential Care for Older People principally from an increase in construction activity reflecting increased approvals on previous years of capital grants for construction of Aged Person Nursing Homes and Hostels.
* $120 million for Services for Families with Children as a result of 1990-91 Budget Policy changes, enhancements to child care relief and changes to the payment cycle.
Veterans' Affairs
* $38 million for Other Services reflecting a large increase in the demand for medical and hospital services for veterans.
Defence
* $288 million for Equipment and Stores flowing from increased payments for approved projects coming on stream and greater activity levels for existing equipment projects.
Employment, Education and Training

* $107 million for Special Employment, Education and Income Support reflecting Growth in Student Assistance programs (including Student Numbers, indexation of benefits and an additional payment in the Supply period in 1991-92 compared to 1990-91) as well as new measures (namely implementation of the Active Employment Strategy in JOBTRAIN and the March 12 initiatives in the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme.

* $28 million to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission largely reflecting the significant growth in Aboriginal programs between 1989-90 and 1990-91 on which the Supply estimates for the two years were based.
Industry Technology and Commerce

* $142 million for Other Services with the $143 million increased provision for National Interest payments by the Australian Trade Commission to the Australian Wheat Board in respect of Iraqi wheat debt default partially offset by net reductions in other items.
Social Security

* $69 million for Running Costs which includes provision for payments to the Australian Valuations Office and the Australian Government Health Service for which there was no Supply provision in 1990-91.
Treasury

* $56 million for Australian Bureau of Statistics Running Costs largely as a supplementation to take account of the peak in outlays in August 1991 associated with the 1991 census of Population and Housing

* $47 million for Australian Taxation Office Running Costs largely reflecting anticipated expenditure on the modernisation project, increased funding for the Child Support Agency and some `one-off' payments anticipated in the first half of the year.

I wish to emphasise that this Bill seeks interim provision only for approved ongoing policies of the Government. It does not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1991-92 Budget context, for which provision will be sought in the Appropriation Bills.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Motion
Motion (by Senator Tate)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1991-92, the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1991-92 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Supply Bill (No. 1) 1991-92, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1991-92 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92 are essentially routine machinery Bills. They seek interim appropriations to enable the Government, in terms of its ongoing services as well as its expenditure on capital works and services and the continued operation of the parliamentary departments, to be funded during the period from 1 July 1991 to 30 November 1991, by which date it is expected that the Appropriation Bills that form part of the Budget for 1991-92 will have been enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $12.1 billion for the ordinary annual services of the Government. Supply Bill (No. 2) seeks interim appropriations totalling $3.4 billion for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory and certain other services for the period 1 July 1991 to 30 November 1991, and the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill seeks interim appropriations for the ongoing requirements of the parliamentary departments during the same five-month period.

As pointed out in the second reading speech, these Bills seek interim provision only for approved ongoing policies of the Government. They do not anticipate decisions to be taken in the 1991-92 Budget context, for which provision will be sought in the Appropriation Bills. In other words, these are Bills to guarantee or to provide funding, or supply in the technical jargon, for the continued operation of the Government for the first five months of the next financial year until the Budget Bills, which contain the appropriations for the whole of the financial year, are passed. They then subsume these Supply Bills.

There is no doubt that these Supply Bills are being debated, and the forthcoming Budget will be debated, in a period during which Australia is facing the most severe and protracted recession in the last 60 years. There is no doubt that this recession has been deliberately engineered, to use the words of the former discredited Treasurer, by the Government. There is no doubt at all that the Government has failed the people of Australia in its management of this nation, and particularly the economy. By any test it has made a mess of the economy and of countless thousands of people's lives. What we cannot be sure of is whether the Government knew what it was doing and simply lied about it or whether it was so incompetent that it lost control of economic management and just stood back and let the disaster happen.

Last year when for month after month I and my colleagues on this side of the chamber pointed out the errors of policy being committed by the Government, the Government, with the ignorance and arrogance personified in the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, denied that anything was wrong or even could go wrong. Remember the self-justification, the superior knowledge and the scoffing at any question of the direction of economic policy. Remember the then Treasurer's assurance at the time of the 1989 Budget when he said:
As a result of the Government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent level of spending without a recession and with its economy and social structure improving.

How wrong he was then; how deluded the Government was. On the other hand, was it all a big cover-up? Did the Government know precisely what was going to happen? We now know that, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) lied to the people of Australia about the succession to the Prime Ministership, so the Government lied to the people of Australia about the recession. On 22 March last year, two days before the 1990 election, the Prime Minister said, `There is no need to fear a recession in any sense'. On precisely the same day, the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, told the people of Australia that there would not be a recession because the Government would not let the recession happen.

If anyone should be in any doubt about the integrity of the Labor so-called leader- ship team, the erstwhile Treasurer followed that lie with the shameful admission on 30 November last, `I knew there had to be one'-that is, a recession- `but I didn't want to tell you'. He is the sort of person and that is the sort of approach that, regrettably, gives politicians in this nation a very bad name.

Having denied the clearly looming recession for so long, when reality eventually overtook the Government and it knew it could not deceive the people of Australia any longer-at least on that point-the discredited former Treasurer continued the lie with the line that this was the recession that we had to have. He was wrong then, and the Government was wrong.

We did not have to face this recession; it was avoidable. The fact is that the Government engineered the recession because it was incapable of moving on a number of policy fronts. To do so would have involved offending the trade union bosses and other vested interest groups to which this leaderless Government is beholden. In fear of doing anything of which its bagmen may disapprove, the Government is neutered now in what it can say and do. It is not allowed to admit that the overriding and fundamental economic problem faced by Australia is low growth due to poor productivity and that that in turn is an inevitable outcome of massive and excessive constraints on the freedom of individuals and companies to invest and contract according to their commercial judgment.

Rather than engineer a recession to choke off demand-and that is what the Government did-it would have been far better simply to adopt the policies of the Opposition and actually do something effective about the underlying causes of the economic malaise. Those underlying causes have prevented the productivity of this country from growing in the way that our skills and resources should allow us to do.

That option is still available but only if the Government can jettison its ideological baggage and escape from the influence of union bosses and selected mates. The required changes in policy include scrapping the accord and allowing employers and employees to reach genuine agreements in each enterprise without outside interference-something which is impossible under the present regime.

We should be allowing open competition, thereby achieving real and lasting reform in telecommunications, the waterfront, shipping and other transport areas. We should be reforming the tax system so as to reduce business costs and encourage savings and investment through the effects of a broad-based goods and services tax and through lower income tax rates, particularly on middle income earners who have been taxed out of existence by this Government.

We should be implementing real reform and enduring efficiencies in Federal-State relations. We should be demonstrating our commitment to investment, growth and employment. In this context, nothing could provide a clearer signal of intent than approval of exploration and mining at Coronation Hill. There is a total in- ability on the part of the Government to take a decision. The Government has been locked in all day on this matter-I understand that it is still locked in.

These changes have to be made if Australia is ever going to recover and achieve the rates of economic growth which are necessary to avoid the cruel wastage due to unemployment and to generate the income required to climb out of the mountain of debt into which this irresponsible Government, through its policies, has plunged us.

I think it is instructive for all, including members of the Government, who thus far have proved themselves incapable of learning, to look at the results of the discredited attempt to rein back demand and suppress growth by imposing excessively high interest rates and throwing people out of work. The data speak for themselves.

Company profits collapsed by a massive 29 per cent in the March quarter of this year. The profit share of gross domestic product now stands at the lowest rate for any quarter since September 1986. The situation there is even worse than the statistics suggest, because companies with fewer than 30 employees are not reported upon in the company profit survey.

As most of us know, many small businesses are in a disastrous loss situation. There are 53 per cent more bankruptcies than a year ago. The household savings ratio, a major source of investment funds, has collapsed to a record low of 4 per cent. As a result of the drop in profits, dried up savings and lack of investor confidence in the Hawke Government, new capital expenditure has crashed to a level 12 per cent lower than a year ago, and the expectation is for worse to come.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of the outlook for new capital expenditure in 1991-92 shows that a further fall of 16 per cent is anticipated. Building approvals in April were 26 per cent lower than the year before. Motor vehicle registrations collapsed by 24 per cent in the year to April.

Consistent with the mess that the Government has made of the economy, gross domestic product is flat or negative depending on the measure used. Taking account of movements in the terms of trade, the March quarter gross domestic product was down 0.5 per cent, and that was the fifth quarter of nil or negative growth in the last six quarters. As I said at the outset, that is the most protracted period of recession that this country has had in 60 years. Gross national spending in the March quarter was 5 per cent less in real terms than a year ago. That is a clear indication of the extent to which confidence has been eroded.

Let us look at the cruel hard figures of employment and unemployment. Unemployment has increased by 258,600 people or 47 per cent in the year to May. On the trend estimate, which puts the data in their longer term perspective, a total of 818,800 people are now out of work and the trend unemployment rate stands at a record 9.6 per cent. There could be no clearer indictment of the Government's failed policies than that. The scandal of youth unemployment is even worse. The Government is mesmerised with more important issues in its view, such as the ongoing leadership crisis. The trend series shows youth unemployment at a catastrophic 27 per cent. In many areas of Australia the youth unemployment rate is up around the 40 per cent mark, but for Australia as a whole the average is 27 per cent.

The record is the same when one looks at the number of people on unemployment benefits. Unemployment benefit recipients increased by 31,000 in May to a total of 647,414. The number of people on unemployment benefit in Australia at present is 242,000 higher than a year ago-an increase of 60 per cent. What a monument to this so-called Labor Government.

Quite apart from the human tragedy of this engineered recession, which is the real tragedy, the human tragedy, the Government has created massive problems for itself in framing the coming Budget. The massive fall in company profits in 1990-91 will be reflected in a corresponding fall in company tax payments in the forthcoming year, 1991-92. That significant fall in revenue will be exacerbated by lower personal income tax receipts as an outcome of reduced employment; lower sales tax and other indirect tax receipts because of depressed domestic demand; increased expenditure arising from the blow-out in unemployment; and growing but nonetheless absurd demands from Labor's left for new ways to spend money.

So the Government faces an extremely difficult task in formulating a responsible Budget. The economic climate substantially limits the Government's options and it now has to take account of the greatly increased influence of its left wing and, in particular, the existence of a left wing Deputy Prime Minister who delights in spending up big with other people's money. In this year alone the Budget surplus has slipped from the original forecast of $8.1 billion to an estimated $2 billion, and that could well still prove to be conservative.

The demand for public sector borrowings on capital markets in this year, 1991, now looks set to be $7.2 billion, which is $5 billion or thereabouts more than the figure in 1989-90. For 1991-92, the forthcoming year, estimates by the very respected economics consultancy, Access Economics Pty Ltd, have put the public sector borrowing requirement as likely to be some $14.6 billion. That is 3 1/2 per cent or thereabouts of gross domestic product.

So the outlook is therefore one of a return to the large public sector borrowings of the mid-1980s and the high interest rates which come as a result of the competition for funds. If there is any recovery in the private sector of the economy in the course of the forthcoming financial year, 1991-92, the increased demand for funds by the private sector will run slap bang into this massive borrowing requirement that the public sector is almost certain to impose on the market. There is only one way that that leads in terms of interest rate direction, and that is further upwards, adding to a real interest rate in Australia which is still extremely high by world standards. So the outlook on the fiscal front for the Government over the next 12 months is extremely difficult. The implications of that for the private sector are increasingly serious.

As I say, this situation has been deliberately created by grossly incompetent mismanagement on the part of the Government over several years. If one looks at the fundamentals of the Australian economy and compares today with the situation that the Government inherited in 1983-and it was a very difficult situation then because of the world recession that had occurred at that time; bearing in mind that the slump in the Australian economy in the last couple of years has been at a time of continuing world increase in economic activity-on virtually every fundamental, the Australian economy is in disastrously worse shape now than it was then.

Many things can, should and need to be done to correct that situation. The worst thing that can happen in this country is that we come to believe that the problems we have today are so entrenched that we cannot do anything about them. That is the whole spirit of defeatism. As soon as we have a spirit of defeatism, that becomes self-feeding. We are a very resourceful and a very rich, skilled and talented nation. We have fantastic opportunities for the future, but the question of whether those opportunities will be grasped is entirely in our own hands. The longer it takes us to start on the path of putting into place the basic policies needed to correct the existing situation and put Australia on to a dynamic, sustainable growth path, the more difficult it will be to ever get back onto that path.

There are many things we can and should be doing. The first thing we should be doing is genuinely committing ourselves to price stability. The Government talks about near enough being good enough-that if we get 3, 4 or 5 per cent inflation, that is okay. The whole impression the Government gives us is that if we can get down to 4 per cent that is pretty good. Four per cent is still very high by international standards over time. We should be prepared to commit ourselves as a nation to genuine price stability. That means an inflation rate of something of the order of zero to 2 per cent. The Treasurer has ridiculed the Opposition for claiming that that is a reasonable goal to aim for. If the Government will not aim at a goal like that, it will never get the price stability that this nation needs.

The second area of a structural type we need to address is Commonwealth-State financial relations. We have to rebuild the financial relations between the Commonwealth and the States. It is a very difficult area. It also involves delegating functions or dividing up the functions between all three levels of government-Commonwealth, State and local-and ensuring that at each level there are the appropriate taxing powers to fund the expenditures those governments are expected to meet. This is a very difficult task. We have now had this imbalance for 50 years plus between the spending and revenue raising responsibilities and capacities of the Commonwealth on the one hand and the State and local governments on the other. It is a task which ought to be occupying our time and which will occupy our time inevitably during the 1990s. It is probably the most important source of micro-economic reform that we could possibly embark upon, and I think that the 1990s is, and certainly should be, the decade of meaningful and lasting reform of Commonwealth-State relations.

We should be looking much more at decisive action in the area of labour market reform. There is no alternative but to move to workplace agreements, to look at the possibility of enterprise-based agreements at each workplace. To do that, we have to change the law. The Government is totally unprepared to change the law in that area. The Opposition is committed to doing so.

We have to look at a major reform of the taxation system-again, an area which will not be easy to tackle but an area where reform must be tackled head on. An essential part of the tax reform package which has to be put into place is the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax. We must also have lower personal tax rates, significant cuts in personal tax, and increased incentives to save as well as to work. It can be done, and under a coalition government it will be done.

We have to look at the whole of the so-called infrastructure area-that is, looking at all the cost disadvantages to business, whether it is the waterfront, shipping, land transport, air transport, telecommunications, power generation or the like. That is what infrastructure means. Reform in that area means making those industries more efficient, more competitive and less costly. Those industries are the backbone of, and the wheels which turn, all other productive activities.

We need to cut back on the continuing growth in government expenditure. We need to look realistically and full-bloodedly at the area of privatisation of government enterprises-not just the 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank, a bit here and a bit there, which seems to be this Government's program of privatisation. That is mickey mouse privatisation in every sense of the word.

Those are the sorts of things we have to tackle in this country. They are very important issues-vitally important in the context of looking at Bills such as the Supply Bills that are with us today. Even though they are essentially only machinery Bills, they are all about the process of government and economic planning and economic policy. As we move from now through to the next Budget and to the consideration of economic policy in the build-up to the Budget and its aftermath, as I said earlier, we need to be concentrating all our efforts and all our activities on getting the fundamentals right in this country. Economic policy is a fundamental part and Budget policy is an essential element of doing that.

The Opposition is not opposing these Bills-they are traditional machinery Bills-but in considering them the Government does deserve, quite rightly, to stand indicted for the dreadful economic mess and the enormous human hardship that its failed policies have caused.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —This second reading debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1991-92, Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991-92 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1991-92 in the Senate provides me with an opportunity to consider at some length alternative regimes of taxing and spending in Australia. If we were to look at the way in which taxation totally permeates the economy, we would find that virtually every economic decision, including options to produce, consume, save and invest, is influenced by income tax and expenditure taxes. Taxation impacts upon incentives of all households and firms-large and small alike-and is a dominant influence on national production and income.

SPEECH.PARA: It is sobering indeed to consider that total taxation receipts are equivalent to almost one-third of national income. The threshold question, therefore, is a simple one: what, if anything, is wrong with the current level and mix of taxation? The answer is that the highly distorting set of incentives that flow from the current taxation arrangements is a significant source of foregone national productivity and income, so much so that genuine taxation reform has the capacity to increase national income to ordinary Australians by the equivalent of several percentage points of gross domestic product.

Income tax accounts for 70 per cent of Commonwealth taxation receipts. Underlying the current income tax arrangements are a number of distorting effects on incentives due to differences in the specific form of taxation, the measurement of taxable income and the tax rates themselves. We are said to have a mongrel income tax system, given that it is neither homogenous nor consistent. Taxes on goods and services amount to less than 30 per cent of Commonwealth taxation. The broad range of taxes includes the ramshackle wholesale sales tax, excise taxes and import duties. It is my intention to focus on the shortcomings of the wholesale sales tax, in particular, and to indicate some of the alternatives that are offered by the coalition to produce a better taxation system.

The coalition is stout in its resolve to introduce a broad-based goods and services tax. I say this as one who has not come as a latter day convert to the concept. It is a concept that I have believed in and one that has needed to be implemented for over a decade. But let us be intellectually honest about the taxation debate in this country. It is not simply about whether we should have a consumption tax, because we already have a consumption tax and it is the Government's own secret tax-the GST or goods and services tax, otherwise known as the wholesale sales tax. Let us have no more scaremongering from the Government about the introduction of a consumption tax because we already have one. It is unfair, unbalanced and mindless in its application, and it distorts income investment and the way that people decide to spend their after-tax dollar.

The fact remains that we have an expenditure tax in the form of the wholesale sales tax and it remains for the Government to try to argue for its retention, as distinct from our abolishing it and implementing a system of tax reform which will bring about a better and fairer form of taxation. Rarely have I heard a government senator in this place rise to defend the wholesale sales tax. That is because the Government knows just as well as we do that a significant loss of national income is brought about by the uneven pattern of effective rates of taxation levied by that wholesale sales tax.

By artificially distorting production and consumption there is a misallocation of resources to less than optimal production use. It has been estimated by the Business Council of Australia that replacing the wholesale sales tax with a broad-based consumption tax would generate productivity gains exceeding the equivalent of half a percentage point of gross domestic product.

Let us look at the weaknesses of the tax that I am attacking. The wholesale sales tax base is a very narrow one, and in many cases it is ill-defined. There is a most arbitrary pattern of exemptions and an ambiguity in the definition of the point and value of sale in assessing the tax liability. But, most importantly, the relative incidence of the wholesale sales tax falls quite unfairly on business. Only 37 per cent of the total incidence of the tax falls upon the final consumer, while the remainder falls upon the purchase of business inputs or investment goods. As a consequence of this, the tax acts as a tax on exports and on the production of import substitutes.

The most obvious drawback of the tax is brought about by the multiple tax rates. In addition to the different tax rates, there are many more categories of different effective rates of tax due not only to the exemption of services but also to the input taxing component and the associated transfer of the tax forward to buyers. These different effective rates greatly distort household purchasing decisions.

Consider, for instance, the final consumption expenditure of an ordinary household: housing, furniture and appliances are taxed at an effective rate more than double that of the tax on recreational items. The result is relative overconsumption of recreation items as compared with goods such as housing and those other items I mentioned. But, even more importantly, it acts as an incentive to spend and not to save.

We have heard the examples of the in- equities, if not absurdities, that have been brought about by the different rates of wholesale sales tax. I think it is well to re-examine some of those absurdities. For instance, caviar and oysters are tax-free, but chocolate biscuits and ice cream have a tax of 10 per cent. On mineral water no tax is paid, but if one's taste is for Coca-Cola 10 per cent is paid. Aeroplane flights are exempt, but a poor family, in comparative terms, wanting to have a holiday in a caravan pays 20 per cent tax. No tax is paid on a taxi ride, but a person who wants to ride a bicycle to save some money will pay a 20 per cent tax. A piece of art is tax-free, while photographic equipment carries a 30 per cent tax.

So no matter how the Government attempts to tamper with the wholesale sales tax, as it did in the 12 March statement, the tax is fundamentally flawed. Inevitably, such a tax will either involve some inflation of business inputs or will be imposed on a very narrow base. So long as there remains some taxation of business inputs, there will remain distortions to production decisions. The alternative is to throw out the current wholesale sales tax and introduce a broad-based consumption tax.

The replacement of the wholesale sales tax with a goods and services tax will be advantageous in a number of ways, but honourable senators should remember that our proposition is to introduce the tax as part of overall tax reform-other elements will be considered as well. It is certainly not the imposition of a new tax: it is part of an overall reform which will result in the lessening of tax.

There will be a reduction in the distorting effects of taxing business inputs, leading to greater neutrality in the choices of production methods and product mixes ultimately leading to greater productivity. There will be a more neutral and less distorting pattern of effective tax rates on the goods and services consumed by households. Again this would lead to more neutral consumption decisions, thus increasing household welfare.

In spite of perhaps a once-off price shock, which has been the experience in other countries, there will be little effect on the underlying inflation rate. Looking at the New Zealand experience, the initial inflationary impact disappeared in four quarters. Importantly, there would be a reduction in the complexity of indirect tax, which would engender greater certainty into the decision making process of households and firms.

The impact of a goods and services tax on aggregated savings, as I mentioned before, is an important consideration. Consider the coalition package, which entails lower income tax rates, reduced government expenditure, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, which is the Government's own GST-the Government's secret tax-and the introduction of a goods and services tax.

Such a change in the tax mix will increase the incentive to allocate income to saving and future consumption rather than current consumption. There is an unambiguous substitution effect away from consumption and towards saving. In addition, there is an added incentive to save which is brought about by increasing the after-tax return on savings due to lower income tax rates. This in turn will reduce the cost of future consumption relative to that of current consumption.

I remind those who choose to scaremonger about the introduction of a goods and services tax of the coalition's commitment to introduce an explicit compensation package. We have never sought to deny that a tax mix change, as I have outlined, will cause some households to experience a loss of real disposable income and real purchasing power. The notion of a compensation package is intended to offset the loss of real purchasing power associated with a net increase in the taxation of goods and services tax.

I do not seek to provide answers at this time to the details of that package, which will be put forward by the Opposition at the time chosen by Mr Peter Reith, but it is relevant to examine the suggestions put forward by the Business Council of Australia, which has done a splendid analysis that is worth looking at. In general terms, the Business Council of Australia proposed that the three adjustments to be made were as follows: firstly, an increase in social security rates by the one-off increase in price multiplied by a scaling factor which recognises consumption outlays as a percentage of social security receipts; secondly, an increase in the tax-free threshold such that disposable income is increased to maintain real purchasing power of income at the new threshold level; and, thirdly, reductions in marginal tax rates to maintain the real purchasing power of consumption outlays from income in each tax bracket.

`The choice of which type of broad-based consumption tax is an important one for the Opposition to consider', wrote the Business Council of Australia, and indeed it is. It is relatively simple to dismiss out of hand wholesale sales taxes, turnover taxes and manufacturers taxes due to relative inefficiency and administrative flaws. The choice, therefore, is between a retail sales tax on the one hand-as used in the United States-and on the other hand a value-added or goods and services tax.

Overseas experience strongly favours a multistage goods and services tax above a retail sales tax. The reasons for that are that, firstly, the tax base for a GST is much larger than the retail sales tax. The importance of this is that a broad base means that one is given an aggregate revenue that can be collected at a lower tax rate than would be the case with a narrow base. Secondly, the goods and services tax is more successful in exempting business inputs from the indirect tax than is the retail sales tax. Similarly, the goods and services tax causes less distortion to production and consumption decisions. Lastly, the goods and services tax is a superior weapon against tax evasion and avoidance. This again has been borne out by the New Zealand experience.

Of the 24 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, 21 have a multistage broad-based consumption tax. The New Zealand goods and services tax provides a worthy model for Australia to consider. Indeed, I had the recent fortune, as did several of my colleagues, to visit New Zealand to investigate its goods and services tax in operation.

Without providing any detail of how the coalition's goods and services tax will operate after the next election, it is worthwhile having a look at how the New Zealand GST would apply in Australia. Firstly, all business enterprises above a minimum size could be registered with the Australian Taxation Office and provided with a GST number. The tax could be calculated using a credit offset system which would take a measure of taxable sales, less credits for tax paid on purchase inputs, with exports being rated as exempt or, indeed, zero rated.

Net tax could then be remitted to the Government at different periods, depending upon the size of the business, so as not to disadvantage small firms. In this way, smaller businesses could be compensated for the higher per dollar compliance costs. A hybrid system of allowing both methods was introduced by New Zealand in its review process. In implementing the tax, it is important to announce the broad parameters of that tax in advance and to provide consultative mechanisms to establish and develop details within the constraints of those parameters. Certainty is important. In New Zealand I was impressed to see material used in the community education and promotion campaign for the tax, which would be essential in minimising uncertainty and transition costs while the tax was being introduced. I cannot stress enough how important certainty and predictability are.

I do not seek to make any predictions as to the breadth of the base which will be caught by the GST under a Hewson government, except to make the in-principle comment that, the broader the base and the fewer the exemptions, the more efficient and relatively less distortional the tax will be. The benefits of replacing the current wholesale sales tax with a broad-based goods and services tax are considerable and could increase national income by 0.5 per cent. This puts this reform in the league of the potential benefits to the national income brought about by the micro-economic reform of transport and communications.
It is worthy to consider the comments of Prime Minister in waiting Mr Keating on the necessity to introduce that broad-based sales tax which he believed in in 1985. At the tax summit he said:

If we fail to approach tax reform constructively we have failed not just ourselves, but the nation generally. The spoilers in any such process will have much to answer for in condemning this and the next generation of Australians to the blight-the latent unfairness and gross inefficiency-of our current tax regime.

I thus ask the question: what has changed since 1985? The answer is that the boom times have gone. In the depths of recession we are now in far greater need of tax reform than existed at the time of the tax summit. Just as the former Treasurer recognised the requirement to introduce a broad-based consumption tax in 1985, that same need remains with us today. The Opposition is committed to taxation reform; it is the Government which will have to argue the case for the retention of the current unfair, unjust and inequitable system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION COMMISSION BILL 1991AUSTRALIAN WOOL CORPORATION BILL 1991PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1991WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1991AUSTRALIAN WOOL INDUSTRY COUNCIL BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 and 17 June, on motions by Senator Cook and Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating nine separate pieces of legislation within the wool package, including the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991 and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: This package of Bills restructures the wool industry following the removal of the reserve price scheme and the tabling in April 1991 of the report of the Vines Committee of Inquiry into the Wool Industry and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council. Tonight I intend to debate the technicalities of the legislation. I will leave the industry perspective to my Opposition colleagues, Senators Archer, Bjelke-Petersen, Brownhill, Boswell, Chapman, Crane, Knowles, Panizza and Walters.

Following the collapse of the reserve price scheme, the Government enacted legislation to take the industry through to 30 June this year and until it received the Vines report on the future marketing of wool. Following the Vines report, the Government decided to establish the following bodies: the Wool Realisation Commission, which will be responsible for the disposal of the wool stockpile and the assets of the Australian Wool Corporation; a restructured Australian Wool Corporation, which will be responsible for promotion, standards and industry training; the Wool Industry Research and Development Corporation, which will be responsible for research and development; and the Wool Industry Council, which will consist of all sectors of the industry and which will be used by Government as its advisory body rather than the Wool Council of Australia.

It is interesting to reflect on the present situation. Since the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, released the debt repayment schedule on 30 April, the wool market has improved, less wool than predicted has been offered for sale in the latter part of this season and interest rates have fallen. All of this has resulted in the debt being reduced to $2.63 billion, almost the $2.559 billion that the Government expected at the end of 1992-93. Importantly, the Minister admitted in his second reading speech:
. . . a 15 per cent . . . significant numbers of specialist wool growers will have no farm cash operating surplus in 1991-92.
He said further:
In practice, the effect of the difference on farm cash operating surplus for the average grower is in the order of hundreds of dollars, not thousands.

However, when farmers are facing negative incomes, hundreds of dollars are important and the actual difference is actually in thousands of dollars. The Minister's arithmetic is shonky. For example, a producer with 5,000 sheep selling wool at 450c a kilogram will pay $10,125 with a 15 per cent tax but only $6,750 on a 10 per cent wool tax. That is a difference of $3,375, which is enough at least to put food on the table for a year.

Because of the negative cash flows expected by growers, they need the lowest possible levy which can be sustained in a disciplined repayment schedule by the maximum amount of growers to ensure full payment of the debt. The Wool Corporation has the ability to borrow at lower rates of interest than the woolgrower. For example, the Australian Wool Corporation borrows at interest rates of 10.75 per cent, while the farmers are borrowing at interest rates of 18 per cent. Therefore, it is better to maintain a lower levy.

The Australian Wool Corporation figures treat the asset sales inadequately. A $120m transfer to debt servicing would almost cover the five per cent difference between the so-called need for a 15 per cent levy and a more appropriate 10 per cent levy. With this in mind, the Opposition will certainly not be supporting a 15 per cent levy. A 10 per cent levy is clearly all that is necessary. I seek leave to incorporate a soundly based economic table of options in Hansard to substantiate our position.
Leave granted.
