They are, firstly, that the Australian Wool Corporation can borrow at the long term bond rate of 10.75 per cent; secondly, 25 million kilograms can be released from the stockpile next year without a significant impact on price; thirdly, the cost of storing the stockpile and of running the Australian Wool Corporation or its replacement organisations is $45m a year; fourthly, the Australian Wool Corporation or its replacement organisation is committed to expenditure in 1991-92 of $187m on promotion and $54m on research and development; and, fifthly, unless otherwise noted, the average price to prevail in 1991-92 is 295c per kilogram or 447c per kilogram clean, the bottom of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics range of price forecasts of 450c to 550c clean.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant point for woolgrowers centres on asset sales. It is the crux of the 10 per cent levy versus the 15 per cent levy. It is a question of what level of asset sales are reasonable from the Wool Corporation and where receipts from those sales should be applied. In supporting the unsustainable and unnecessarily high figure of 15 per cent, the Government is claiming that it can only sell $40m of the $280m to $300m of assets of the Wool Corporation in the next financial year.

We have repeated indications that $120m is a quite reasonable figure in the first year and in the second year. If the Government wants to maintain that sort of situation on the basis on which it is operating, it should be honest and state how many years it will take for the whole debt to be removed. Will it be four or five years? It will certainly be far shorter than the seven years which the Government originally proposed.

The Government is once again showing its lack of sympathy and lack of understanding for the problems facing woolgrowers. What does it matter if it takes one or two years more to pay the whole debt off if the viability of Australia's woolgrowers is maintained? If there were a maximum levy of 10 per cent, I believe that it would put sensible pressure on the Wool Corporation and the Wool Realisation Commission to perform.

The Australian Wool Corporation should be selling off its assets-in particular, those assets, stores and warehouses that are not currently holding any wool. Those premises would certainly be serving commercial purposes with good returns. It would therefore be a good time to sell them. If there are no returns, the loss to the wool industry from selling $120m worth of assets at the present time, as against what could be obtained on a maximum market, is minimal compared with the far greater capital and farm losses for thousands of Australian farmers who would be sold up because of that significant difference between the 10 per cent and 15 per cent cost levy. The Government's heartlessness is transparent.

If we compare the choice of selling the Wool Corporation assets with farmers selling their hard-earned assets in the form of individual farms, anyone with any sympathy at all for this great Australian industry will realise the implications for the Australian economy. As more people enter the unemployment queues there will be a greater burden on ordinary Australian taxpayers and it will do nothing to aid the industry to get back on its feet-to say nothing of the family tragedy. There must be a greater sale of assets from the Wool Corporation than the assets sales of farmers' individual properties. With this in mind, I wish to move a second reading amendment to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991. I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) regrets the Government's unnecessary decision to create a Wool Realisation Commission separate from the Australian Wool Corporation;

(b) regrets the Government's failure to provide some certainty in the wool market by not implementing an orderly schedule, with appropriate legislative authority, for releasing specified quantities of wool from the Australian Wool Corporation's stockpile; and
(c) calls on the Government to support a properly managed industry funded flock reduction scheme to be introduced if and when the industry agrees such a scheme is necessary''.

This amendment reaffirms the Opposition policy towards a predictable and accountable release from the stockpile on a predetermined volume basis which we believe is the best method. We believe it was unnecessary to create another body by separating the Australian Wool Corporation from the wool realisation aspects. I also seek leave to move a further amendment to the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate calls on the Government to have the Industry Commission conduct a full and comprehensive inquiry into the level and methods of wool promotion, so as to help ensure that Australian wool growers are receiving full value for their contributions''.

The Opposition intends to move further technical amendments during other stages of this package of Bills. The amendments to be moved in relation to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991 and the Australian Wool Corporation Bill involve a number of amendments to the audit provisions of both the Realisation Commission and the Wool Corporation. I will quote from the Auditor-General's Report No. 35 1990-91 concerning the potential erosion of accountability to the Parliament which was tabled yesterday in the Senate. In it the Auditor-General states:
I am very concerned that a continuing effort to weaken the Parliament's role in the scrutiny and reporting on the activities of all public-sector entities appears to be gaining strength.

In the early hours of 31 May 1991, without consultation with the ANAO, the above Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives which I believe could tilt the balance against Parliamentary scrutiny of public-sector entities.

This action was despite the Government's decision that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities announced in a statement by the Government on 6 December 1990 in response to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' examination of the ANAO and the Sheridan Review.
The Auditor-General goes on to say:

It is surprising that a Bill such as that proposing the creation of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, with its significant cost implications for the taxpayer, should even be contemplated as suitable for potential choice of private auditor because of `special circumstances'.
Further to this, the Auditor-General says:

If parliamentary democracy is to have any meaning, no `special circumstances dictate' any further erosion from Parliament's right to be informed. Parliament (and the public) have a right to know what has been done with power and/or taxpayers' resources granted or guaranteed to any group. This right will be undermined if the current attempt to weaken the audit mandate of the Auditor-General succeeds.

This matter has already attracted the attention yesterday of my colleagues Senator Crane, Senator Bishop, Senator Short and Senator Watson. The key to whether the decision represents a real restoration of mandate to the Auditor-General depends on the exemptions allowed. These Bills do nothing to reassure the Parliament in this regard if the potential is seen by the Government for an exemption in a Bill dealing with $2.7 billion of debt and a 4.7 billion bale stockpile shouldered by the taxpayer. The Opposition strongly supports the Auditor-General's most valuable and valid contribution to the debate on this legislation and, therefore, will be moving amendments at the committee stage.

At this stage I mention some points regarding the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991, which was introduced into the Senate only yesterday afternoon. This Bill in its original form attracted a number of reservations, made clear to the Opposition by the Cattle Council of Australia, the Australian Dairy Industry Council and the National Farmers Federation, regarding the effect on their respective commodity groups, which were not under consideration or debated in this wool industry package. Their concern centred on the fact that the original legislation-then entitled the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill 1991-was an umbrella piece of legislation which set up industry councils by regulation rather than by legislation.

The Opposition is pleased that the Government has taken up the concerns of the Opposition and industry in relation to this matter and has introduced the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991 for the wool industry specifically. For this reason, the Opposition will be supporting this Bill with, again, a minor technical amendment.

I indicate to the Senate that the package of amendments proposed by the Opposition will contain approximately 23 or 24 amendments. It is indicative that in legislation of this nature we have to again do the Government's work in so many areas that are of a technical-and should be-professional and political expertise area. It is indeed unfortunate, even given the haste with which we are being asked to consider this legislation, that it is incumbent upon the Opposition to pick up and do the Government's dirty work.

I also note with some considerable concern that the list of speakers on this particular package of legislation, other than the Minister who will obviously speak in reply at the end, includes only one other senator from the Government-from the Australian Labor Party. I pay credit to the fact that Senator West will be speaking on behalf of the Government. It will be very interesting to listen to her comments and to fathom the depth of understanding and, hopefully, the reasons why her colleagues are not backing her up with their support in this chamber. It is very patronising that we can expect only a nominal reply from the Minister at the end of such an important piece of legislation that requires such extensive amendment and consideration.

I note that on our side of the chamber there will be some 13 speakers, many of whom have a very close personal involvement in the issue. They will obviously be reflecting the important values, important concerns and compassion of the people of Australia who are so closely aligned to this tragedy which the Labor Government has induced for so many of us. Therefore, it will be very interesting to listen to the debate and also to participate in the debate on the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just waffling. Why don't you get down to the substance of the Bill instead of how many Bills there are?

—It is very interesting to note the flamboyant and cavalier manner of the Minister at the table with regard to this legislation. It is obvious, from the debates of Federal Cabinet over the last couple of years-and even from the other important resources debate that is going on today with regard to Coronation Hill-that the Government cannot reach conclusions, cannot make decisions--
—What do you think I am sitting here for?

—The Minister is probably sitting here because he is bored to death with what is going on in the Cabinet room where, after four or five hours, his Government cannot reach a conclusion. We are talking about the lives of thousands of Australian people, their economy and their farms, and the wider network of the rural and remote parts of Australia that depend to such a great degree on the important wool industry of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills-the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991 and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991-that we are debating in the last week of the autumn session of parliament is of critical importance to the future of not only woolgrowers but also all Australians. I support Senator Tambling in leading the Opposition in the debate tonight on these very important Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The saga that has been the history of the wool industry in this country over the past few years is a sorry one. The saga of legislation and its passage through this Parliament is no less shameful. Wool has long been recognised as this country's single most important product. The one commodity that we can produce better than anyone else in the world has been treated like an old dog.

We are debating a package of no fewer than nine Bills, eight of which the House of Representatives debated under the threat of guillotine. The legislation has, quite rightly, been called `last minute'. Given that changes to the industry must take effect on 1 July, we are once again experiencing this last, mad dash to the line-just as we did last year. It is legislation by intimidation. It is no way for this Parliament in this country to be treating our single most important industry.

For all our haste last year, the wool industry was no better off. When are we going to learn that legislation written and debated in haste will be repented at leisure-except that it will not be we who directly suffer the consequences of this Government getting it wrong yet again, it is the woolgrowers who suffer directly and immediately. They suffered when the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy interfered in their industry last year. They were told that they had to make tough decisions, accept the umpire's ruling, shoot their sheep, reduce their flock numbers and adjust to the fact that overnight their income was to be halved.

To the industry's credit, it bit the bullet. Woolgrowers lost the floor price, shot their sheep and got on with the business of making a living without street marches and without going on strike. That is very different from the other side of industry and some people in the trade union movement where the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) comes from.

It is a great pity that the Opposition's proposals for a properly organised slaughter scheme were not adopted. I believe that the industry today would be in a far stronger position had those proposals been accepted some time ago. But retrospective navel gazing is of no value to anyone, especially at the moment. Having said that, I do not in any way wish to underplay the very serious situation of the wool industry and the very difficult decisions that must be made in the future. Not only are there problems of disposal of the stockpile and repayment of the $2.63 billion debt, there is also the future marketing of wool to consider. The Government now is proposing that the industry be taxed to a level of 15 per cent to assist in that debt recovery. That is fine. But have the people on the Government side bothered to consult the industry as to its ability to pay that tax? I think not.

Throughout the whole of this debate on the wool industry woolgrowers have been the last to be considered. If the Labor Government could prise itself away from playing follow the leader for five minutes and concentrate on the real problems-and I include the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and his departmental minions-it would come to the realisation that when it reduces people's incomes by 30 to 50 per cent, increases their costs and restricts their production, it also reduces their ability to pay those taxes. Nowhere has the Government satisfactorily explained how growers will be able to afford to pay the 15 per cent tax.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy admitted in his second reading speech that at 15 per cent a significant number of specialist woolgrowers will have no farm cash operating surplus in 1991-92. He further said that, in practice, the effect of the difference on farm cash operating surplus for the average grower is in the order of hundreds of dollars and not thousands. However, I ask my fellow senators: when farmers are facing negative incomes, hundreds of dollars are important-and the actual difference is in the thousands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank Senator Walters. She understands the problem. I am afraid people on the other side of the House do not. For example, a producer with 5,000 sheep, selling wool at 450c a kilogram, will pay $10,125 with a 15 per cent tax but only $6,750 with a 10 per cent wool tax. That is a difference of $3,375-enough at least to put food on the table for quite some time. A 10,000-sheep farmer would pay $20,250 with a 15 per cent tax and only $13,500 with a 10 per cent tax. At 500c a kilogram, the tax on 5,000 sheep would be $11,250 at 15 per cent but only $7,500 on 10 per cent-a difference of $3,750. For 10,000 sheep the difference would be $7,500. I believe that this has to be taken into account when we are looking at the tax people can afford to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: This period in Australia's history has been the most painful for rural Australia. For those of us in the Opposition, particularly those who have been here for a few years, this debacle has brought home clearly the frustration of being in opposition. I believe that we are not going to be here much longer; we are going to be on the Government side. We have had to observe the destruction of an industry by this Government that we have been powerless to stop. We cannot, and this time will not, sit impotent and helpless while the Government attempts to get the proverbial blood out of a stone.

The industry is bankrupt. It cannot pay 15 per cent tax. What is more, it need not have to pay that higher tax. The Opposition's proposals for a maximum of 10 per cent are valid and sustainable. They are also not negotiable. I have just done a tour of the western regions of New South Wales, visiting woolgrowers in different places. They cannot afford to pay any more than 10 per cent in tax. If any people from the Department, the Government or anywhere else wants to see how people are battling, let them go out and see the people who are running sheep in the western districts of New South Wales. I am quite sure that it would be no different in a lot of parts from South Australia, Western Australia-where Senator Panizza comes from-or Tasmania. Too much tax is just very difficult-in fact, impossible-to pay.

We have done our figures, which is more than can be said for either the Government or some groups advising the industry. During the debate in the other place, several Opposition speakers incorporated figures prepared by the Opposition on options for the industry. Senator Tambling has done the same here tonight, so I will not have them incorporated in Hansard again. Where are the figures and the options of the Government? On what is its judgment for 15 per cent based? What about the Wool Council of Australia? What figures has it produced for its members? What sort of industry group that purports to represent the best interests of woolgrowers would recommend support for a 15 per cent tax, as the Wool Council did originally, and only latterly come to realise the sustainability of a 10 per cent tax?

Only yesterday I received a piece of paper that was written on Wool Council of Australia letterhead. The letter was written by Alan Bowman, the President, and was dated 7 June 1991. After having talked about the 12 per cent tax and the 15 per cent tax, it went on to say:

This is not to say a lower tax would not be equally prudent if property sales could generate more than $40 million in 1991/92. Therefore, the Opposition's policy to set the wool tax in 1991/92 at 10% is a feasible alternative.

What sort of honest brokers are the Democrats if they are prepared to push their 12 per cent barrow just so they can claim credit for saving the industry 3 per cent? On what basis was the 12 per cent arrived at? Do we know, or do they know?

One needs only to look at how this mess first started. Let us take as an example the former primary industry Minister when he embarked on what is now regarded as the beginning of the end of the reserve price scheme. In 1987, in introducing changes to the operation of the wool industry, Mr Kerin suggested that the Bill:
. . . seeks to place the Australian Wool Corporation on a sound commercial footing . . . equipped to respond now and into the future to the pressures of the market place.

One could not be much further off the mark than that. One can only pray that this man, now the nation's Treasurer, will not make as big a mistake in his new portfolio. What of his departmental advisers, his experts in the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and the Corporation itself, who projected figures and futures so unrelated to the reality of today that one has to ask on what basis their judgment was made? Is it any wonder that, with that track record, the industry is in the predicament it is? The wonder of it is that it is not even worse off than it is at the moment.

On the question of marketing wool, I have received a great many suggestions. Growers, housewives and marketing experts have come up with ways of promoting wool-wool blends, cool wool and greasy wool. It seems that there is no shortage of ideas. Consumers, if asked, say that they prefer woollens to synthetics, but somewhere along the chain there is a marketing breakdown and wool sales are not meeting the expectations. One of the greatest disincentives is price and, at some stages last year, the fact of supply through the pipeline.

Consumers read that woolgrowers are shooting sheep and that the price of wool has fallen through the floor, but they cannot buy a decent wool jumper for under $60 and they cannot buy a skein of wool for less than $3 to $4. Preferences are all very well but only when they can be afforded. Every Australian child should own a pure wool jumper, but it is much easier and cheaper to buy a synthetic product. Patriotism is very well but it does not come before price. People regard wool as an expendable luxury fibre rather than as an essential for cold climate living. Confidence must be instilled again into the selling chain. The consumer must be respected in the wool chain. The producer must be respected so that he or she is still there in the future to produce wool and not be driven out of business. I believe that a 15 per cent tax will drive people out of business.

The wool industry is a great industry and will remain so if we do not drive the nail into its coffin by taxing it more now than it needs to be. It is time for the administration of the industry to tighten its belt and to sell some of the corporate assets, and quickly, rather than impose a high tax which would put undue strain on the growers and force them to sell their assets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991 and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991. They are the final nail in the coffin of the reserve price scheme. Let us not make the mistake tonight of setting the tax into the next 12 months and beyond for the debt realisation scheme, which will put the nail in the coffin of many woolgrowers.

SPEECH.PARA: How things have changed. In the early 1970s I was part of a group of angry, young new land farmers who were prepared to stop all traffic from east to west, both rail and road, to try to force the government of the day to introduce a reserve price scheme. The scheme worked well until 1987 when it was turned into a market price setting mechanism. From that day it was doomed. The reserve price scheme became a dog chasing its tail in ever decreasing circles. In late January 1991 it collapsed; it was exhausted.

What is left? There is a debt of $2.63 billion, a stockpile of 815 million kilograms or some 4.4 million bales, and thousands and thousands of growers at risk. Before one looks to the future, one must ask: where does the ultimate responsibility for this lie? It must clearly rest with the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who removed section 41 from the Act in 1987. That part of the Act revolved around the discipline which was required financially in an operation such as the reserve price scheme. Until that date the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) at fortnightly intervals had to make reports to the Minister and to the Treasurer as to how the reserve price scheme was travelling. That all changed and greed and misjudgment took over.

One must also not forget that Mr Kerin was responsible for the appointment of the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation. He also appointed the Government's representative on the Wool Corporation. It is not good enough to claim that the Government did not know what was going on. It had the people there and they knew what was going on.

I refer to the Auditor-General's report which came out yesterday entitled Potential Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament-Australian Wool Realisation Commission and Australian Wool Corporation. A number of honourable senators spoke on this matter yesterday. I will not go over that debate, other than to say that it was a grave mistake to present these Bills to this Parliament and not have the Auditor-General as the key person in terms of auditing and reporting to the Parliament.

Also one must not forget what has happened in the wool industry and other industries where high interest rates caused by Government monetary policy have borne down heavily not only on individual woolgrowers but also on the Wool Corporation. At the same time as wool was travelling well-and there were a couple of years when it earned $6 billion worth of export income-income equalisation deposits (IEDs) were removed. The one mechanism which people on the land had by which they could offset their high incomes and prepare themselves for a rainy day or when the cash flow was not so good was taken away. Treasurer Keating took millions and millions and millions of dollars off woolgrowers for the Treasury coffers. Had those IEDs been left in place the wool industry would be in a much better position to handle the situation which exists today.

Let us look at the difference between a 15 per cent tax and a 10 per cent tax. The simplest terms that I can put it in are that at 450c clean a kilo for every 1,000 sheep shorn the difference between 10 per cent and 15 per cent is $750. We can all do our figures from there. For many that would mean the difference between viability and non-viability.

I now turn to the work the Opposition has done on how we could have a significantly lower tax than that proposed by the Government in these Bills. Since the Vines Committee report was brought down, there has been a lower debt than anticipated. Prices have been much better than anticipated. There are lower interest rates in servicing that debt. There can be a much greater emphasis on the disposal of the Wool Corporation assets and a significantly lower production figure than initially anticipated. That has come down from an anticipated figure, some three or four months ago, of 914 million kilograms per annum to about 880 million to 881 million kilograms today officially. But independent research that I have commissioned would suggest, at least in Western Australia, that it is even more than that. The figure could well be down somewhere around 850 million kilograms.

Let us look at some other potential mechanisms by which the tax could be kept down so that as many growers as possible could survive and the hardship that will occur over the next year or two could be minimised. When I talk about hardship, I do not talk only about the farmers on the land but also about those people who service the industry, and they are a very important component of it.

Looking at the current situation with the Wool Corporation, we find that it has reserves of some $200m in general promotion and research and development. That begs the question: why would the Corporation in the situation it found itself last October-November, particularly with regard to promotion, have those sorts of reserves tucked away in its hip pocket? Today they can be used to lower the tax that has to be applied.

We must also look at the $290m worth of AWC assets. Some of those assets are not even being used in the wool industry; they are being leased out to store motor cars and a number of other things. I cannot in all honesty stand here and suggest that those stores should remain in preference to producers being sold off.

Looking firstly at the figures, one must challenge the Government-as was done in the other place-on why it has not put its figures on the table on how it comes to its conclusions. Looking at the figures across the board, one can see that there is a potential for significant asset sales and there is a potential, with the drop in production, for some sales from the stockpile. There is an ability to use the promotion reserves and run them down. There is no reason why we should keep millions and millions of dollars tucked away in that cosy little pouch.

When we analyse all these figures-these figures have been tested by a number of people and nobody has found any holes in them-we find that the level required to finance the shortfall on the operating costs of the Corporation is about 5.1 per cent. So it is not necessary, as is the case with the Government, to do that with a figure of up to 11 per cent plus 4 per cent for promotion, research and development. I re-emphasise that we should sell the wool assets and run those reserves down before we start selling up growers.

Research and development, promotion and the future development of the International Wool Secretariat have to be looked at very carefully. We must start placing emphasis on promoting the Australian product and what Australian wool can do. We must look at whether there is a better mechanism for promoting wool on world markets. It could well be better to put wool promotion out to tender. A number of very professional world promoters might well do the same or better job for significantly less cost. This has never been reported on.

I now want to touch on a number of other pieces of research that have been done. The ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report entitled Financing the Wool Industry's Debt, which I received yesterday from one of the members of the Wool Council of Australia-the report was brought down on 7 June, and that was the first time I saw it-showed quite clearly that, in fact, in the first year a tax of 9.25 per cent in total for promotion, research and development and the servicing of the debt could meet what was required. Further research has indicated that, if the tax were set at 10 per cent, it would take five years to service that debt realisation scheme. When Minister Kerin's plan is over a seven-year period, one asks why we need to have a tax at 15 per cent.

In the time I have remaining, I wish to acknowledge the success of the flock reduction scheme. That has put us in a position today-although many people did not like it-where we are able to produce figures of the magnitude we have talked about. I very strongly urge the Government to accept that there should be as a component of these Bills a provision, if the industry sees fit in the future, to reintroduce a flock reduction scheme. At the end of the day, there has to be a balance between supply and demand and price, and that is one way of producing that.

Finally, I touch on a very sad matter. I just hope that the importance of getting the tax down gets through to Government members on the other side of the chamber. Just before I walked into the chamber, I was informed of the third suicide of a bona fide woolgrower in the last fortnight in Western Australia. The situation is critical. It is so damn critical that it is imperative that the Government sees that, by placing a 15 per cent tax on the wool industry today, it will create a situation where a whole host of other people give up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are, for the fourth time in two years, debating a heap of wool Bills-namely, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill. That alone shows what stopgap measures the Government has taken over the last two years; every time there is a problem, it comes in with a stopgap measure. The one thing I have learned since I have been in this place is that any important Bill to do with primary industry-whether it be the wheat, wool or meat industry-comes in late in the session and late at night. That reflects the importance that this Government places on primary industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the eyes and ears of not only Australian woolgrowers, but also businessmen from large and small businesses and their employees on us to see what sort of decision we are going to make this evening, because our decision will have a bearing on whether or not we are going to have a wool industry and whether or not a lot of those people will have jobs for very long. My fears, that I have expressed in every speech that I have made on wool in this place, are seeing the light of day.

Going back over the history, first there was that ill-fated decision-agreed to by this Government and its then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who is now the Treasurer (Mr Kerin)-to lift the reserve price from 670c to 870c a kilo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—That is all right, Senator West can stay there and cop it because her Government went right along with it. I hope that Mr Kerin makes more success of the Treasury than he has of fixing this portfolio. Senator West can stay there and listen but, if she does not want to listen to what is going on out there, she can leave the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Next was the inflexibility of the Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Council of Australia in refusing to submit to the folly and reduce that reserve. Even though it is short, history has shown us that the biggest single outcome of this ill-conceived system of 1986-87 was the increase in production. This was led by New South Wales where production jumped up 48 per cent and Victoria where it was up 38 per cent, and the Australian average was 33 per cent. It occurred because we were selling wool to ourselves at a price which was too high and which we could not afford. That is all that happened.

The real beneficiary, as Senator Crane has already pointed out, was the Australian Taxation Office, which could do what it liked. The next beneficiaries were the banks which were doing the best they could with the woolgrowers and also financing the stockpile. The greedy bigger studs, with their increased sales of higher priced rams, are just as much to blame. The stockpile was growing and growing and the Minister sat on his backside and did nothing about it. The Corporation itself stumbled from disaster to disaster, so did Mr Kerin, as attempts were made to get out of the mess and we finished up with 5.6 million bales and nearly $4m in debt.

We saw the levy increase to a 30 per cent maximum plus another 10 per cent levy. We saw $7m spent by the Corporation on computers to put in action quotas which never saw the light of day. I do not know what happened to the computers; they are probably still not being used. Mr Kerin made a statement that 870c was immutable and then dropped it to 600c while he gave an ironclad guarantee all over the world on 700c. Then there was total collapse and the suspension of sales. The perpetrators of this scheme-the Corporation, the Wool Council and the Minister-have certainly got a lot to answer for.

So much for the history. Now there is damage control and, hopefully, the return of this great industry to the rightful position that it has had in Australia as a leading exporter. Only three years ago this industry was gathering more export income than coal, then we let it go wrong. Fortunately, since February when everything collapsed, there have been a few lights on the horizon but not very many. The price of wool is somewhat better than expected because of better demand. Production, because of the season and loss of confidence, has eased. The slaughter scheme had a bit to do with this, especially in the eastern States where there was probably more slaughter than anywhere else. They needed it. They are the States that had overproduced and overstocked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—New South Wales did. It then used different methods and different guns for a slaughter scheme. Unfortunately, the real problem for a high percentage of the 66,000 woolgrowers is that they are in jeopardy of having to leave their farms, and the final outcome of this Bill will have a great bearing on their future. That is why I said we are going to have to make a very big decision tonight. A 5 per cent difference in the wool tax made tonight can mean about $4,000 to the average woolgrower. If a woolgrower or anybody else has a zero income, $4,000 is a mighty lot of money.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I wish to address my remarks to a group of people around Australia-some of whom came to see me yesterday-who want to abolish the wool tax altogether. I think they call themselves the Abolish Wool Tax Movement. They want to pay no tax at all, but they have to face up to their responsibilities. The woolgrowers, along with the Corporation, the Minister and the Wool Council, got themselves into this position, and they have to get themselves out of it. I will not go along with the extreme methods they propose. If the wool industry wants to retain credibility in the bush--

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to dictate the number of people in the industry. You are critical of the 40 per cent in New South Wales.

—Yes, I am critical of the 40 per cent increase, and the 38 per cent increase in Victoria, as well as the increase in Western Australia. As a whole, we have to get ourselves out of this situation. We have to address the problem of how we can keep most of these farmers on their farms.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of the debate is the figure we finish up with tonight. The figure for research and promotion alone is 6 per cent. Whatever figure we talk about-whether it is 4 per cent, 6 per cent or 10 per cent-is on top of that 6 per cent. No-one has yet questioned the 6 per cent promotion figure. I believe that it is too much. After all, the cotton industry does not have a promotion levy, nor does it pay for promotion. It lets the industry do that-the ones who are making the money on the way through and processing it. We should look at that approach to try to reduce the number of people the industry is carrying and cannot afford to carry any longer. That problem has to be addressed. That is not quite the problem we are addressing tonight, but I put it as an aside. We are paying out far too much.

The coalition has done its figures and published them. No-one has laid a glove on them. Not one person, newspaper or organisation in Australia has laid a glove on our figures. Where are the Australian Democrats' figures? I have never seen them published. All they can say is that our figures will not stand up. They say what the tax figures should be. Senator Bell will tell me that every time, but he has not shown me his figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza, will you please address your remarks through the Chair.

—I apologise, Madam Acting Deputy President. I will address my remarks through the Chair. The Democrats have not published or produced any figures, nor has Government. Where are the Government's figures? The Government has told us-and it will continue to tell us tonight-that our figures are wrong, but it has not produced figures of its own.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic point to be considered is how we arrived at these figures, and Senator Tambling alluded to this. We can support what we say. We say that we can support 10 per cent over the next seven years. If we get into promotion and use some of the reserves Senator Crane spoke about, I believe we can get the figure down to 7 per cent or even lower. If honourable senators opposite bothered to read the figures, they would see that we could do it.

When earlier figures were worked out we were looking at a production of 914 million kilos a year; forward projections now show that to be 881 million kilos and dropping. A lot of sheep have died because of the unfortunate start to the season in the east and in part of the west. The projected average price was 435c per kilo at 21.5 micron clean. That figure was much lower when we debated the wool quotas; now it is projected to be 465c. Incidentally, today it is still 594c, which is 33 per cent above that estimate. That is something else we should keep in mind.

The last time we debated the opening debt, I thought it was going to be between $3.5 billion and $3.9 billion. In March it was mooted to be $2.88 billion and now in June it is $2.660 billion. Has anyone on the Government side taken these projected figures into consideration? Obviously not. That is how the Opposition has arrived at what it reckons it can do. The Australian Democrats have not produced anything; I know they have used figures from the Wool Council. The last time I saw figures from the Wool Council, one could drive a truck through them. The Wool Council does not know what it is talking about; that is where the Australian Democrats went wrong. The Wool Council commissioned ACIL Australia Pty Ltd to give it a report. When it received that report on 6 June, as Senator Crane said, it conveniently kept it in the dark because it shows that the Council could do the whole lot at 9.25 per cent. Once again, no-one has taken notice of that. I have asked the Government where it got its figures from; I asked the same question of the Australian Democrats.

In the final analysis the Opposition believes that the way to strike a fair tax, to keep farmers on their farms and to pay this debt off while woolgrowers keep credibility is the way in which we handle real estate. I believe that the Australian Wool Corporation is working on selling $65m-worth of real estate in the first year, and the Government is doing the same. The Opposition believes it could sell $100m in the first year and another $100m in the second year, but I believe the total assets to be in excess of $280m. I asked the Wool Corporation when it gave us a briefing why it did not sell more real estate in central business districts rather than selling farmers off their farms, and I was asked whether I would sell real estate returning 14 per cent. That real estate is full of cars; it was not built to store cars. If I wanted to sell real estate, the first I would sell would be the one returning 14 per cent because that is what it would bring me-in the present downturn, the quickest sale for the highest price. If I were to buy a building that was already tenanted, the best I could hope to get generally would be about 7 per cent, and I would hope to build it up to 10 or 11 per cent in the first rent review. No, real estate returning 14 per cent would be the first to go. The Wool Corporation should get those people out of that building in the Melbourne central business district and put them into a disused wool store or something like that for the rest of the Corporation's time and until we get rid of the stockpile. That is how we will get that figure down-by getting rid of the real estate in Melbourne and in the south of France, where the Corporation has obviously been entertaining its friends and/or customers.

That is the whole point: if we get rid of that real estate more quickly, we will have a chance of getting that stockpile down. At this stage I challenge the Democrats and the Government to look at the Opposition's figures because, as I said at the start of my speech, the rest of Australia has its eyes and ears on us tonight because this will be the Waterloo of whether the industry survives. We need to bring in good wool stockpile management, but that is a byplay to getting that figure down to a figure our woolgrowers can afford to pay during this downturn. I know that the wool industry will revive, as it has done on every other occasion it has been down. In my time I have seen the price of wool fall four times and I have seen it revive four times.
In conclusion, I ask the Democrats, the Government and the independents-mainly led by Senator Brian Harradine-to look at what we are saying, because we are making a vital decision tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important thing about this debate is that at the end of it, we must retain an active and viable industry. The actions we take tonight will determine whether this industry survives and prospers in the year ahead. My ancestors turned up here in the 1820s. They brought with them on the ship merino sheep and they found that these sheep did very well in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: As time has passed and quality has improved, Tasmania has now reached the stage of having about five million sheep, including, of course, some of the very best in Australia. Over the past 12 months, there has been an overall decline of about 10 per cent in the sheep numbers in the State, a trend that we must all hope continues, not only in Tasmania, but also throughout Australia, until the stock and the debt position are brought to manageable conditions.

Over the 200 years of Australia's history, we have had a sheep's back mentality and too often we have acted as though providing we had sheep, nothing else mattered. I well remember the problems of the industry at the time when I first came into the Senate. I have followed the operation of the Australian Wool Corporation during its life and times ever since. There can be no doubt that the scheme worked very well. It did everything its originators said and hoped it would, but most of all, it took away some of the normal risks of business and provided a considerable smoothing of incomes.

Sheep and wool increased in numbers and popularity as the risk declined. Wherever other forms of farming hit hard times, the farmers seemed to resort to sheep. Eventually, numbers alone brought about a situation where supply exceeded demand. But instead of market forces reflecting this with the lower prices, the floor price, which by then had also become a ceiling price, failed to give the signals and we developed the well-known problems of enormous magnitude.

Over many years it has been considered right that Australia should produce wool but let others process it and sell it back to us. I can never go along with that and I believe that even now we should be doing everything possible to remove any obstacle that would enable us to become prominent in the world of woollen processors.

With the appalling state of the Australian economy, employment, relative standard of living and overseas debt, we must surely all concede that our primary and mineral industries cannot produce a level of income that can get us back on the rails. Secondary manufacturing must be encouraged and fostered. Our research achievements have been tremendous in growing and in the processing of wool. It is time that we got the sorts of benefits for Australia that are available from these developments.

In recent times, it has become clear that wool is really not one product-just wool-but at least two and probably three products. If it is two, the division would be apparel wools and non-apparel wools. If it is three, we have got fine, medium and coarse. The superfine wool, which is the flagship of the industry, does not need much more introduction at this stage. Then there is the medium wool which is the substantial majority of the total clip. This is where the major opportunities and extension of uses exist and where the work must be done in the years ahead.

I comment most favourably on the coarse or carpet wool and its industry. This group of growers are well organised; they know what and where their market is and they operate very efficiently. The coalition's rural committee has spent nearly all of its time this year investigating, consulting and contacting as many people as possible so that our recommendations can be of the highest possible standards.

I take this opportunity to thank the members of our committee and all those people who have made their time available, either here in Canberra or in their home States. I thank all who have made suggestions, prepared submissions and spent hours and hours on the telephone with one thing and one thing only in their minds-how to get the wool industry back on the track for the good of those in it and for the country as a whole.

One issue that has come through is the reflection of what the wool industry really is. As at 31 March 1990, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, there were 63,716 rural establishments with sheep and a total of 170.297 million sheep, representing an average flock size of just 2,673.

For honourable senators' information, on a State by State basis flock sizes are as follows: New South Wales, 2,814; Victoria, 1,799; Queensland, 5,389; South Australia, 1,848; Western Australia, 3,805; Tasmania, 2,610; and the Australian Capital Territory, 2,033. Bearing that in mind, there are 16 flocks of over 50,000 sheep and 330 flocks of between 20,000 and 50,000 sheep; while at the other extreme there are 2,645 flocks of fewer than 100 sheep. The median flock size falls between 1,500 and 2,000 sheep.

All of those producers now know the situation. They are fully aware; they have learnt from the past and they understand that no industry can prosper unless it is market driven or consumer oriented. The floor price removed all of the skills of marketing and the need to produce for special needs. As the industry recovers this will, and must, be the basis of that recovery. The latest figure I have is that the stockpile totalled 4,639,123 bales as at 7 June, so there is still a very long way to go.

Out of that-as was pointed out very strenuously by one of my callers last night-there are two things to remember. The stockpile is not a liability; it is an asset and a very good one. In fact, with the increase in prices over recent weeks the potential recovery has improved by 35 per cent to 40 per cent. The other point on which an independent, arms length assessment needs to be made as soon as possible, followed by a report to the industry, the trade and the Government, is as to the quality of the holding. Should there be hundreds, or even thousands, of bales of substandard or unsaleable wool, it should be disposed of-and disposed of quickly. With the new start there should be no self-imposed handicaps.

Let us bear the market in mind. The buyers need to be assured that they can face an open market with complete certainty, subject to their own market judgment. Whilst it is comfortable to work within a controlled market, in the long run the free market has to be the best judge. From our Committee deliberations one thing stands out: namely, that production must be slowed down. On the best reasonable estimates we cannot expect to sell quantities vastly greater than previously established ranges of sales; nor at this juncture do we see extensive new product nor new country markets. The alternative therefore is a production reduction until the slide really takes over and holdings clear.

We all hope that fewer ewe lambs will be retained and fewer ewes mated. We hope that mutton sales can be expanded further and that reduced flocks will not be restocked yet. In the meantime, I believe today is the last of this year's Launceston wool sales. Of course, Launceston has been the real centre of selling for the cream of Australia's superfine wool. So much of the trade there is now personal, with regular buyers for the special lines. Year after year it produces the seasonal record prices. I, and I am sure all of the other Tasmanian senators, will be pressing for the retention of these very special sales.

I noted this week that certain potential buyers did not participate in a particular sale because of the tri-dumped bales. It will be sheer stupidity if we lose buyers because we fail to take into account the needs of the average regular buyers. It does not matter what suits us; it is what the buyer requires that matters.

The times ahead will surely be difficult for some time. The new boards will have to play a tremendously important part and we will look to them for reduction and guidance. There will be requirements on the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics for close monitoring and judgment, while matters of production techniques, handling, transporting and marketing will involve all of the resources of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other bureaus, besides every capability of the private sector in order to reduce costs and improve efficiency so that profitability may be restored as soon as possible. We all feel desperately sorry for those who have suffered, or may suffer, as a result of the combined effects of the recession and the wool collapse.

The flow-on effects will hurt many others; so we must ensure that we reduce the debt as fast as possible, but not by overtaking those who do not have a capacity to pay. The Opposition believes 10 per cent is quite adequate for this tax-and it has carried out hundreds of calculations to confirm this. The Wool Council's ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report would confirm that there is no justification to move to a higher figure on economic grounds and there is certainly no good reason for more than a 10 per cent tax on compassionate and humanitarian grounds as well. I support the thrust of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight will mark, I hope, the final episode in this saga of the wool industry problems that have beset the industry and the nation for some time now. I am definitely supporting the Government position, which I guess is no surprise to the Opposition. However, I am a little alarmed at some of the suggestions I have heard tonight. I have heard criticism of the fact that there was a 40 per cent increase in the number of New South Wales woolgrowers over the past few years--
—Forty-eight per cent.

—A 48 per cent increase in the number of New South Wales woolgrowers and a 36 per cent increase in the number of woolgrowers in Victoria. I ask the question of those who believe in free enterprise: in a democracy how does somebody anticipate, and how would we go about stopping, people moving into an industry?
—Do you believe in free enterprise now?

—I have never said it was that. Those opposite are the ones who say they believe in free enterprise, but also they are critical of increases in production and would appear to want to do things to stop it.
—You are really misquoting dreadfully.
—I have learned from you, Senator Walters.
—You must have been one of the few who have.

—I have not learned much, but that is one thing I have learned. We have heard a number of times tonight reference to the ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report that was done for the Australian Wool Council. I do not know which ACIL report for the Wool Council has been quoted tonight. It is certainly not the one I have seen. I quote from its summary:

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, justifiable variation to the assumptions likely to have been used by the Government mean that no change to the wool tax is required for 1991-92. Some changes work to reduce the rate of tax while others work in the opposite direction. Overall, the changes amount to a difference of less than 0.5 per cent.
In conclusion, fine tuning of the original assumptions used by the Government does not justify a reduction in the total wool tax rate (for 1991-92) from the 15 per cent announced.

To reduce the rate of tax below 15 per cent in 1991-92 would require, a combination of deferring the payment of $20 million debt, capitalising some of the debt, extending the repayment period, selling wool from the stockpile and greater sales of AWC assets.

The report then goes on to assess the options. If I am asked about the date, are we up to changing our assumptions, which is the usual trick of the economists? Is that how people are coming up 10 per cent and 6 and 7 per cent, as we have heard tonight? The suggestion that some people have been making is that the tax should be at 6 or 7 per cent. Are we changing our assumptions? We really need to get a level playing field.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just reading the whole thing. No-one said it should be at six per cent.

—Senator Boswell has just arrived. He has obviously not heard what was said by some of his colleagues. The Opposition's final amendment talks about a properly managed industry funded flock reduction scheme. Senator Archer has quoted the average flock size at 2,600-odd head. Who will decide how this reduction is to take place?
—It is voluntary, of course; free enterprise.

—That is not how you are talking about it here, you are talking about managing it. When I see the word `manage' I interpret it to mean that there are some controls over it. What you are obviously promoting is a scheme that would, in effect, reduce the flock numbers of a number of farmers to sizes that are not viable. That is one hole within your amendments that I think you really need to carefully look at and think about.
—Order! Senator West, I would be pleased if you would address your remarks through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Madam Acting Deputy President. I have already been naughty and made some interjections on assets sales-that people do not want cash flows-and it is not an argument that I intend to pursue any further. However, it is one that one looks at whether one wants a once-off payment or a guaranteed cash flow-an income-and that is an issue that obviously we disagree about.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to talk briefly about the wool promotion strategies that are being planned within the legislation. It is very true to say that wool promotion strategy in the past-and even now-tends to concentrate on the top quality end of the market. It is for the fine wool that has gone into these products, it is not for the wool of the lower microns--

TALK.START.PARA: —The indicator that was always used was lower microns.

—Let me tell Senator Panizza that I do not think the indicator was used in the coat that I happen to have on-it was certainly finer than that. I support, and want people to be very conscious of, the promotion of all of our wool. Wool is a wonderful product-no-one would ever argue with that-but we have to look at the proper promotion of wool in all of its micron widths. Carpet wool manufacturers have managed to do that- they have carved out a niche for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to make sure that promotion of the industry takes place in a way that does not concentrate only on the premium fine wool area. It is beautiful wool-it is without par in the world-but we have to make sure that we do not promote it to the exclusion or diminution of the promotion that has gone on in the past. People in the industry keep saying to me, `They do not promote the type of wool that I grow, and I grow good medium wool'. It is a comment that I hear all the time.

The Australian Wool Corporation will also be looking to set quality standards and ensure that these standards are met. Obviously, the standards for quality and for bale cleanliness are still not being met. Every few years we have a program of promotion and work on reminding wool producers that they have to make sure that they do not put foreign matter into wool bales. This is something that we have to work on at our level-the producer level-so that we are not producing and sending overseas bales that are full of extraneous matter that is certainly going to clog and foul up the machines. That is an important thing that we must undertake to do.

The other thing that we must undertake to do is the testing of our wool-an objective measurement of our wool. I will quote two people within the industry who are buying Australian wool-Mr Kamei from Lachlan Industry Pty Ltd at Cowra, and Mr Ishiguro from Kanebo Ltd in Japan. In an article that has appeared in a number of papers they say:
The Japanese wool processing industry has called on Australian woolgrowers to insist their clip is measured for staple length and strength.
Managing Director of Lachlan Industry Pty Ltd at Cowra, Mr T Kamei, has urged woolgrowers to insist their clip is tested in this way.
At present, just 50 per cent of combing wools in Australia are measured for length and strength.
It is important for this figure to increase significantly in the 1991-92 season so that processors can be certain of the specification of the greasy wool.
This will increase the demand for such wool.
Woolgrowers who do not test will be disadvantaged because there will be reduced price competition for untested lots.
These views were supported by Mr K. Ishiguro, manager of the Raw Wool Department of Kanebo Ltd, a major wool textile processing company in Japan . . .

`Kanebo is prepared to pay more for staple tested wool because we can be confident our automatic spinning and weaving machinery can operate effectively when the raw material is objectively specified,' Mr Ishiguro said.
`Almost all our purchase contracts stipulate wool must be 100 per cent additionally measured.
`Japan has a reputation for high quality wool products.
`This means we must ensure our raw material is supplied to our strict specifications.
`This can only be done if the wool is well classed and fully tested before sale,' Mr Ishiguro said.
These are some of the things the new Wool Corporation is going to be able to provide for the industry, and that is an extremely important point to bear in mind.

We have heard a number of calls tonight and concerns expressed-justifiable concerns-about the fate of people in the wool industry with the downturn in the economy. They have failed to recognise that the Government has announced significant increases in the rural adjustment scheme. We are dealing with that issue and looking to that. Of course, the States also have a responsibility there. The sooner this debt is repaid the sooner the wool industry can get back to looking constructively at where it is going.

This is an important debate tonight. I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate much longer. I urge honourable senators to be very cautious and careful when they think about what will be happening. I urge people to be careful and cautious also when dealing with economists' work. Much criticism has been expressed about the fact that economists work upon assumptions and, having heard lots of figures bandied around tonight, I think we must go back and look very carefully at each original assumption upon which those assessments are based.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator West not for her knowledge of the wool industry but because she is the only Government speaker who is prepared to stand up for the Australian Labor Party. I would have thought Senator Walsh might have had a go tonight, but perhaps he is too embarrassed to support the 15 per cent. I suspect that is why he has not entered this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating tonight nine wool industry Bills that will restructure the administration of the great Australian wool industry: the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991; the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991; the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill 1991; the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills 1991; and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991. These nine Bills will impose on Australia's 60,000 woolgrowers a system they do not want and for which they cannot afford to pay if the 15 per cent levy is carried. I am hoping that the Australian Democrats will find it in their hearts to come across and support the 10 per cent levy that the coalition is moving for. I appeal to the Government, but it has not shown any sympathy to the rural or primary industries for as long as I have been in this Senate, so I think my appeal will once again fall on deaf ears.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not have to tell you about the state of the economy in the bush. Many woolgrowers are destined to go out of business because of what this legislation will do to them. It is not only a tragedy for those woolgrowers and for rural Australia as a whole but also for all Australians. The wool industry more than any other is responsible for providing prosperity to this nation. It supports indirectly and directly approximately 650,000 Australian jobs. It is up to this Senate to ensure that as many Australian woolgrowers as possible stay in business. It is in this nation's interests. Wool growing is what Australia does best. We have heard predictions around the Senate, and I agree with them, that there will be a wool shortage in three or four years time. But the immediate future for woolgrowers is fragile, and the level of taxation inflicted by this Government will take them to and beyond the breaking point.

We have seen the industry let down so many times in the last 12 months by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who has now been elevated-I think the industry term is `laterally promoted': when people botch something up, they are pushed sideways. Mr Kerin could not have done any worse for the wool industry. He even put a new meaning into such terms as `immutable', `rock solid', `cast iron' and `guaranteed'; he put a whole new meaning into the vocabulary.

When the Minister was talking about the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing, he was talking about a 12 per cent tax applying after July 1991. The Vines report concluded that a 12 per cent tax was the top that the woolgrowers could support. That was a government-structured committee. Even then, the Vines committee reported that, if that tax was applied, the wool industry on average would be running at minus $620 per farm in 1991-92. The Government now ignores its own committee findings and imposes a tax of 15 per cent, which many farm bodies say will bankrupt 30 per cent of woolgrowers.

These Bills replace the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) with three new bodies-the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the new Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool Research and Development Corporation. The Wool Realisation Commission is scheduled to last seven years and is to sell off the stockpile of 4.7 million bales and the non-wool assets, repay the $2.7 billion debt and wind up the supplementary payments scheme. The Government has decided that the responsibility for the debt and the stockpile must remain with the industry. This is despite the Vines committee recommending a government responsibility for a debt contribution of $500m over the next two years, representing a 60 : 40 split between the Government and the industry, and that the Government be the ultimate guarantor of the debt.

The Commission is to determine the combination of asset sales and sales from the stockpile in accordance with guidelines drawn up by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin). The new Wool Corporation is to promote and market wool, but not in a direct way, and to oversee quality control. We have not had the Bill in here more than a day and the first thing we get is a report querying the accountability by the Auditor-General. I believe that Senator Tambling will move amendments that will pick up those points.

It has been disclosed that the Minister can appoint external auditors instead of the Auditor-General without justifying the decision. We do not know what the extra costs for growers involved in this will be. We do not know why the Minister has made this extraordinary situation for those two bodies without any consultation with the Auditor-General, or with the industry, for that matter. It puts into doubt what other complications will arise from the Government rushing through this legislation only days before it has to start.

The other bodies set up by the Bills are the Australian Wool Industry Council and the Research and Development Corporation. The splitting of the AWC into three bodies is not supported by the industry, prominent businessmen or academics. It has always believed that to separate or divide is to conquer. All this is to be financed by a tax payable in the proportion of 0.5 per cent to the Wool Research and Development Corporation, 3.5 per cent to the Wool Corporation for promotional purposes and 11 per cent to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for debt management. Our figures, which have been researched by a number of people, show that a figure of 6 per cent to the Wool Realisation Commission would be adequate.

The Minister in his second reading speech acknowledged the importance of the correct tax rate and the rate that growers can afford. The Minister then went on to say in his second reading speech that a 15 per cent wool tax meant that significant numbers of specialist woolgrowers would have no farm cash operating surplus in 1991-92. I do not know what he thinks woolgrowers will live on. Obviously he has not been out in the bush and he does not realise the plight of the woolgrowers there.

The Minister then made an amazing discovery. He said that, whether it was 12 per cent or 15 per cent, the rate would not affect growers. In practice, he said, the effect of the difference on farm cash operating could be measured in hundreds of dollars, not thousands. I hope he does his sums a bit better now that he is the Treasurer. This is where the 30 per cent of farmers who will be put out of business by a 15 per cent tax would strongly disagree with the Minister.

Let me enunciate a few of the differences. On 5,000 sheep, $10,125 is paid on a 15 per cent levy against only $6,750 on a 10 per cent levy-a difference of $3,375. That is a considerable amount of money. It is particularly considerable when one is on a negative income and does not know where the next quid is coming from. That is only a small flock of sheep. When we get up to 10,000 sheep the difference is $7,000-$20,000 on a 15 per cent levy compared with $13,000 on a 10 per cent levy. It can be measured at $750 per one thousand sheep. The Minister then said that an extra 5 per cent tax would not affect incomes. That is an absurd statement. A 10 per cent tax is all that is needed in the new circumstances. Our proposed levy of 10 per cent divides into 0.5 per cent for research and development, 3.5 per cent for promotion and 6 per cent for debt reduction.

There have been many changes since the Government first formulated its plan and which the Government should now consider. Wool prices have risen above expectations. The Government based its calculations on 435c per kilogram and the coalition's 10 per cent tax is based on 450c per kilogram. I do not have today's wool price, but I think it has gone to 594c a kilogram, a rise of something like 14c within the previous couple of days. It is a rising market. Wool is being released from the stockpile. Dry weather and stock reduction schemes have reduced production. Latest wool production estimates for the next season from the Australian wool production forecasting committee show that production will be reduced to 881 million kilograms from 914 million kilograms which was the calculation used by the Government.

I wish to refer to the ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report. Senator West must have been using a different report. Perhaps the one I used supersedes hers. The ACIL report to the Wool Council said that the lower level of shorn wool production projected for 1991-92 provided the industry with the opportunity to sell wool from the stockpile, and to use the proceeds for such sales to supplement income from the wool tax. Interest rates have fallen, and the wool debt has been reduced to $2.63 billion, which is almost the level at which the Government expected the debt to be at the end of 1992-93. The Government has then provided another $200m interest free loan for two years, so the amount of the debt to be serviced amounts to $2.43 billion.
The other key factor is the level of property sales. I can never see in business why one would sustain fairly significant property when one's constituents are going out the door backwards.

ACIL recommended asset sales of $40m in 1991-92. It further concluded that it is not to say that a lower tax would not be equally prudent if property sales could generate more than $40m in 1991-92 and that, therefore, the Opposition's policy to set the wool tax at 10 per cent in 1991-92 is a feasible alternative.

The asset sales and utilisation of the AWC reserves should take priority over putting more farmers out of business because of the high tax. The AWC reserves are calculated at $30m generally, $114m in the promotion fund and $56m in the research and development fund. The real estate assets are conservatively estimated at around $290m. For every $20m sale of non-wool assets, the tax can be lowered by one per cent.

It comes down to a simple equation: the sale of assets compared to the sale of farmers' assets. When it comes to that, there is really no decision left: it is in the interests of Australia that we maintain a viable wool industry. There are so many benefits arising out of that, and they must be obvious to everyone.

I do not often do this, but I appeal to the Australian Democrats because it is so bad out there. The 2 per cent difference between 12 per cent and 10 per cent may not seem much money, but in many instances it could be the straw that breaks the camel's back. It may be that 2 per cent that holds so many people into this industry.

We have done our research in a number of ways through a number of people. The Wool Council supports the 10 per cent and believes it is viable. The coalition has run this 10 per cent figure through computers-ACIL has backed it up-and we believe that figure is not only sustainable but also absolutely necessary.

If next year that 10 per cent is not adequate, then maybe we can look at it again. But every indication would confirm that the price is rising; less wool is going on the market; and a higher demand for wool. In the next two years the industry will really have to sort itself out. It needs help now. It may be able to pay a little more later when it can afford to, but it certainly cannot afford to pay more than 10 per cent now. So it is up to the Australian Democrats as to which way they go. It will mean a great deal to the 65,000 woolgrowers if a levy of 10 per cent is carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill and allied Bills represent further inadequate attempts by this Hawke Labor Government to rectify its gross mismanagement of the wool industry and, indeed, of the economy in general. The legislation is a product of procrastination, indecision and bad judgment by this Government, by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and by industry leaders, which has resulted in the wool industry having to face its most serious crisis since the Great Depression of the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills that we are debating this evening are designed to ice the cake of the legislation that we debated in this chamber only four months ago, which did very little to secure the long term stability of the great Australian wool industry. At that time the Government claimed that it was waiting for the report of the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing before it would enter into any long term restructuring of the industry. The Government has now had that report for some time. In this legislation it has adopted some of the recommendations highlighted by that report, but it has not adopted the most important of the Vines committee recommendations-the one which will hit woolgrowers hardest-and that is, the level of the wool tax.

What is at stake and what is at the heart of this legislation is the very survival of a large number of woolgrowers. Make no mistake, what the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has claimed is a mere 5 per cent difference between a 15 per cent and a 10 per cent levy will be enough to ruin many woolgrowers. The difference runs into thousands of dollars for the majority of woolgrowers-not just a few hundred dollars, as the former Minister claimed in his second reading speech in the other place. For a farmer running 5,000 head of sheep with wool prices at 450c a kilogram clean, the difference between a 10 per cent and a 15 per cent tax is $3,500; for a flock of 10,000 sheep, it would be $7,000.

At a time when farm operating cash surpluses have fallen by 89 per cent and are predicted to fall a further 111 per cent, which will mean a cash operating deficit of about $626 per sheep farmer, $3,500 could well mean the difference between survival and disaster for many farmers-the difference for many families between being able to put food on the table and not eating. If there was a comparative income decline among employees represented by some trade unions in this country, there would most certainly be massive industry upheaval and disruption within the entire country. I suspect, however, that the Government would move a lot quicker to ease the situation for its union mates than it has been doing for the farmers of this country.

What is unforgivable is the Government's stubborn persistence in sticking with the 15 per cent tax when the current figures demonstrate that a tax of 8 per cent to 10 per cent would be sufficient to repay the debt. I will illustrate what I mean. The coalition has undertaken detailed studies and very accurate calculations. As a result of that, we have calculated that the recent improvement in the wool market and lower interest rates have reduced the wool debt to about $2.63 billion. This is almost the amount the Government had expected the debt to be by the end of 1992-93 with a 15 per cent tax. Taking into account the Government's $200m two-year interest-free loan, the amount of the loan to be serviced comes down to $2.43 billion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables which illustrate the calculations the coalition has made on this matter.
Leave granted.
