TALK.START.PARA: —Our calculations are based on some very conservative assumptions of long term borrowing rates, wool prices, industry costings and stockpile releases. We have allowed for the fact that supply has fallen below the 900 million kilogram a year figure that the Vines Committee deemed to be the optimum amount to maintain prices. This will enable a greater amount of wool to be released from the stockpile-our figures assume 25 million kilograms for next year-and makes a flock reduction scheme unnecessary in the immediate future.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition maintained for some time that a vigorous flock reduction scheme should be in place to reduce supply and allow room for the stockpile to be sold off in an orderly and predictable fashion. Indeed, the former Minister agreed with us and commenced a flock reduction scheme which eliminated 11 million sheep before it was abruptly terminated.

In reply to my question in Senate Estimates Committee F a month or so ago, as to why the sheep slaughter scheme had been terminated without the review the Minister had promised earlier, officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Australian Wool Corporation admitted that no proper economic analysis of the effectiveness of the scheme had been undertaken.

As a result, in its report to the Senate, Estimates Committee F expressed the view that the Department and its associated agencies should conduct such an analysis in order to ascertain the value of any future use of the flock reduction scheme. If the flock reduction scheme had been continued, as the coalition urged it should be, then more of the stockpile could have been released and the amount of debt and consequently the levy could have been even further reduced.

We have assumed in our calculations that the Wool Corporation can borrow for a little less than 11 per cent on the long term bond market. It would be far better for the Wool Corporation to borrow to cover the debt at these rates than for woolgrowers to have to borrow at the much higher current rates of 16 to 18 per cent, or even up to 20 per cent, applying to them, in order to pay a tax of 15 per cent. After much careful consideration and consultation, we have based our figures on operating and storage costs of about $45m per year; promotion expenditure of $187m in 1991-92; and research and development costs of $54m. We have used the lowest estimate given by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics for the average price of wool next year at 447c per kilogram clean. The current prediction for the average wool price for next year is 450c per kilogram clean. So it is obvious that our calculations are indeed erring on the side of caution.

The coalition also believes that the sale of the Wool Corporation's non-wool assets is vital for keeping down the tax level. We believe that it is quite reasonable to anticipate that we can sell $120m worth of assets in each of the next two years, even with the current depressed economy. If we do not sell off the Wool Corporation's non-wool assets we will have to sell off the farmers' assets for next to nothing, and then there will be no hope of ever paying off the debt. It is totally foolish to suggest that the Wool Corporation should hold on to assets such as empty wool stores while the woolgrowers are forced to sell off their assets from which they earn their very livelihood.

The coalition is not alone in believing that the 15 per cent tax is too high. The Vines committee report confirmed that woolgrowers could not afford to pay a tax of more than 12 per cent. The Wool Corporation recommended a levy of 12 to 13 per cent, and that was before the price of wool improved to the extent it has. The consulting firm ACIL Australia Pty Ltd has calculated that it is possible to pay off the debt with a wool tax of only 8 per cent over seven years. In that regard I simply have to take issue with the remarks earlier in this debate by Labor Senator West. She completely misrepresented and misinterpreted the comments in the ACIL report. It is worth quoting again the statement the honourable senator made, which came from the ACIL report, and then showing the way in which it was misrepresented. The ACIL report is entitled Financing the Wool Industry's Debt. Clause 3.11 reads:
In summary, justifiable variation to the assumptions likely to have been used by the Government mean that no change to the wool tax is required for 1991-92. Some changes-
that is, since March-
work to reduce the rate of tax while others work in the opposite direction. Overall, the changes amount to a difference of less than 0.5 per cent.
That was the quote Senator West read to the Senate. Of course, what she ignored was the following passage from this report:
To reduce the rate of tax below 15 per cent in 1991-92 would require a combination of deferring the payment of $20 million debt-

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at what I said. I did quote all that. Just brush your ears out.
—The honourable senator says that she did quote all that. If so, she obviously ignored the logical conclusion that can be drawn from that--
—Economists' assumptions.

—Senator West talks about economists' assumptions, but she has not told us exactly what the Government's assumptions are. One would assume that the Government relied on some economic advice for its assumptions. The fact is that those assumptions were made some time ago and circumstances have changed significantly and, indeed, favourably for the wool industry since that time. So if any assumptions are to be questioned, it is undoubtedly the Government's assumptions.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this report the ACIL consultants quite clearly conclude and spell out that a tax of less than 15 per cent is quite a viable option to pursue. I simply refer to issues which are raised in this report under the heading in paragraph 1.2- `Is the 15 per cent tax necessary'-whereby ACIL, the author of this report, which Senator West has quoted, concludes that a 15 per cent tax is not necessary. On page 1 it says:

Since the Minister's announcement of the repayment arrangements, a number of events have occurred, leading to the possibility that forecasts made at the time of the Government's decision might already be outdated.
Just as I said a few moments ago. It continues:
For example, in recent weeks the wool market has been more buoyant than most observers had expected.
Higher prices have resulted in larger wool tax collections than budgeted and a faster rate of debt retirement.

As I said earlier in my remarks, the rate of debt retirement now required is lower than that which was assumed by the Government when it made the decision to impose a 15 per cent tax. The report goes on:

Furthermore, there has been increasing discussion and anecdotal evidence that the rate of rundown in sheep numbers and the size of the clip might be more rapid than assumed by current official estimates, hence the possibility of a faster reduction in AWC stocks and, consequently, a lower debt servicing cost and wool tax necessary to cover it.
Senator West, I wish you were listening to these statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chapman, it would be better if you addressed your remarks through the Chair. I have let you go through your speech while you have addressed Senator West on a number of occasions very directly. Please do it through the Chair and then there will not be any interjections.
—You should stop them talking.
—Order! Senator Walters, when I am giving advice from the chair I ask you to remain silent. You are of no assistance in this matter. Senator Chapman has the floor. I call Senator Chapman.

—I will observe your advice, Mr Acting Deputy President. I say through you that it is a pity that Senator West is not listening to the remarks I am making because they are directly taken from the very ACIL report from which she--
—And the Minister.

—Indeed, it would not hurt the Minister to listen to this very wise comment from this ACIL report, which Senator West quoted in support of the Government's position when the whole basis of the report and the conclusions of the report are that a 15 per cent tax is quite simply not necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: If we proceed further with this ACIL report we will see spelt out very clearly in graph 4.3 that a 15 per cent tax is not necessary and that with prices at 495c a kilogram clean a tax of 8 per cent-again, I wish that Senator West would listen to what I am saying-would quite adequately pay off the debt in some six years. Wool is currently selling at almost 100c per kilogram above that 495c a kilogram clean to which this graph refers. There can be no doubt that a tax of 8 per cent is adequate and a maximum tax of 10 per cent, which the Opposition has suggested would be appropriate, leaves a very healthy and adequate margin for any changes in conditions and changes in assumptions which might later take place.

We also need to remember that even the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, implied in February that the tax would be only 12 per cent. The former Minister, who has supported a tax of 15 per cent in this legislation, acknowledged even at that time, before the more favourable circumstances developed, that a tax of 12 per cent would be adequate.
Despite all of this and all of the subsequent favourable events, Mr Kerin ignored the advice, changed his mind and said, without supporting evidence:
We cannot take the risk of having a tax any less than 15 per cent.
In response to that, I say that we cannot take the risk of sending a large percentage of our woolgrowers broke with the tax at a level of 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear!

—I am glad that Senator Walters and Senator Watson acknowledge that in support. If that happens, it will leave fewer woolgrowers and consequently a lesser amount of tax revenue with which to pay off the wool debt. That will mean that either the repayment term will have to be lengthened or the tax will have to be increased further. Where will that all end? We will simply have a diminishing spiral of woolgrowers paying an ever-increasing rate of tax to pay off this debt. It will result in a vicious spiral in which all players-the growers, the industry and eventually all Australians-will lose.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite incomprehensible that this Government can contemplate imposing a level of tax that would in effect totally wreck Australia's greatest export industry, an industry which is the backbone of this country's economy. Already entire communities and towns have been devastated by the crisis in rural Australia and the effects are flowing on to every sector of the economy. The metropolitan areas of Australia are now starting to feel the effects of this disastrous rural recession and they will certainly feel it more as the months go by. The human element-the personal tragedy-in all of this is incalculable. We already have far too many instances of farming families losing their homes and everything they have worked for all their lives and of family breakdowns and children unable to cope with these pressures.

Not one honourable senator in this chamber would not have been approached by rural people desperate for some assistance and compassion, although perhaps Senator West is the exception. In my State of South Australia rural organisations such as the United Farmers and Stock Owners and the Country Women's Association have made repeated pleas to the Federal and State Labor governments for additional emergency funding for farmers and small business owners, many of whom are unable to qualify for regular social security benefits because of assets restrictions. However, assets do not put food on the table nor do they put shoes on children's feet. Some families have been forced to turn to churches and similar organisations for assistance to pay grocery bills. Others succumb to the frustrations and pressures caused by the economic situation, and there are reports of increasing levels of suicide, attempted suicide, domestic violence, abortion and stress-related illnesses in rural areas.

It often falls to women to keep the family together but they are finding this harder to do as their traditional community support groups break down. Their sense of isolation and despair grows with the realisation that there is no immediate way out of the mess and that the Government simply does not seem to care. Mismanagement by this Labor Government has sent much of Australia to the wall, yet it remains steadfast and seemingly unwilling to face up to the drastically worsening situation. The mismanagement crisis in the Labor camp continues unabated, with individuals fighting over the spoils of leadership like dogs over a bone, insensitive to the hurt and suffering which is the reality out there in the community and which continues to deteriorate daily.

While the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills are the major cause of concern for the coalition-and indeed for the woolgrowers-other issues in this legislation package also deserve comment. First, there is the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, that establishes the Commission, which is to take over the debt of $2.63 billion and a stockpile of about 4.4 million bales of wool. The Commission will be given seven years in which to discharge the debt and dispose of the stockpile and other assets, using what it considers to be the best mix of sales of non-wool assets and wool from the stockpile. As I have already mentioned, the Government has provided a two-year interest-free loan of $200m against future asset sales and has set a very modest target of $20m debt reduction in the first year. I have already highlighted that with recent improvements in the wool market and lower interest rates that target has almost been reached before the scheme has started. The coalition questions whether we really need the Wool Realisation Commission at all.

This legislation will in fact mean that there will be no fewer than five institutions all concerned with administering the wool industry. They are the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the International Wool Secretariat, the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Research and Development Corporation and the Wool Industry Council. Why do we need all these different empires? They will presumably each have boards of directors and administrative support staff, the funding of which will require a substantial percentage of the woolgrowers' tax, leaving less to pay off the debt. Such costs will be astronomical and one wonders how efficient each will be, how much responsibility will overlap the organisations and, indeed, how much empire building and self-interest inherent in such bureaucracies will emerge.

We are also concerned that having a body discrete from the Australian Wool Corporation will create uncertainty and instability in the wool industry. Another concern of ours, and, not surprisingly, a concern of the Australian Wool Council, is the lack of legislative requirement for any of these bodies to consult with the Wool Council. Considering that the woolgrowers are funding the entire operation, it is only proper that their representative body be consulted and kept advised of all actions and decisions undertaken.

With regard to the Wool Realisation Commission, the Wool Council is concerned that the charter the Commission has been given to discharge the debt over the shortest possible time may not be in the best interests of the wool industry or the nation. Once the debt has been repaid and the Commission is wound up, the legislation as it currently stands does not specify that any surplus funds should be returned either to the contributors or to the industry in general. Rather, the wording of the legislation is such that the Minister can distribute any surplus funds outside the wool industry. It would seem that these institutions are being given an enormous amount of responsibility and autonomy with precious little accountability to the very people for whom they are supposed to be working.

The coalition would also like to see an Industry Commission inquiry instituted to investigate the levels and methods of wool promotion and wool marketing, to ensure that the woolgrowers' contribution is being used effectively. There is much evidence that this has not always happened.

We cannot just simply sit and wait for buyers to come to the market; we have to create a demand for wool. When demand outstripped supply and the price of wool soared to 1100c a kilogram back in 1988, manufacturers turned to other cheaper fibres. We not only have to attract those markets back but also have to create alternative ones and find innovative ways of using wool fibres. Let us not forget, however, that it is this Labor Government which is responsible for getting the wool industry into the mess it is in now.

This Labor Government has refused to acknowledge that the industry was in trouble back in 1989. I recall the cavalier way in which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, reacted to the warning I gave in August of that same year of the growing stockpile of wool being purchased by the Wool Corporation.

The grassroots growers in my own State of South Australia are entirely dissatisfied with the past performance of the wool industry statutory organisations. Many of these growers want all the old bureaucracy of the wool industry to be thrown out and they do not want any statutory government bodies running anything. They would rather see the wool industry regulating itself, with only a small statutory body to execute particular tasks, such as contracting for research and development, promotion and statistical investigation.

Many South Australian growers are adamant that they cannot afford this proposed bureaucratic structure provided for in this legislation and they have indicated a willingness to pay a 3 per cent tax for a period of seven years, or until such time as the stockpile is disposed of, whichever is the earlier. These growers' sentiments may be unrealistic on the low side, just as the Government's requirement for a 15 per cent tax is quite unrealistic on the high side. But they are a reflection of general grower reaction across Australia and a reaction to being made responsible for a debt which in many respects was not of their making. But it will not help at this stage to throw recriminations around.

The fact is that a delicate balance must be struck to eliminate both the stockpile and the debt in the briefest possible time without bankrupting the producers and the Australian economy in the process. That is why the coalition is firm in its belief that 10 per cent is the maximum viable tax that woolgrowers can afford and which should be levied through this legislation, coupled with an option to further reduce the flock with a slaughter scheme, if that becomes necessary in the future. That is why we have moved significant second reading amendments which I strongly support and urge the Senate to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than repeat the arguments of the previous nine speakers, at this point I will refer to some of those arguments and attempt to shed a different light on this debate. To begin with, I must say something with regard to Senator Panizza's contribution. I am disappointed he is not in the chamber to hear this because he very seldom receives congratulations from me for bringing something which I think is perfectly accurate to our attention; more often I am in the position of disagreeing with the honourable senator's contributions. But in this case I think it is the first time I have heard somebody actually go public with a list of those people to whom we can ascribe responsibility for this mess in which we now find ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza's list was broad and comprehensive. He included the existing Government-I was disappointed that he did not include previous governments, but I will forgive him for that. He also apportioned some of the blame to the Australian Wool Corporation, the Wool Council of Australia, the banks and the greedy new producers, as he described them-those who had expanded into production in which they had previously not been involved. He also included-and I think wisely so-the greedy stud breeders who took advantage of the demand for extra wool production. He included the Australian Taxation Office, which I thought was most observant of him. The only thing that disappointed me about Senator Panizza's list was the fact that he did not include politicians. I ask the rhetorical question: are we to blame?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, he did.

—He only selectively included them. I suggest that we are all to blame and I suggest that we should put ourselves at the top of the list rather than being an errant last minute inclusion. However, in saying that, I will go on to consider some of the history of this matter. I was surprised that some of the previous speakers did not start their contributions with what I see as being essential to the situation now.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go back to where Senator Archer was-and I appreciated his short lesson about the beginnings of the industry in Tasmania in which his family has honourably and proudly been involved. The recent history is that the Vines committee report recommended earlier this year that a 12 per cent wool tax was necessary to manage the debt and stockpile and that a Government injection of $250m for each of two years was necessary to sustain that position. That second component of the Vines committee's recommendations has lost emphasis in many of the contributions we have heard.

The Government refused to provide that injection. Therefore, in April the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, announced that 15 per cent would be necessary because the Treasury would not move to provide that additional push start in order to reduce the debt overhead and bring it into a manageable state. Of course, it was disappointing for all of those people involved in the wool industry to hear that announcement. As soon as the Australian Democrats became aware of that announcement, I challenged it, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, suggesting that Vines's recommendations had a solid basis for investigation and should be reconsidered by the Minister. But there was no reconsideration. The Government then had the temerity to appoint Vines as the Chairman of the Australian Wool Industry Council, having rejected the two key recommendations contained in his report. What an insult!

Since Vines's rejected recommendations, we have seen the sorts of developments indicated by Senator Crane. He was perfectly accurate and I think his omission was certainly by mistake and not by design. Senator Crane included in his list the fact that the beginning debt will be lower than anticipated by previous commentators, that there are lower interest rates applying to that debt, and that there is lower production. I know that it was by accident that Senator Crane did not include in that list the fact that there are increased average prices. I know that he is well aware of that fact, and that fact has been brought to bear on the situation since the Vines committee report.

These developments lead, I believe, to the position that 12 per cent can be sustained without the $500m injection that was originally proposed by the Vines committee. That is the position of the Australian Democrats. Recent developments have reinforced it, but the Government has not budged from its original position taken at the end of April by Minister Kerin who suggested that 15 per cent would be required.

TALK.START.PARA: —An improvement on the Vines figures.

—It has improved on the Vines figures. The improvement has been that the Vines figure of $500m has been countervailed, counteracted or counterbalanced-whichever expression is most appropriate, but I think it has been counterbalanced-by those developments and the $500m, the second component, is the component which is not now required to substantiate 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the statement just now that the Government did not budge, and I ask the question: what position did the coalition take? I quote from a press release issued by the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, the Deputy Leader of the National Party. It is headed:
Opposition cannot alter wool tax legislation to 12 per cent
The first paragraph states:

The Coalition does not have the power to alter a tax bill and therefore will not be able to meet any demands from the wool industry to reduce the wool levy, according to National Party Deputy Leader . . . Shadow Minister . . . Bruce Lloyd.
It goes on to say:
The amount of levy that growers had to pay would depend on the amount of wool taken out of production and how much growers wanted to pay off the principal debt.
Then there is the other key, the key common element so often seen in coalition policy in this regard:
If 20 million sheep were slaughtered, growers could have a levy of 10 per cent and still pay the $120 million they received for the sale of assets off the debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an old one.

—Yes, that is old. I agree with that. I am asking: what position did the coalition take? This press release is dated 1 May 1991. The reason I have read it is not to glory in how old it is but to ask what was the position that the coalition took at that time. I will develop this as I go along. I will not selectively quote.

SPEECH.PARA: On the next position taken by the coalition I will quote from Hansard of 4 June 1991, page 4679, where Mr Lloyd was speaking in the debate on the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill. Towards the end of that speech Mr Lloyd was granted leave to incorporate tables in Hansard, and I quote from those tables, not from his speech. These are tables which Senator Panizza and, I think, Senator Crane invited us to examine as containing figures which justified their position. The very first figure in that table shows the Australian Wool Corporation debt as $2.63 billion. The note to that states:
The Government's interest free loan of $200m to the AWC effectively means the AWC only has to service $2.43 billion of debt.

I quote that because that $200m is not available to be used to reduce the debt from the beginning. Logic also tells us that if it is used in that way it remains a debt. If it is a loan to the Australian Wool Corporation, and if it is used immediately, it remains a debt. The sum of $200m is still owed. The notion that the Wool Corporation debt can be immediately reduced by $200m by using that is a pure fallacy. That is why I am very wary of using those sorts of figures--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have misunderstood it. Quite seriously, you have misunderstood it.

—I will listen to Senator Walters. I would like Senator Walters to explain to me, by way of interjection, how on earth I can misunderstand that. I will take a note from her, because I am very serious about this. I am not playing politics; I am playing it straight down the line. That $200m is not available to reduce the debt. Those sorts of misunderstandings make it very difficult for us to attach any credibility to the figures that follow, because the figures that follow from that very first figure are all predicated upon it. We have other figures. I have been shown spreadsheets, tallies, betting slips, all attempting to justify tax rates of everything from zero per cent to 30 per cent, covering payment periods from three years to 10 years, and suggested debt obligations from $3.5 billion to total debt write-off.

SPEECH.PARA: The ACIL report has been referred to often in this debate-and there have been many different versions. The report to which I refer was published and sent to us on 7 June. I presume it is the same one referred to by Senator West. I found a different interpretation from that of Senator West. I acknowledge that Senator Chapman quoted thoroughly from the report, but I gained another interpretation from the same report. On the overview page, numbered (i), the first column states:
The Government's analysis, based on information then available, has been demonstrated to imply a 15 per cent wool tax.
I will continue in the same vein that has been canvassed by all coalition speakers:
Recent developments-such as the release of 100,000 bales of AWC stock for sale prior to 30 June and higher than expected wool prices at auction-improve the tax arithmetic.
There is further discussion on that point. Then there is a discussion of varying key assumptions:
* assuming that wool production in 1991/92 reduces at a more rapid rate than expected;
* assuming higher wool prices;
* capitalising the first year's interest into the overall debt level;
* focussing on keeping within the outstanding debt schedule as against meeting minimum debt repayments;
* assuming some wool stockpile sales do occur in 1991-92; and
* re-introducing a flock reduction scheme.
The report continues:

The conclusion is that scope exists to lower the rate of tax in 1991-92 if future revisions in projected wool production show a marked fall; trade clearances are able to be sustained and some stocks sold in 1991-92 or wool prices rise. A central element in this analysis is expected wool production in 1991-92.

It is demonstrated that if wool production falls to 885 mkg or less in 1991-92, with assumptions on price and trade clearances holding and using a conservative $40m from the sale of assets, then the wool tax can be reduced to 12 per cent in 1991-92. At this rate the Government's debt repayment can be met.

I quoted extensively because nearly every sentence I read contained a qualifier such as `if' or `can' or `may'. That is the basis on which we are proceeding: there are many qualifiers in all the assumptions. Even the word `assumption' is one we should not gloss over lightly. We should not base too much upon it. Here we are dealing with the future of Australia's huge wool industry. It is not something to be based on assumptions; it is something that should be based on concrete.

As well as reading that sort of information, the information and the input which I have received-and I have no doubt that other senators have received similar information-is that we have been contacted by those involved in the industry. I would like to read a selection of the information which has been provided to me. I will proceed as quickly as I can through some of them. They come from throughout Australia. I received from Ravensthorpe, Western Australia, a note which says:
Dear Sir,
I produce 220 bales of wool. I pay no Federal income tax. The difference between 10 per cent and 15 per cent wool tax is six months' living expenses . . .
Another letter reads:
Dear Senator,
I am writing to you in an attempt to get you and your Party to reconsider your stance on the tax levels to be legislated on in the proposed Wool Bills that come before the Parliament shortly.
A letter from the Shire of Kellerberrin says:

The Council of the Shire . . . encourages you to support the coalition in its efforts to have the maximum of 15 per cent tax on the Wool Industry reduced to 10 per cent as it believes that the Industry could only stand a 10 per cent impost at this stage . . .
I have another from Cranbrook, Western Australia. It says:
. . . we urge you to do all you can to ensure that the wool tax is abolished.
We cannot continue to pay indirect tax through sales tax and fuel taxes, plus direct taxation, as well as a wool tax.
A heavy tax has already been paid on the wool in the stockpile.
A letter from Esperance says:
As a woolgrower I implore you to do everything in your power to have the proposed wool tax of 15 per cent amended to as low a figure as is sustainable for the wool industry . . .

In view of the fact that the Vines Committee recommended a wool tax of 12 per cent and the final AWC debt is going to be considerably less than was predicted when that report was handed down coupled with the fact that interest rates are now lower it would seem to me that a maximum tax of 12 per cent or less would be easily sustainable.
A letter from the Blackall branch of the Central and Northern Graziers Association states that it held a meeting on 17 May 1981 and that a resolution was passed. I will quote it only in part:
``That we write to relevant Federal politicians and register our strong support for a wool levy of 12 per cent or less and definitely not 15 per cent''.
The Western Australian Farmers Federation writes:
The Western Australian Farmers Federation has previously advised you of its opposition to the Government's proposal to set the wool tax . . . at 15 per cent.
We have argued for some time that a range of factors are now moving in favour of the wool industry and warrant the implementation of a lower tax rate.
The Wool Council has written to me saying:
``The Government's plan for a wool tax of 15 per cent for the next 7 years will ruin a large core of specialist woolgrowers unless prices recover markedly.

``Woolgrowers are focusing on net returns for survival and the proposed tax rate of 15 per cent is in excess of the 12 per cent figure the Minister promoted when he suspended the Reserve Price Scheme.
I have a letter from the Branch President of the Apsley branch of the Victorian Farmers Federation, which says:
The eighty members of the Apsley VFF overwhelmingly support a wool tax significantly below 15 per cent.
Many district farmers are in severe financial difficulty, some already receiving welfare benefits . . .
Note `receiving welfare benefits'. I continue:
Therefore we strongly argue against the unnecessarily high rate of tax proposed and urge you to do your absolute utmost . . .

These notes and letters are innumerable in their mass and embarrassing in their content. It seems that they are from people who are desperate to get their opinion across and most concerned that at least somebody should listen to them. A plethora of journalists have opined on this matter. Most of them have been more concerned with the politics of the matter than with the facts, which should be guiding our political decisions. But I do respect the report on page 5 of today's New South Wales Farmers Association News by that organisation's Executive Officer, Howard Moxham. In part, Howard Moxham refers to the fact that, because of increased prices, the 25 per cent tax which is still applicable has accumulated funds more rapidly than expected, allowing the Corporation to clear approximately $310m of debt by 30 June, 1991. Here is a fact which I am sure the coalition and the Government will both find interesting: `This means that we will be opening the 1991-92 season with an accumulated debt of $2.57m as opposed to the previous $2.88m'. I respect that figure and the justification behind it more than I respect the estimate that was given in the speech I previously quoted from the lower House.

Let me assure those who are interested in this debate, those who are listening and those who will read about it subsequently, that the Australian Democrats have listened to all who have presented their facts, opinions and ideas to us. We have had to call in volunteers. Several volunteers in the last week have been operating from the offices of Democrat senators just to handle the extra load. We welcome the input; that is why we asked extra people to come in to help us with that.

I doubt whether Australia's woolgrowers could have done any more to try to bring their information to us. We have received, as I know other senators have, deputations in person, phone calls, faxes and letters. Any other means of conveying information to us has been taken advantage of. No other issue I have been associated with inside or outside politics has excited such a cross-section of input. It has not been exclusively directed at presenting what I think might be either form letters or suggestions made by members of the coalition; it has simply not had that sort of input. Input has been initiated and generated for all sorts of reasons. I respect people who have responded for whatever reason.

Even so, I still believe that the Government cannot justify its intransigence. So much has changed, I am amazed that no movement has been suggested by the Government. Similarly, I believe that the fundamental flaws made at the beginning of the calculations that were generated by the coalition present an overly optimistic case for the 10 per cent tax. That does frighten me. I believe that the only description for it is a gamble. My optimism is attached to the future of the wool industry and the belief that increased effort given to marketing and sales, especially internationally, will guarantee the future of this industry.

Information from Europe which was gleaned last week was given to me only last night. It suggests that European markets will be eager to buy our wool this year and next and that we will have, as has been expressed in some of the other contributions, a viable, vital industry in the future. But we must not saddle that very industry with either the Government's bludgeoning 15 per cent tax, which will kill the industry, or the coalition's risky 10 per cent, which might allow the debt to grow unmanageably. Therefore, we will propose at the committee stage an amendment to introduce a tax level of 12 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating a package of wool Bills and I wish to make some comments on them. We have heard many honourable senators make excellent contributions to the debate this evening. As a National Party senator from Queensland, I have the honour of representing many Queensland woolgrowers in this place. I know of the parlous financial state in which many of those people find themselves at present. Some of their problems are due not only in part to their industry organisations but also to the many tax burdens placed on them by this Government, including the 25 per cent tax originally imposed by the Hawke Labor Government, about which we complained bitterly. Now it is proposing a 15 per cent tax, never taking into account how hard it will be for so many wool producers to meet a 15 per cent tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The wool industry over time has provided much of our export earnings. Until the troubles of recent years it had been Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. Currently, woolgrowers are facing a future of enormously depressed financial circumstances and they want and need proper assistance before they are irrevocably destroyed.

The Government has a particular obligation to help woolgrowers when one reads of the history of this crisis in the past few years. In light of that history, it is astonishing to read in the second reading speech of the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on this legislation:

It is now a new era. The recriminations and disappointments of the past 18 months should remain in the past, and all efforts and energy should be devoted to building a revitalised and sustainable industry.

If ever there was a case of trying to dissociate oneself from some of the blame for what has happened, the Minister was surely trying to do just that. The origins of this crisis can be traced back to 1987 with the introduction of the Wool Marketing Bill when, in the second reading speech, the then Minister for Science said:

First, the Bill seeks to place the Australian Wool Corporation on a sound commercial footing so that it is equipped to respond now and into the future to the pressures of the market-place. Secondly, the Bill is designed to introduce appropriate arrangements to ensure that the Corporation is fully accountable to industry and government without disturbing its commercial performance.

Those words, I am sure, must come back to haunt the Minister because, no matter how hard he tried to achieve that, he in fact failed, and failed dismally. Until recently, the industry managed to operate a market scheme, a reserve price scheme, very effectively. For 20 years the Australian wool industry benefited from unprecedented price stability. Yet the Government decided to intervene, purely because it was unhappy that money was not going quickly enough into the Treasury coffers to assist Australia's enormous balance of payments problems.

As I told the Senate last year in a number of debates on this issue, nowhere had it been demonstrated, as distinct from asserted, that were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained. Our current wool stockpile is a testament to those predictions.
I said that interference by the Government would only ruin the reserve price scheme and ravage future orderly wool marketing. Yet in June last year the Minister said:

If there is one central message I want to convey to you today, it is the commitment of the Australian industry and the Australian Government to stand behind the decision to lower the floor price and to work to overcome the problems we confront.
He went on to give a cast-iron guarantee that the Government would never again lower the floor price. But the Minister went and did that again in July. He said:
The Government will not contemplate under any circumstances a further downward movement of the floor price.

Yet a few months later he acted to lower the floor price. This is just one of numerous actions for which the Government does have to be held responsible. The sad situation is that this has been a lesson for the Government, an experiment which has impacted adversely on the livelihoods of many farmers. The Government may have wanted to make the industry more commercial; it may have wanted to allow the industry to have more say; but in fact right now it has achieved the exact opposite where the industry, more than ever, has been at the mercy of government. That is probably why some of the solutions being proposed today are being imposed by a government which is really showing very little sensitivity to the problems facing individual growers.

I now turn to the actual legislation, a package of nine Bills that relate to new administrative and management structures and the imposition of a wool tax at the rate of 15 per cent. My major concern with this package is with the level of the levy and the options available to manage the $2.7 billion debt and the 4.7 million bale stockpile held by the Australian Wool Corporation.

Now, once again, as has been the practice over the past few years with the Government in relation to wool, we are debating legislation in the final days of a parliamentary sitting when the legislation has to be in operation by 1 July. It is a most unsatisfactory situation for this most important industry. It comes at a time of great difficulty for people engaged in the industry. All farmers are facing the worst situation since the Depression of the 1930s, and for woolgrowers the worst is still to come.

To give some indication of projections concerning woolgrowers' income, I want to cite some figures from the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly of March. Those figures are already out of date. When one looks at the farm cash operating surplus for the sheep industry one sees that in 1989-90 there was a cash operating surplus of $50,407 per sheep farmer; in 1990-91-the year just ending-it was down to $5,724, a reduction of 89 per cent; and for next year, 1991-92, the projection is a negative figure of minus $626, a further fall by 111 per cent. I am sure that as a woolgrower Senator Panizza would not be very happy with those figures because they are frightening statistics. They show the impact of what is still to come for the woolgrowers of Australia.

This very grave financial situation confronting our woolgrowers emphasises the crucial part of all the Bills before us, that is, the tax level or the levy and the impact that a higher than necessary levy rate can have on thousands of woolgrowers. It can force them off the land by fire sales of their properties. After that, there will be fewer growers to pay out the stockpile debt for the remaining years, with even more pressure on those still remaining.

Large numbers of woolgrowers will have no farm cash operating surpluses in 1991-92. The report of the Vines committee of inquiry into wool marketing recommended a 12 per cent levy, acknowledging that the industry could not cope with a higher levy. Of course, Mr Kerin mislead the growers again when he wrote a letter to all woolgrowers in February implying that the tax would be 12 per cent, which he repeated on a number of occasions. He must have been tarred with the same brush as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who on so many occasions is able to change his mind like he changes his clothes and tell stories that are not true.

This legislation discards those views and has set the tax at 15 per cent. It seems that the former Minister has managed to avoid facing up to his responsibilities since he made that announcement in February. In contrast, the proposal that the coalition has developed for a 10 per cent levy offers flexibility in its detailed analysis. It is credible and will give a lift to the level of confidence of rural communities suffering during this time of national economic depression. It also means considerable savings.

Despite the former Minister's view that there is little difference between a 15 per cent levy and a lower tax, he is clearly wrong. A producer with 5,000 sheep, selling wool at 450c, would pay $10,125 with a 15 per cent tax levy, and $6,750 with a 10 per cent levy. With 10,000 sheep a grower would pay $20,250 with a 15 per cent levy, and $13,500 with a 10 per cent levy. Given that the industry is forecast to have negative incomes in the next season, these figures are obviously very important. They are not insignificant if someone has a negative income. They are stark figures. They may well provide the difference between maintaining viability and being able to keep children at school, which I believe is a very important matter to think about.

Our proposal also has the advantage of applying some discipline on the Australian Wool Corporation and its successor bodies. Also, and most significantly, it does not force growers to go further into debt to try to prop up the Corporation when clearly the Corporation can borrow at a considerably lower rate than individual growers. It is a very responsible position.

The legislation effectively removes the 30 per cent tax on a 700c floor that has become part of the wool scheme following the abandonment of the floor price last year. As we have heard from all other speakers, the proposal from the Government is that woolgrowers around Australia should now be saddled with a 15 per cent tax. This tax could and should be lowered to 10 per cent. Once again, I ask the Government to check the figures, as everybody else in the industry has, and acknowledge that a far lower figure is credible, sustainable and sensible at this time for the future of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the nine wool Bills-the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Amendment Bill, the Wool Tax (Nos 1 to 5) Amendment Bills and the Australian Wool Industry Council Bill-eight of which were introduced by the Government into the House of Representatives and gagged through that House just a fortnight ago. It is because the Government has treated these Bills and the House of Representatives with such disdain that tonight the Opposition has to bring forward so many amendments to right the Government's shoddy legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's aim in this package of Bills is to make sure that, come hell or high water, the Government is not left with one cent to pay out of the debt incurred by its bungling and mishandling of the wool crisis. We all remember the international and domestic promises that were made by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that the floor price would remain, and then that it would be 700c and remain at that. But we are used to the Government repeatedly telling lies. The Government has decided to set the wool levy at 15 per cent. It has done that to ensure that the debt is paid as quickly as possible, but the levy is so high that it will be the last straw that breaks the camel's back-the back of many woolgrowers.

Let us look at the situation our woolgrowers are facing. I hope Senator West particularly will pay attention because her speech did not take any of this into consideration. I hope the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is meant to be taking this Bill, will also take notice. According to the Agriculture and Resources Quarterly for March-we know the new figures are coming out next week-the average farm cash operating surplus for the sheep industry in 1989-90 was $50,407. That is not profit; that is an exemption of the operator's wage or salary and any capital expenditure. In 1990-91 that figure dropped by 89 per cent and came down to $5,724. In 1991-92 it is expected to drop by 111 per cent and will be a minus figure-minus $626-with neither the operator nor his family drawing a salary and with no capital expenditure.

I believe that is a very frightening prospect for all woolgrowers. Imagine what would happen if the waterfront unions were asked to drop a cent. Waterfront workers are on strike already because they are all getting a $12 increase, with a productivity allowance of 6 per cent. They are all on strike over that, not over a 111 per cent drop in their cash operating surplus. It is absolutely frightening. But it extends further because the country towns and the small businesses in those country towns will feel the crisis as the year goes on.

We have a drought covering a lot of the continent, and on my island, Tasmania, it has been a disaster. Our Tasmanian farmers are presently paying $185 a tonne, plus cartage, for wheat to feed their sheep. That, plus the higher interest rates, means that in Tasmania the whole of the wool industry is a disaster. The average specialist woolgrower has 3,625 sheep to a property. What chance does the one-family farm have if the Government insists upon its 15 per cent levy? Is the Government's purpose to get rid of those one-family farms? Is it to make farmers sell up and have fire sales at their properties? It would certainly appear so.

The Opposition has consistently pushed the Government to lower that levy from 15 per cent to 10 per cent. There is no need for that higher figure. Our figures have never been queried. The Government has tried to fault them repeatedly. It has gone through them with a fine tooth-comb, but it has not found one error. We may have made some general assumptions on factual knowledge, and I will mention a few of them. We know that the Wool Corporation debt is $2.63 billion. This is where Senator Bell has become confused as regards the debt and the $200m that the Government has given interest free to bring that debt down to $2.43 billion for servicing purposes. There is no difference between that and what the Government actually intends to do; that is, to pay the servicing debt-the difference between the $2.63 billion and the $2.43 billion-which amounts to $22m each year for two years. I seek leave to have two pages incorporated in Hansard. I showed them to Senator Ray when he was in the chamber.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As I say, our figures have never been queried and, given the background statistics and the general assumptions put forward, we know that our figure of 10 per cent is a very conservative one. Indeed, it comes down to 9.1 per cent because we have an additional comfort zone, if one cares to call it that, of 0.9 per cent, making the levy a total of 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The table covers two other scenarios. The first is with a slight increase in price. That increase was from 447c a kilogram. We say, maybe it will bring 475c a kilogram-still with the same long term interest rate of 10.75 per cent which the Wool Corporation can certainly get. With that scenario, the levy could be down as far as 8.7 per cent. But, if one takes account of the falling interest rates, and should the interest rate come down to 9.75 per cent and we go back to the very conservative price of 447c a kilogram clean, we could bring the levy down to 8.2 per cent. The table is now incorporated in Hansard and the situation will be clarified for that reason.

The former Minister in the other place has said that the difference between the 15 per cent tax and the 10 per cent tax was just `a few hundred dollars'. That is an extraordinary statement for the Minister to make because it is not accurate. We know-and it has been quoted today in this debate-that at 500c clean a kilogram, with a farm of 5,000 sheep, the tax is $11,250 at 15 per cent and $7,500 at 10 per cent, a difference of $3,750 or $72 a week. That is not much to the Minister or Senator West. They should go and tell the farmers that they do not need that $3,750 when, according to the estimate we have, their farm operating surplus is a minus figure of $626. They should go out and tell the farmers that they do not need that $3,750.

The Opposition has included in its figures-and this was a controversial issue as far as Senator West was concerned-the $120m sale of the Wool Corporation's non-wool assets. The Government has refused to sell that amount of assets. In an interjection Senator West said, `What about their cash flow?'. All I can say to Senator West is that she has obviously never had that feeling of going broke. Let us not forget that the Corporation belongs to the woolgrowers, not to the Government. If the woolgrowers are going broke they start selling their non-wool assets, particularly if they are bringing in an interest rate of between 14 and 16 per cent because they know they can be sold at a good price. If one is going broke one sells one's assets; one does not just go broke because one wants to have a cash flow. I have never heard of anything quite so startling from someone who is meant to be supporting the woolgrowers in her particular State.

Senator West was talking about Senator Panizza referring to a 6 per cent levy. She did not understand that Senator Panizza was talking about a 6 per cent levy to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. A 6 per cent levy to the Realisation Commission excludes the 4 per cent tax on promotion and research and development which would bring the 6 per cent and 4 per cent to 10 per cent. That was exactly what Senator Panizza was talking about.

I now move to the various committees. The Australian Wool Realisation Commission will manage the stockpile, the Australian Wool Corporation will manage promotion, the Wool R and D Corporation will manage research and development and the Wool Industry Council will advise the Government. Why we cannot amalgamate the Realisation Commission and the Wool Corporation, I have no idea. Surely the same body could manage the stockpile and promotion. Both these corporations are funded by the woolgrowers; they are not funded by the Government. I do not understand why the Government wants two bodies to do something that one could do quite easily.

It is also important that the body have a pre-specified volume of wool to be sold from the stockpile, otherwise no planning is possible. I hope that the Australian Democrats will support our amendments. I will be interested to see how the Government reacts to the many amendments that are being put forward by the Opposition.

Of the Labor senators who are present in the chamber and are interested in this Bill, only the Minister and Senator West have spoken on the legislation. I do not know whether honourable senators opposite have given up, knowing that the woolgrowers will not vote for them anyway, but I will be most interested to see the reaction of the Government to the amendments the shadow Minister will move on behalf of the Opposition.
