DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION COMMISSION BILL 1991AUSTRALIAN WOOL CORPORATION BILL 1991PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1991PRIMARY INDUSTRIES (INDUSTRY COUNCILS) BILL 1991WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1991AUSTRALIAN WOOL INDUSTRY COUNCIL BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating a package consisting of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill and eight other Bills related to the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the latest legislation on the wool industry, I emphasise once again my support of a consistent and responsible coalition attitude which gives priority to the welfare of the woolgrowers and the long term future of the industry.

The Hawke Labor Government has displayed a careless and short-sighted attitude in its insistence on a 15 per cent wool tax, without full consideration of its necessity or its effect on woolgrowers. Sadly, only one Labor senator has contributed to the debate tonight. Unfortunately, Senator West's contribution was probably one of the most unbelievable speeches I have ever heard anyone make on such an important subject. It is sad that Senator West has been left to carry the can, because clearly she does not know anything about the wool industry. I remember making that same statement quite some time ago when dealing with the same subject. Senator West then came in and took a personal explanation, saying that her brother owned a truck or something and that she knew a lot about the industry.

I think the wool industry itself will be able to draw a conclusion tonight on the sad state of intransigence now taken by the Government on this 15 per cent wool tax. As I say, the Government has not taken into consideration the effect this tax will have on the growers. The Opposition asked the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to seek from his Department and from producer organisations an estimate as to how many woolgrowers will be forced into substantial negative incomes and rendered non-viable through the imposition of a 15 per cent wool tax as opposed to a tax rate set at 10 per cent. But we cannot get an answer to that question; the Minister will not provide it because he knows, as we do, that the response to that is damning.

It is as if both the former Minister and his successor decided that they would impose an unnecessarily high tax in order to wash their hands of the problem in the short order and avoid detailed examination of the issue. Their only objective appears to the liquidation of the $2.4 billion debt in the shortest possible time. Regardless of whether that is practical or not, it is nonetheless their only objective. We all agree that this is an essential objective, but the coalition knows that the task of a responsible government is to avoid driving growers to the wall when this can be avoided. The Government is now seeking the repayment of the debt in five rather than seven years but is carefully concealing this fact from the growers. Surely, a seven-year repayment period is in the interests of Australia if it results in less devastation of a key industry.

This is an objective which apparently may now be shared by the purported friends of the woolgrower-the Australian Democrats-who accuse the coalition of being irresponsible. Having listened to Senator Bell's contribution tonight, I hope the Australian Democrats may now see reason and act in the best interests of the woolgrowers and the wool industry generally.

It is a very strange objective to apply to a carefully assessed proposal for a 10 per cent wool tax from a party that last month was gung ho to spend an extra $1.2 billion on Austudy. I hope when it comes to the critical time to vote tonight that the Democrats will understand the importance of this to the wool industry. The Government knows that the report of the Vines Committee of Inquiry into the Wool Industry and the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council made it clear that any wool tax above 12 per cent would be a disastrous slug for a great many growers as they adjust to the new and inevitable discipline of a free market in wool-a reality that the coalition has supported. The former Minister made the bland statement that a 15 per cent tax would result in:
. . . no farm cash operating surplus in 1991-92.

But he claimed that the level of the tax would make only a few hundred dollars difference. He might as well have said that if growers are going down the drain they might as well go down a bit faster for all that the Australian Labor Party cares.

We are trying to avoid having any of them going down the drain at the rate that they are going at the moment. If it is the Government's objective to reduce the number of woolgrowers by the 15 per cent tax rather than through market forces, let it say so, but that is not what Senator West said tonight. She has not admitted one way or the other. She has just put the Government line that a 15 per cent tax is quite appropriate, regardless of whether that sends many of the woolgrowers to the wall.

I come back to the simple arithmetic that has been mentioned here tonight by many of the Liberal-National Party speakers. A producer with 5,000 sheep selling wool at 450c a kilogram would pay $10,125 with a 15 per cent tax compared with the $6,750 under the coalition proposal of a 10 per cent tax. If this Government thinks that that $3,750 would not make a big difference to a family farm income, it really shows how out of touch it is. Once again, Senator West, as the only contributor from the Labor Party, did not address that and did not admit one way or the other that over $3,000 would be a significant saving to any wool producer.

This Government does not stop to consider that, if so many farm incomes are cut by several thousand dollars each, it can mean the difference between pulling through and adding to the dole queues. Lower incomes mean more expenditure on family allowance and the family allowance supplement, but has any of that been taken into consideration in tonight's debate by Senator West? No, not at all.

On a wider basis, the lower Great Southern region of Western Australia has over 10 million sheep producing 49 million kilograms of wool for an income of $220m at a price of 450c per kilogram. With a wool tax of 15 per cent over a year, $33m of disposable income is lost to the region, not merely to the individual grower families. Quite frankly, the state of Western Australia at the moment is so critical that it can ill afford to lose a further amount of money along those lines for particularly blinkered reasons. A 10 per cent tax would limit this to $22m-still a highly unacceptable figure in the longer term. But that is the difference-we are looking at $11m between the 15 per cent level and the 10 per cent level of tax.

The proposal for a 10 per cent tax is realistic when interest rates at last are falling consistently, and wool prices are rising to a level now of 580c per kilogram clean. It is realistic in the context of a reduction of supply closer to demand levels, with a likely production figure of 850 million kilograms rather than 900 million. This figure might have been further reduced in 1991-92 had not the sheep slaughter scheme been prematurely terminated, having reduced numbers by 11 million.

The coalition figures, however, do not depend upon a revival of the slaughter scheme. It is certainly not at all the best option, and I know that there are many woolgrowers in Western Australia who are very anti the slaughter scheme. For that reason, we are certainly not looking at the revival of such a scheme. It is realistic to be advocating a 10 per cent tax of which 6 per cent will be for debt reduction when we have produced the figures that show its feasibility. It was, after all, the realism of the coalition last year that put paid to the prospect of wool quotas that would have destroyed the industry.

It is becoming more apparent that the Government is placing savage pressure on the wealth producers-the woolgrowers-rather than pushing the new wool bureaucracies to play a more positive role. Where is the requirement placed on the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) to realise more of its assets, conservatively valued at $290m? Immediately prior to my speaking, my colleague Senator Walters quite clearly made the point that if people are going broke they do not just hold on to their assets.

That is the point that Senator West failed to comprehend tonight, in saying that it was not important for the assets to be sold. They must sell the assets and they must do it quickly. The coalition would insist upon the sale of $120m in the non-wool assets of the AWC, 70 per cent of which are not actually used to store wool and are readily saleable. This figure amounts to a substantial part of the difference between a wool tax of 10 per cent rather than 15 per cent.

What this legislation offers is not real reform that would give growers a chance to compete in the world of real prices and real demand, but mere reorganisation. The coalition supports the excision of research and development from the AWC but it does not see how costs will be contained and the interests of the wool industry enhanced through creating a Wool Realisation Commission separate from the AWC. It is all very clumsy and very concerning to the woolgrowers of Australia. Growers in Western Australia are telling me that they have had enough of corporations and bureaucracies and that they want to get on with producing wool and selling it at a price that the market will bear.

Even if the Government and the Democrats see sense and support the coalition proposals, we would not simply believe that this solves the problem. A 10 per cent tax still represents a big slice of grower income which growers can ill spare when in March it was predicted that the farm cash operating surplus for the sheep industry would average minus $626 in 1991-92-a reduction of 111 per cent from the modest $5,724 in 1990-91. Consideration simply must be given to new initiatives in the disposal of the stockpile. The proposal of a wool zero coupon bond that would enable individual growers to share this task deserves full scrutiny.

The Senate has the responsibility of choosing the option that best allows Australian woolgrowers to survive and compete in the free market and the Liberal and National parties have economic logic on their side in urging that the wool tax be cut to 10 per cent. I am very concerned that the only contribution made by the Government tonight has been so blinkered. I hope that before this debate is concluded the Government will eventually see reason and see the economic logic behind our proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Second reading amendments have been moved to two of the nine Bills and I propose to put the question--
—Senator McMullan is not even going to respond.
—That is unbelievable.
—There is a slight misunderstanding. Senator Bolkus is on his way to the chamber to respond. That is the point I was trying to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am on the list to speak to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991 and allied Bills. I had indicated that in order to save time I would not speak at this late hour but, if I may, I will speak for a short period. This debate has been a very interesting one. Honourable senators have made a number of extraordinarily good speeches during the second reading stage with which I have been impressed.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a question with which I have been struggling for some years. I have been interested to hear the tribal warfare that has been going on about this issue for several years. I have viewed with growing concern the uncertainty that has been developing in the industry. It is not entirely the fault of the Parliament but, as I think Senator Bell said, we do have to share some of the responsibility. Again, it is all very well to say this in hindsight, I guess, but, having seen what has occurred in the wool industry, I think we should be very careful when matters such as this come before us. I believe we should err on the side of caution and in favour of the woolgrowers-on the side of certainty.

It was summed up fairly well by Senator Bell. In a contribution that I believe was equal to the high standards of the Parliament he made the point: are we going to have a situation where we agree with the Government's 15 per cent, which would absolutely ruin thousands of woolgrowers? Are we going to have a situation where we support the Opposition amendment? If that is agreed to, Senator Bell considers it might mean an unmanageable debt situation arising. Or are we going to support the Democrats' proposition of 12 per cent? I think he put a very strong case before the Senate.

I put it to Senator Bell that he and I and others have received many submissions and representations from woolgrowers and others on the effect of 15 per cent and even of 10 per cent. It is my view that we ought to err on the side of caution on this occasion in giving the woolgrowers the benefit of the doubt. If it is found that all the factors upon which the assumption of the Opposition is based do not come about, this matter can be reconsidered by the Parliament. That is the view I have adopted.
As to the second reading amendment put forward by the Opposition, I have some problem with (c), which reads:
calls on the Government to support a properly managed industry funded flock reduction scheme to be introduced if and when the industry agrees such a scheme is necessary.

My concern has been compounded by some of the things Opposition senators have said in the second reading debate, including the contribution of Senator Panizza, which I was interested to hear. He said, and indeed it was repeated by others, that our wool is going to be in demand in the foreseeable future. If we look at the situation now with the recent autumn drop, there is about a 20 per cent reduction, as I understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Early figures show that.
—Early figures show about a 20 per cent drop now. If our wool is going to be in demand, I do not know what the Opposition is doing putting (c) in the second reading amendment.
—That is only if it is necessary. Naturally, it would not be necessary if your scenario is correct.

—I understand what Senator Walters is saying, but I have some problem with that. I know a number of woolgrowers have a problem with the type of flock reduction that might be envisaged. As a matter of fact, last year when farmers were shooting their sheep I put to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) a proposition that some of our aid money should be paid to the farmers so that the sheep could be properly slaughtered and the food then packed and sent to countries as food aid.
—That made too much sense.

—I acknowledge that interjection. Admittedly, it was a costly exercise, but in my view it would have been well worth it, because the cost would have been redistributed amongst the rural community and of benefit to persons in developing countries; in particular, countries with a food shortage. I see that the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, is in his place and I now yield to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for a very timely and useful intervention, as most of his interventions are. I am sure that most of the points that I need to respond to now will come up in the course of amendments in the committee stage, so I do not think I need to go to those points in any great detail. A point that really needs to be gone to at this stage is the question of how we determine the most appropriate tax rate for the industry. In this respect, it is obvious that the Government had to weigh two competing objectives. The first was a need to ensure the continued viability of the Australian wool industry. That objective, of course, is of primary concern to all honourable senators. The second was a need to protect the liability of the Commonwealth-and, in turn, the contingent liability of the taxpayers-for the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax rate is only one part of the overall stock release and debt management strategy which the Government has put in place. The strategy has had the objective of maximising the benefits to society, but most particularly to the wool industry, from the disposal of the stockpile, while limiting the liabilities faced by the general taxpayer and woolgrowers. Any change to one component of the plan would place pressure on other components and so threaten the achievement of the objective of the plan.

What the Government has done has been based very much on the latest Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) forecasts of a reduction in the tax rate from 15 per cent to 10 per cent and the assessment by that organisation that such reduction would increase the gross returns, production-time prices, to the average specialist woolgrower by $2,480 in 1991-92. Given that farmers adjust their expenditure in response to higher returns, the corresponding increase in farm cash operating surplus is consequently $1,350.

We recognise that there have been some changes to forecasts underlying the tax rate calculations. We also recognise that there is some risk involved in adjusting these forecasts. We recognise also that additional stocks would need to be sold. This would force down wool prices for growers, consequently reducing their incomes or, alternatively, the tax rate would need to be increased in 1992-93. It has not been an easy decision. It is one where we have to balance the interests of the farming community with the liability on the community in general. In doing so, we have to take into account the longer term viability of the woolgrowing community. A continuation of market growth of recent stocks and accelerated debt repayment may enable the tax rate to be revised downwards in 1992-93.

A number of scenarios have been developed. These can be developed, and they can suggest that a lower tax rate could be applied, but these scenarios, as people should recognise, are often based on additional wool being sold from stocks in 1991-92. The trouble with these scenarios is that they often ignore the effect on prices of the release of this additional wool. Based on the analysis conducted by ABARE, farm income in the short run is lower under a low tax and high stock release strategy compared with a high tax and low stock release strategy. That is a primary consideration that we have taken into account, and we have concluded that considerable risk is associated with adopting a tax rate lower than 15 per cent in 1991-92.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are crazy.
—Senator Archer might say `crazy', but what he cannot deny is that the Government's assessments in this area have been made on the best statistical evidence produced to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I made a mistake; I overestimated Opposition senators' capacity for analysis. There is considerable risk associated with adopting a tax rate lower than 15 per cent in 1991-92, although there may be scope for reviewing the tax rate in future years.
—Why won't you sell the assets of the Corporation?

—Senator Walters is making the point-it was made earlier by, amongst others, Senator Tambling-and that is: why do we not sell the assets of the Wool Corporation at an appropriate rate? We have not gone into this without assessing that sort of situation and, in assessing it, the Government does expect that the wool store assets will be sold over the next two years-and that, I think, has been recognised in the debate. As to those particular sales and details of them, they will be very much a matter for the Commission's commercial judgment. The present AWC has estimated that, in respect of property sales, there could be of the order of $40m in 1991-92-and one cannot deny that particular assessment.
—That is lovely! If you're going broke just sell $40m, not $120m. Go broke rather than sell the $120m. You really are hopeless.
—I really worry about the day that you will not be here, Senator Walters, because I will really miss your bons mots!
—Minister, would you address your remarks through the Chair, please?

—The basic point is that we have to recognise what is happening in the market and we also have to ensure that the balance is right. That is what this Government is quite concerned about. In an uncertain property market, the point I am making--
—Sell them up in a fire sale.
—When the honourable senator opposite has quite finished, I will just proceed. But if she wants to continue, it is okay with me. It is only eating into her time.
—Come on, get on with it.
—Senator Tambling has asked me to get on with it. If Senator Walters just stays off for a minute, I will get on with it.
—Can't you cope?
—Can't I cope? This is the least of my problems in the last 16 years.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, will you please address your remarks through the Chair and avoid the provocation from my left.
—Yes. Madam Chair, what they have to recognise is that, in an uncertain property market it is very--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that was worth laughing at, but I did not quite pick it up. In an uncertain property market, it is very difficult to accurately predict which wool stores might actually be sold and the timing of such sales. I am sure that other people recognise that. To rely on any particular level of sales in order to get the wool tax rate below 15 per cent is, of course, taking a considerable risk. In the Government's view, it was not appropriate to take that risk because, if the assets could not be sold in line with expectations, this would result in increased and unnecessary pressure on future property sales and wool tax rates. It is basic economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, if the wool tax were set too low and the expected property sales did not eventuate in the first year, of course, as people should recognise, the tax would have to be increased in future years. What we are not about and what no side of this Parliament should be about is a fire sale of assets. A fire sale of assets--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about the reserves?

—Given the instruction from the Chair, I have decided that I will not respond to any more interjections, so Senator Crane can go on if he likes. But a fire sale of assets for the sake of getting a particular value from sales next year is not-and I underline `not'-the optimum way of disposing of the assets and is not in the best interests of the woolgrowing industry. That should be recognised. It is recognised out there. We recognise the difficulties of selling assets in the property market and, for this reason, we are facilitating a $200m interest- free loan for two years to cover expectations of property sales over the two-year period.

SPEECH.PARA: In making our decisions we have had to balance expectations against risk and make the best judgment we can. The decision to have a 15 per cent wool tax for 1991-92 is of course the best judgment, and I am sure it stands up to sustainable scrutiny.

In the course of this debate tonight, we have heard those opposite making repeated comments on the average effect of their 10 per cent tax rate and of the Government's 15 per cent rate. It is based on an assessment of average growers and the number of sheep they have. If one goes back through the debate, it is interesting to note that there is some divergence in the average number of sheep. Senator Crane mentioned 5,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not; I mentioned a thousand.

—That is good enough for me. Senator Panizza mentioned 6,000; Senator Crane's figure goes somewhere between 1,000 and 10,000. What no Opposition senators can deny is that the average number of sheep owned by woolgrowers Australia-wide is only 3,740. Those opposite can make all their assessments, but the basic problem is that by overstating the size of the average grower's stock the Opposition overstates the effect of its amendment. That does the industry and the taxpayer no good. I am sure that anyone who rationally assesses the debate tonight will come to that conclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point those opposite make is that their figures have never been queried. They have been queried; they have been queried by the Government, the Australian Democrats and the media, condemned by ACIL, and disagreed with by the AWC and the WCA. That in itself is a fairly comprehensive list of those who disagree with their assessments. As the Government has said repeatedly, the figures Opposition senators use on which to base their assessment are quite spurious and rubbery and they are not figures that we would refer to. I will not go much further in respect of this matter, but I do make that point.

This Parliament should be concerned about making an assessment of the future viability of the industry. It is one that looks not to immediate political gain and populism but very much to the underlying economics of the industry and the underlying economic future viability of it. It is very easy, as we often see in this place, to run the populist line. This Government is not about that. Obviously, extremely important issues are involved here. No degree of cynicism from the other side will undermine the fact that this Government is concerned about ensuring the future economic viability of an industry which has gone through hard times. Those opposite might come in here and promise fools gold to that part of the Australian economy. For some people it may be receptive, but to those who are involved in the running of the industry and ensuring its future economic viability their arguments do not hold water.

In respect of other points raised in this debate, it is probably best for me to tailor my responses to the amendments that are moved by both the Opposition and the Democrats in this debate. I will not go much further at this point, but I make it clear that the amendment to the second reading moved by the Opposition is one that is not supported by the Government.

I therefore now put the question that the amendment moved by Senator Tambling in respect of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991 be agreed to.
