SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, definition of ``Commission auditor'', lines 32 to 36, omit the definition.
2. Clause 3, page 2, definition of ``company auditor'', lines 37 and 38, omit the definition.
5. Clause 64, pages 28 and 29, line 17 (page 28) to line 11 (page 29), omit ``Commission auditor'' (wherever occurring), substitute ``Auditor-General''.
6. Clause 65, page 29, lines 12 to 36, omit the clause.
7. Clause 66, pages 29 and 30, line 37 (page 29) to line 2 (page 30), omit the clause.
8. Clause 71, page 32, subclause (3), lines 12 and 13, omit ``Commission auditor'', substitute ``Auditor-General''.
9. Clause 71, page 32, subclause (4), line 26, omit ``Commission auditor'', substitute ``Auditor-General''.

These amendments relate to the issues that we have raised in the second reading debate concerning the role of the Auditor-General and the audit functions that apply to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. As the Committee is aware, this issue was raised in a specific report to the chamber by the Auditor-General which related particularly to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill. That report of the Auditor-General was entitled Potential Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament.

I have made extensive comments in my second reading contribution in this regard, and I am sure that other senators will be aware that concerns were raised on this matter yesterday in the Senate by Senator Short, Senator Bishop, Senator Crane and Senator Watson. Some very important points of principle relate to this matter, and I believe that the amendments that I have outlined would address those issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -As Senator Tambling has said, the question of the audit function in relation to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill and allied Bills has been the subject of fairly considerable debate in the chamber both yesterday and again during the second reading debate, including in particular by Senator Tambling, today. I support Senator Tambling in the amendments he has moved on behalf of the Opposition. They all relate to the question of the role of the Auditor-General as far as the audit function is concerned in relation to these Bills, but because of the way the audit function has been treated in these Bills I think the issue has a much wider implication than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General was sufficiently concerned at the audit provisions contained in this Bill to report in great urgency to the chamber yesterday, drawing attention to the provisions in this Bill in relation to audit. The covering letter from the Auditor-General to the President and Mr Speaker states:
The Bills proposing the creation of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission-
and also the Australian Wool Corporation-
have serious implications for accountability to Parliament.
That is a very serious concern expressed by the Auditor-General, and in his report he goes into this matter in some detail.

I would just like to summarise again the issue that concerns both the Auditor-General and the Opposition which is that this Bill makes provision for there to be other than the Auditor-General as the auditor of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. That decision, and that provision in the Bill, is contrary to the decision of the Government last year when it responded to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report on the mandate of the Australian National Audit Office. At that stage, when responding to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Government said that the Auditor-General should be the auditor of all government-owned or controlled entities unless, in respect of statutory marketing authorities and government enterprises, there were special circumstances dictating the appointment of an external auditor.

The Auditor-General makes the point that there is no explanation given either in this Bill, in the second reading speech by the Minister or in the explanatory memorandum, as to what special circumstances may dictate the requirement for an external auditor other than the Auditor-General in the case of this Commission-and also in the case of the Australian Wool Corporation which is covered in the next Bill we are considering. Not only is there no explanation but also the way in which the clauses of the Bill are worded is such that in the Auditor-General's opinion-and the Opposition agrees with this-there is a bias against the Auditor-General.

Under the provisions of the Bill, the Minister for Finance is not required to justify granting an exemption from audit by the Auditor-General; nor is he required, as I have said, to outline what special circumstances dictate such action. But, on the other hand, if the Minister for Finance agrees in principle to the appointment of a company or private auditor, the Minister for Finance must explain the reasons why he does not go ahead and appoint such an auditor. In other words, the onus of indication as to the reasons for not having a private auditor is quite different from the provisions relating to the appointment of the Auditor-General as the auditor.

The Opposition is concerned that there is every indication in the drafting of this Bill that the Auditor-General's mandate is weakened and, therefore, the audit function in relation to the scrutiny of public moneys and the scrutiny of the audit of public moneys by this Parliament is weakened. On 14 June the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, wrote to the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor-who had raised his concerns about this matter with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) on 6 June, following introduction of the Bills on 31 May-saying, amongst other things, that on the advice of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel it was proper to include in the Bills the processes to be followed regarding the appointment of a company auditor should such a possibility be contemplated at some future time. He went on to say:

While I note your comments I consider that it is unlikely that a company auditor would be considered for the Commission or Corporation being established by these Bills. Nevertheless, I believe that the provisions of the Bills are appropriate and consistent with the Government's decisions.

Those are the decisions in response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts last year. They are very weak reasons for including these clauses in the Bill. At face value, these clauses weaken very considerably the mandate of the Auditor-General. They therefore weaken very considerably the scope for parliamentary scrutiny of the expenditure of public moneys.

For those reasons, on behalf of the Opposition, Senator Tambling has moved for the deletion of reference to any other auditor for the Commission's accounts other than the Auditor-General. I think that that is the right and proper way to go if we in this Parliament believe in the role of the Auditor-General and the importance of the Parliament as a scrutineer of public moneys and the expenditure of public moneys. For that reason, I very strongly support Senator Tambling's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I signified in my contribution to the debate yesterday on the motion that the Senate take note of the report by the Auditor-General that we were concerned to receive that report. That report addressed these very concerns which have been expressed in this particular debate by Senator Short. Rather than elaborate, I think that speaks for itself. We support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes all these amendments. I find it quite curious that an opposition which in so many other areas believes in-I go very much to my own area of administrative services-the concept of contracting out--
—Oh, get it right! The Opposition believes in the sovereignty of parliament. That is what it is all about.

—I will tell Senator Watson about the sovereignty of parliament in a minute. For an opposition which believes in the concept of contracting out, an opposition which believes so much in the concept of allowing the private sector to contract for government work, an opposition which within those parameters believes that departments, corporations and government business enterprises should still be responsible to this Parliament, I find it quite strange that the Opposition is moving these sorts of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Tambling will attest, I quite often go to the Northern Territory and to Darwin. The number of times I have had shoved into my face the fact that the private sector up there should be getting more and more government work from my Department and from others is immeasurable.

Through this proposal the Government is saying, `Yes, the Auditor-General is the primary source of advice in this area, but if the Wool Corporation chooses to go elsewhere, it can do so. Within the overall parameters, whatever auditor is finally chosen, that auditor's report will be made public through the annual report to this Parliament, providing for parliamentary accountability'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is good enough, is it?

—Senator Watson can babble on over there, but the point is that there will still be parliamentary accountability, although the Wool Corporation will be able to choose whichever auditor it likes. I find the Opposition's inconsistency on this issue amazing. It is quite hypocritical of the Opposition to propose that we should lock in the Auditor-General when so often it is put to me that my own Department, which is a service provider for government, should go to the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is proposing something which I would well imagine the Australian Democrats would oppose; something which a few people in the Labor Party that I am aligned to would oppose, I must admit; but it is something which I am quite stunned that the Opposition would oppose. The Opposition is being totally inconsistent and hypocritical. The AWC can choose, if it so desires-but with primary obligation to the Auditor-General-whichever auditor it likes, and that person's audits will be made public through the annual report and will come through to this Parliament, therefore providing for public accountability. The hypocrisy of Opposition senators overawes me.
The Government opposes all the Opposition's amendments and finds it quite strange that it has proposed this anti-private sector view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) kindly table the reasons, under the guidelines established by his Government, for the Auditor-General not being at least the supervising auditor in respect of the corporations to be established by this legislation? I think the Parliament is entitled to that explanation under the guidelines established by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will table a letter from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, to the Auditor-General about the Government's position on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 21, page 11, lines 26 and 27, omit from ``in'' to ``industry'', substitute ``either to the contributing levy payers or to the benefit of Australian woolgrowers generally, as the Minister determines after consultation with the Wool Council and other representatives of the wool industry''.

This is an important amendment and an important principle. Due to the fact that funds remaining after the debt is paid belong to the woolgrowers, it is obvious that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy should be restricted to refunding the money either to the contributing levy payers or for the benefit of woolgrowers generally if the amount is too small to be divided equitably. I am sure the Minister for Administrative Services would be well aware of the representations in this regard received by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy from the Australian Wool Council. Important points of principle are involved. The Opposition has certainly received those representations and accepts them as valid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this amendment. The important principle here relates to those who have contributed to the equity of the stockpile as it exists at the moment. This amendment will ensure that that equity is preserved and redistributed as equitably as possible to those who have the equity. I do know what I am speaking about; it does make sense.

SPEECH.PARA: At this hour I shall not go any further. The effect will be that those woolgrowers who have a stake in the stockpile will have that stake returned to them at the appropriate moment if at the end of this process there are moneys to be disbursed. For that reason and also because of the sensible wording of the amendment, we support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I make it clear that although we did not divide on the previous range of amendments, the Government is very much opposed to them for the reasons I set out. That opposition will, I expect, be put into effect in the House of Representatives when this Bill next emerges there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is opposed to this amendment, as the Opposition and the Australian Democrats would expect. There have been discussions with the Australian Democrats and I understand that it might be difficult to get to a final position, but we are surprised at the position taken tonight by the Australian Democrats.

The Government's position is that the amendment moved by Senator Tambling is too prescriptive. In the second reading speech we made it very clear that the surplus will be disposed of in the manner which `best benefits woolgrowers'. In making that commitment, we take into account that we do not want legislation that is too prescriptive, and we also take into account the fact that to keep records to allow such redistribution to the levy payers could cost somewhere in the vicinity of $1m.

The Government has made that commitment. It is a commitment that has been expressed in the second reading speech and it is one that we think is substantial enough in itself. I know that the Opposition is not happy with that, but the basic point is that we are committed to ensuring that the best outcome for woolgrowers is achieved and one that is not overburdened with administrative prerequisites. So we do oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of equitable arguments advanced on this side of the chamber and I am sorry that the Government has not accepted them with equanimity.

—I briefly put on record that in matters of debate concerning the wool industry and a number of other primary industry sectors in this place it has been the strong record of the Australian Democrats to move in the interests of those industries and of the growers and the producers. I cannot understand why the Minister seems surprised that in this case we would do that. We have had a consistent position. Indeed, if the Opposition had been with us and the woolgrowers on another occasion, this problem might never have happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one point relating to what the Minister said about keeping records of levy payers. Records are being kept to date; records are kept by the wool brokers. So the Corporation need not keep those records if it does not want to. The records have been kept up to date. A simple extension of that would not hurt. Any of the brokers have those records in their computers at any time, and that has helped out with the supplementary payments scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. Clause 32, page 16, subclause (2), lines 1 and 2, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:
``(2) Before preparing a corporate plan, the Commission must consult with the Wool Council of Australia and may consult with any other representative of the wool industry as it thinks fit.''.

This again is an important aspect of the proposals that were made to the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats by the Australian Wool Council. What it proposes is certainly consistent with the requirement on other representative bodies or statutory marketing authorities to consult with their respective peak community councils and therefore is consistent with what should be done. I commend it to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment. We believe that the consultation which should occur is as described in this amendment. We believe that it is necessary to put it in this legislation to ensure that it occurs with the Wool Corporation. That consultation should take place regardless of which party is in government at the time, and it should be ensured by this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position on this amendment is as expressed in the House of Representatives. We of course have no problem with the Australian Wool Council being consulted. In fact, that will happen as a matter of course. The Government's intention, as expressed in clause 30 (2), is that we want to broaden the consultative processes to industry at large. In doing so we would include the Wool Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic point is that we would not, as would be the intent of the amendment of the Opposition, see the Wool Council as the one body to consult with: we would consult broadly and widely throughout the industry. That is specifically why we are opposing this amendment. We will not call for a division on this item, but we do express our very strong opposition to it.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, definition of ``company auditor'', lines 28 and 29, omit the definition.
2. Clause 3, pages 2 and 3, definition of ``Corporation auditor'', line 41 (page 2) to line 3 (page 3), omit the definition.
6. Clause 76, pages 33 and 34, line 29 (page 33) to line 23 (page 25), omit ``Corporation auditor'' (wherever occurring), substitute ``Auditor-General''.
7. Clause 77, pages 34 and 35, line 24 (page 34) to line 7 (page 35), omit the clause.
8. Clause 78, page 35, lines 8 to 14, omit the clause.
9. Clause 93, page 41, subclause (3), lines 5 and 6, omit ``Corporation auditor'', substitute ``Auditor-General''.
10. Clause 93, page 41, subclause (4), line 19, omit ``Corporation auditor'', substitute ``Auditor-General''.

Again I seek to aggregate the consideration of several areas. We have an identical argument to that presented on the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill with regard to the principal issue of the use of the Auditor-General and audit matters generally. The identical argument and principles apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats support the amendments.

—How does the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, come to the conclusion: `I consider that it is unlikely that a company auditor would be considered for the Commission or Corporation being established under this Bill.'? Is this premise the reason for not reporting to the Parliament on the special reasons for the non-appointment of the Auditor-General? Is the Government considering the appointment of a company auditor operating under the final arbiter of the Auditor-General? In that circumstance, the Opposition would be happy with the amendments.
—The first part of Senator Watson's question was a bit disjointed; I wonder whether he could ask it again.
—I have taken it straight out of your letter.
—Senator Watson's question was quite disjointed and I would like him to ask it again.

—What is the basis for the Minister, Mr Simon Crean, coming to the conclusion that `it is unlikely that a company auditor would be considered for the Commission or Corporation being established under this Bill'? That is only the first part. I presume the Minister picked up the subsequent part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The experience so far has been that only one statutory marketing authority (SMA) out of so many has chosen to go to a private auditor. In answering that question, I refer by incorporation to the comments I made earlier in the previous Bill in respect to the question of a private auditor and the Auditor-General. I do not need to go through those arguments again, but I say that they are as relevant now as they were before. I think the fact that only one SMA so far has chosen to go to a private organisation is indicative of the inclination of statutory marketing authorities in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Without calling a division on this particular item, I do express once again the point of the Government that we are strenuously opposed to what is being proposed by the Opposition. Given the lateness of the hour and the inconvenience to senators, we do not intend to call a division on this particular point, but otherwise we would do so.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 8, page 8, subclause 8(1), line 17, at end of subclause, add ``including the Wool Council of Australia''.
4. Clause 30, page 16, subclause 30(2), lines 19 and 20, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:
``(2) Before preparing a corporate plan, the Corporation must consult with the Wool Council of Australia and may consult with any other representative of the wool industry as it thinks fit.''.

These issues relate to the consultation process that is important in this whole exercise and with regard to the appropriate relationships in the industry. Both of the amendments, which are very important in this particular issue, propose to include the Wool Council of Australia as an important part and an important body to be consulted with. The Minister will be well aware of the continuing relationships in this area, and I believe the argument is consistent with that which I have already proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has previously been canvassed, for similar reasons we support the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendments. Once again, were it an earlier hour of the day, we would take the amendments to a vote. However, given the fact that it is 1.30 a.m., we will not do so, but that does not undermine or underestimate in any way the opposition the Government has to the amendments, for the reasons expressed in the earlier debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 41, page 20, subclause (1), line 6, omit ``1 May'', substitute ``31 May''.

This amendment relates specifically to clause 42 and omits the date of 1 May and substitutes 31 May. According to the legislation, the Corporation must convene an annual general meeting of wool taxpayers by 1 May in each financial year. This is far too early for the setting of tax levels for the following year. The Minister would be well aware that he has received representations from the Wool Council specifically on this matter that recommend that the AGM be held before 31 May in each financial year. The Opposition contend that this amendment should be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government can at a stretch live with the amendment. However, in saying that, we recognise that it will make life difficult, to the extent that it will be much more difficult to get regulations made, for instance, for new tax rates effective from 1 July into any particular year. We obviously cut short the process by 30 days, and to that extent life will be much tighter for the organisation involved. For those reasons, we would oppose the amendment but, given the fact that both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats support it, we will have to live with the tightened timetable that the amendment proposes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1991
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 12, page 4, line 21, subclause (2), omit the subclause, substitute the following clauses:
``(2) The Council may make public a report or part of a report or a document connected with the work of the Council which has not been made public by the Minister.
``(3) A member or a deputy of a member must not make public under subsection (2) a report or part of a report or a document that has not been made public by the Minister or by the Council.''.

This matter arose basically as a result of representations that were made to the Opposition when the draft Bill was in a previous form as an umbrella Bill picking up a number of other commodity councils as well as the wool industry. The Australian Wool Industry Council Bill 1991 has been redrafted. It is acknowledged that the Government has substituted it on our program and we now have a Wool Industry Council Bill but, at the same time, we accept that the contention is just as important. The reporting and the process should be adopted as in the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment. If one goes to clause 6 of the Bill and looks at the functions of the Council, one sees very clearly that the function of the Council is to inquire into, keep under review and report to the Minister matters affecting the industry. The amendment moved by the Opposition basically means that the Council can and would be used as a body which would be dragged into industry politics. It does not seem to be in anyone's interest to so do, and it does not seem to be in the interests of good organisation of the industry to do it in this way. There is the risk of sections of the industry releasing an adverse report before it gets to the Minister. Opposition senators might think that that is good fun at the moment but, given the balance of probabilities, some time before the end of the century they will be in government and will have to live with that sort of effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic point is that what is seen here is inconsistent with so many other reporting processes in other areas of government. The report should go to the Minister and the Minister should then proceed with it. But to do what the Opposition is proposing-that is, to ensure that the report can be made public regardless of what the Minister so decides-is a precedent which really does not in any way assist the good functioning of government and has the hidden aspect of elevating industry politics to an unhealthy state.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is visible.

—Senator Watson talks about visibility. There are provisions for tabling, but we are talking about setting up good government. I am sure that that is the last thing that he would like to see happen. I can understand his base and crass opportunism at this stage, but he cannot deny that the basic function of the Council under clause 6, as has already been accepted, is to report to the Minister, and this amendment undermines that basic function and objective.

—The Australian Democrats have not been convinced that this is a necessary amendment-certainly not with regard to the fact that this could well be the first of many industry councils for which this could be seen as being a precedent. It would change the nature and role of industry councils which, as the Minister for Administrative Services quite correctly read to us from the Bill, is to report to the Minister. This amendment would not only undermine this Council but also set a precedent which is certainly undesirable for the plethora of councils that is being established and could be established throughout industries. We are not convinced that this is a necessary amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has to understand that again we have his variety of democracy. He points out that we will be in government. Yes, we will, but we will have our variety of democracy. We believe that if the Council gives advice to the Minister and puts up a report, and the Minister knocks it back and decides to keep the whole thing secret, that should not be allowed. We believe the Council has a right to say to the woolgrowers, `We have advised the Government this way'. If the Minister does not want to make it public, then we will tell the woolgrowers ourselves what the report is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's democracy is just different from ours. The Government says, `You won't like it when you are in government'. I can assure the Minister that we are different, and we will like it. We believe in open government and we believe in true democracy. That is the vital difference between the Australian Labor Party and our Party. They are totally different. It gets right back to the very basics of democracy. The Government likes to have it all in secret. If the Council advises the Minister and the Minister does not like it, the legislation says that the Minister should have the power to say, `We will keep it from the woolgrowers'. The Government likes it that way.

The Minister cannot comprehend that we on this side like open government, that we really believe in democracy. The Minister cannot put up a pretence. We like it. We believe that if the Council gives the Minister advice and he does not like it and does not accept it, then the Council has a right to go to the woolgrowers and say, `This is the advice we gave and the Minister did not accept it'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support my colleagues. This is about transparency. One of the problems we have had in the wool industry over recent times is a lack of transparency and a lack of credibility, and that all came about through the changes made to the Act in 1987. I draw the attention of the chamber to the editorial in The Land:

SPEECH.PARA: Wool's lost $1.8 billion.

Wool has lost $1.8 billion of growers' funds-it is here for everybody to see. What are the chances of their ever getting that back? If there had been proper accountability and transparency this may well not have happened. It is quite legitimate to have proper accountability, proper transparency, and to protect the growers' funds. After all, it is their funds that are in this scheme.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
WOOL TAX (Nos 1 TO 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1991
The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As foreshadowed, the Australian Democrats believe that this is the opportunity to reach a compromise on the invidious position in which the chamber finds itself. The argument for establishing a wool tax rate of 12 per cent instead of 15 per cent has been placed before this chamber. At this time I do not propose to rehash that statement. The amendment circulated in the name of the Australian Democrats reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), omit ``15%'', substitute ``12%''.

There is a slight amendment to be made to the text of the amendment which honourable senators have in front of them. I hasten to add that I was not responsible for the typesetting; it is a typographical error. I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to each bill:
Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), omit ``15%'', substitute ``12%''.

I have canvassed the argument, and I believe that it is well understood by those who have followed this so far. After I spoke earlier in the debate, the Opposition continued to push the case that a 10 per cent tax is the most appropriate one. Another matter was raised during that debate by various senators. It was suggested that there was some inconsistency in the Democrats' position in that we were suggesting that there was a looseness about the coalition's calculations when we ourselves stood accused of being cavalier in the amounts of money that were spent on behalf of taxpayers-that that was a contradiction. I think it was Senator Knowles who drew the attention of the chamber to that. I reject that because a major reason for our adopting the figure of 12 per cent is derived from a conservative evaluation of the situation. We were taking into account the suggestion made by Senator Tambling in a previous debate on the wool industry, when the Democrats were proposing that it was the responsibility of the Government to provide a contingency fund to ensure that supplementary payments could be made after removal of the floor price.

When the Democrats argued for that contingency fund of the order of $300m at least, we were roundly criticised by all contributors from the Opposition. It was suggested that we should `exercise some financial discipline', and those are the words I found in Hansard last night. They were the very words used by Senator Tambling, and I throw them back now. We are trying to exercise what we were asked to exercise in the previous debate-some financial discipline-and I would add the word responsibility. That is the genesis of our position. There needs to be an evaluation of the optimism. The 10 per cent figure is an optimistic position to take. If everything else is fine, if the weather stays good and if everything is right it could work, but the more disciplined and responsible position is the one which I am proposing now.

There are some other ifs, which I have canvassed and will not repeat. They are connected with things such as the availability of cash if and when the assets are sold. I noticed that in the Opposition's calculations it was assumed that cash would be available to be taken off the debt. That was in the very first column of the figures I was provided with just now. That is quite a large if. I agree that the non-wool assets of the Corporation should be sold as quickly as possible, but it is very optimistic to assume that those funds will be available to be removed from the debt immediately and in full, as depicted in the Opposition's calculations. That is the sort of optimism which I question, which I cannot endorse and which leads us to adopt the relatively conservative position of 12 per cent, which is consistent with our position throughout this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment before the Committee is important, and it has been the crux of considerable debate and discussion by a number of honourable senators today. I certainly commend the very detailed economic assessment that has been made in this area in the contributions by many honourable senators. At this stage I foreshadow that the Opposition will be moving a subsequent amendment to this one.

SPEECH.PARA: We clearly indicated and expressed throughout the debate that we felt that in the current economic climate-noting the current state of the wool industry and in light of the very considerable economic parameters that have been presented, which do amount to a matter of judgment and credibility-the figure of 10 per cent would be important, and I believe that we have been able to sustain that. But, more importantly, it is urgent that we also have a great deal of compassion for the tragedy occurring at the moment in rural Australia, particularly as it affects woolgrowers.

The Australian Democrats' amendment proposes a maximum figure of 12 per cent, and the amendment that I will subsequently move proposes a 10 per cent maximum. We have shown that this is credible, sustainable, sensible and essential if the woolgrowers of Australia are to survive. It is a question of making a choice between the sensible realisation of the Australian Wool Corporation's assets-$120m of Corporation assets equals 5 per cent of the levy-and the forced fire sale of assets and properties of woolgrowers. Such a choice should be in favour of woolgrowers for their future viability. Therefore, it is a sensible decision to require the Australian Wool Corporation's assets to be sold rather than those of woolgrowers and their families.

The figures presented by the Australian Wool Corporation indicate that only $40m of assets sales in the coming year are to be used for a reduction in the principal debt and are not to be used at all in relation to the debt servicing charge. If those Wool Corporation figures are used, if $120m in assets sales is used to assist in debt servicing, we believe that a figure of 10 per cent could be sustained. Indeed, as many of the charts that were considered indicate, and as many of the discussions suggest, a figure of less than 10 per cent could perhaps be more appropriate.

Senator Bell referred to whether the figure was optimistic. It is a matter of judgment and it is finetuning. At this stage it is very important that we weigh these issues carefully. I certainly invite the Senate's support of the foreshadowed amendment relating to a figure of 10 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support Senator Tambling at this point. The first year of this program will be the worst year. Sheep farmers all over Australia are having it tougher now than they have ever had it, and the situation is not likely to get any better. To put them under a 15 per cent regime would be absolute murder. It is something that I do not think any of us could justifiably live with.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the 12 per cent case that Senator Bell has put forward, but I do believe that we are in the position where we have to try to see what is the absolute minimum that we need to get in the first year. If, for any reason, the amount of money required is not adequate, it can be increased in the second year. But I believe that this figure can be sustained for the first year and that from there on there is no need for it to go any higher.

But we have to consider the industry as it is. The group of wool producers who will be most affected will be the younger woolgrowers, the ones newer to the industry, the ones on smaller properties and the ones on more remote properties: they are the ones we have to protect. That is the industry of the future. I think it would be criminal if we were to drive these people off their farms at a time like this by introducing a tax that we know now cannot be afforded. That is not the sort of thing that we ought to be taking too lightly.

Questions have been raised about the figures that we have produced to demonstrate the 10 per cent. Not one authentic argument has been raised by anybody anywhere in Australia against those figures. Nobody has been able to demonstrate that those figures are flawed in any way. We have done this over and over again in hundreds of runs. We can vouch for those figures in every way. Nobody has come forward and demonstrated that there is any possible error. We know that it can work on a 10 per cent basis. I go along with what Senator Tambling has said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said earlier on in my contribution to the second reading debate that the crunch would come with the figure we set tonight as to how many woolgrowers would remain on their properties. What I would like honourable senators to consider, before we make the final decision, is whether we sell that real estate first or last. The crunch is where we set the figure. Honourable senators must remember that that real estate, which was set up in Melbourne and in the south of France, was put there by the growers themselves-not by the Government, not by the Australian Wool Corporation and not by anybody else. Now that the growers are against the wall, let them make a decision, through us, to sell that real estate first rather than their own properties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision on this has been very elaborately spelt out. It does stand the test of most careful analysis. I state quite emphatically that both the Opposition's and the Australian Democrats' proposals do not withstand that test. The Government's decision for a 15 per cent tax rate was based on the most careful analysis of the Australian Wool Corporation's financial position and an assessment of future market conditions. We all recognise that the latter conditions are uncertain, but our approach aims to maximise the net returns to growers from the sales of current production and the net return from the sale of stockpiled wool.

SPEECH.PARA: What has to be recognised, and what I hope is recognised, is that the tax rate is just one part of the overall stock release and debt management strategy that the Government has put in place. A change to one component of this plan would place pressure on other components and threaten the achievement of the objective. If those opposite cannot understand that, then they are failing here as representatives of the people that they pretend to represent. If those opposite cannot understand that there is an overall strategy and that if one part of it fails that impacts on the rest of it, then they have failed in logic, in economics and as representatives; and those opposite will be exposed as such.

We make it clear that we are not about to change the fundamental structure of our package. Some in the Opposition have argued tonight, and at other times, that the parameters against which the Government arrived at 15 per cent are now outdated. That is not the case, because careful analysis does not substantiate this. Even the report prepared for the Wool Council of Australia by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd concluded that a change of less than 0.5 per cent downwards was all that was warranted. There is a long way between 14.5 and 10 per cent. As I say, the ACIL report was quite clear that a change of less than 0.5 per cent downward was all that was warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't quote selectively.

—It is unfortunate that the Wool Council has chosen not to release this particular report. In terms of substantiation, our figures have been assessed and reassessed but the Opposition's have not. The Opposition has not released the basic parameters and assumptions that its figures are based on, and while Senator Bell might smirk with a big smile on his face, nor have his figures been assessed. Tonight, only one side of this Parliament has come up with figures that have been assessed as being sustainable.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the figure of 9.1 per cent that was reached on 4 June, the debt start-off figure was too low-although I understand that this has now been changed-the production figure for 1991-92 is a bit lower than the recent official forecast, the debt servicing and storage costs are on the low side and the trade clearance rate is on the high side. The Opposition also assumes a significant income from assets sales of $120m in the first year. In a depressed poverty market, that sort of assumption is one which everyone would understand is totally and fundamentally flawed. What we have from the Opposition is a coincidence of optimistic assumptions. It can postulate a low rate of tax but it does not accept or acknowledge that if any one of its assumptions is out then its projected tax rate is blown. The Democrats understand that.

Unfortunately, the Democrats do not take the analysis to its logical conclusion and come to within 0.5 per cent of what we are proposing. Like the Opposition, they are playing bingo with us. They are playing bingo with the wool industry. Fifteen per cent is the figure that is sustainable by analysis. The Opposition has put up a figure of 10 per cent-it thinks that is a fair cop and it can sell that out in its constituencies. But I am surprised by the Democrats-what was wrong with 12.5 per cent? That is midway between us and the Opposition. The Democrats are playing bingo with the future of the wool industry and that is something that this Government will not tolerate. We have an extremely serious problem here tonight.

The future of the industry is very much involved here. It is one that depends on the recipe that we put together at this particular stage. If there is a basic miscalculation at this time, if one of the factors in the formula is out, the whole result is out. As I said earlier, the Opposition has put up a coincidence of optimistic assumptions. Even ACIL's report to the Australian Wool Corporation states that, given recent developments, the best one can look for is a 0.5 per cent reduction. Our analysis stands up to scrutiny, the Opposition's does not, but that is not uncommon in this place. What is also not uncommon is that we have our friends from the Democrats steering a midway course between it all without rhyme or reason.

The Democrats can play bingo with the lives of the farmers, but we will not. We will oppose any amendments on this particular point. Our view is that it is prudent to retain the 15 per cent tax rate for 1991-92. We have no intention of amending the legislation. We also state that within the scope of the uncertainties inherent in the assessments of the wool market in the future, recent changes in market conditions do not alter the outcome sufficiently for it to be prudent for the Government to reconsider the position of the 15 per cent wool tax rate for 1991-92. If we reduce the tax now there will be more impact and more of a burden on the industry in future years. The Opposition is making some pretty basic assumptions that are wrong. As I said, the sustainable evidence is that what the Government is doing is right, or very close to right. We oppose both amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services whether he will table the figures on which the Government has based its conclusion. The Opposition has not seen those figures and they should be made available to enable us to make an assessment of them. Secondly, I ask the Minister whether he will table information relating to the adjustment that has been made with the change in the production figures from 914 million kilograms to 881 million kilograms. Finally, the Minister tonight spoke about bingo: I say to the Minister that he has been playing Russian roulette with the wool industry tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane would appreciate that, if the Government were to do what he asks, it would jeopardise the future of the market.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically those opposite are economic anarchists. If the Government were to release what the Opposition is after, it would jeopardise the industry by the release of commercial in-confidence information. Opposition senators cannot deny-it cannot be denied-what the ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report commissioned by the Australian Wool Corporation made very clear: on the basis of changes in recent days, the best we can look at in a reduction of the tax rate is 0.5 per cent. That is as far as the Government is prepared to go and it is as far as anyone would expect the Government to go responsibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moment ago Senator Crane asked the Minister for Administrative Services to table his figures. The Minister went over to his public servants and asked them whether they had any figures to table. They shook their heads: no, they did not have any figures to table.
—How do you know?

—I am sure the Minister will not deny it because it was so obvious. The Minister then fudged around; no figures, nothing. All honourable senators on the Opposition benches tabled their figures during their speeches tonight. I incorporated mine, as did Senator Crane, Senator Chapman and Senator Tambling. How many more copies would the Minister like? The Minister says that Opposition senators do not have any figures. We have the figures; we asked the Minister to table his figures. His public servants tell him he does not have any figures to table. The Minister refused to table his figures. What else does he expect when he tells us that he has them?

SPEECH.PARA: A moment ago the Minister quoted the ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report. I have a copy of the wool tax rate for 1991-92, which contains ACIL's conclusion. For heaven's sake, if the Minister cannot get a copy from his public servants, he should listen to me. It says:
. . . 9.25 per cent wool tax would be sufficient in 1991-92 to meet the Government's minimum debt repayment requirement.

That is what the report says. The Minister should get it from his public servants. If they cannot give it to the Minister, I have a copy in my hand and I will give it to him. For heaven's sake, the Minister should not misquote things to us at 2.05 a.m. and expect us to be too tired to pick it up. We on this side of the chamber are not too tired: no doubt the Minister's colleagues are all sound asleep in their rooms. The Minister has no support, apart from two honourable senators presently in the chamber, and even the Government Whip is not here. If the Minister is going to quote the report, he should do it accurately. Would the Minister like me to read it to him again? It says very clearly:
. . . 9.25 per cent wool tax would be sufficient in 1991-92 to meet the Government's minimum debt repayment requirement.

Not 10 per cent, as the Opposition is going for, but 9.25 per cent. The Opposition's figures give the Government 9.1 per cent. As I said in my speech, we have a 0.9 per cent comfort zone, if that is what one likes to call it, but ACIL says 9.25 per cent. The Minister cannot find it: the public servants are trying to show the Minister where it is. I will come across and give it to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters!
—I can cross over; there is no standing order against my crossing over.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really resent the inferences that have been made by Senator Walters. I know that she means well. She and I have had quite a positive relationship in this place and in the previous place, and tonight she has jeopardised that.
—Oh, Nick! Where is my hankie?

—I hope that it is a woollen one. Quite seriously, what has been alleged tonight not only about me but also about the public servants who are here is something that I do not think I or the Committee should tolerate. I am being quite serious about this. I will table this document from Senator Walters. I do not know where she found it; it is a scrappy piece of paper, but it acts as research for the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic point I was making earlier on is that there has been advice commissioned by the Wool Council of Australia and that advice has come from ACIL. The Wool Council has chosen to keep that advice to itself, but it indicates that only a reduction of 0.5 per cent is justifiable. I really cannot cop, nor should people sitting in the advisers box, the sort of attack that has been made tonight. Given the provocation and intimidation by members of the Opposition, I do not think I have any option but to table the ACIL report of May 1991. In doing so, let me quote in full the summary of ACIL.

TALK.START.PARA: —We got up to date; so should you. We have updated figures.
—Senator Panizza can babble on all he likes. For God's sake, just hold on for a second.
—Babble on! Yes, I will babble on as much as I like.
—Senator Panizza, you will not babble on as much as you like. I call the Minister.
—Paragraph 3.11 in the summary in the ACIL report to the Wool Council of Australia is very clear.
—What date is it?
—It is dated May 1991. If I have to repeat it another time, I will. The summary states:

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, justifiable variation to the assumptions likely to have been used by the Government means that no change to the wool tax is required for 1991-92.
It is very clear. It goes on:
Some changes . . . work to reduce the rate of tax while others work in the opposite direction. Overall, the changes amount to a difference of less than 0.5 per cent.
In conclusion, fine tuning of the original assumptions used by the Government does not justify reduction in the wool tax for 1991-92 from the 15 per cent announced. The summary goes on:

To reduce the rate of tax below 15 per cent in 1991-92 would require some combination of deferring the payment of $20 million debt, capitalising some of the debt, extending the repayment period, selling wool from the stockpile, greater sales of AWC assets . . . These options are assessed in the following section.

I table this report because of the intimidation and provocation from members of the Opposition; I would not do so otherwise. I do not expect those opposite to be moved by this, because I have recognised, as have others, their incapacity to respond to rational argument. However, I now expect that the Democrats-who are much more attuned to rational argument, who are much more responsive, who can actually read, comprehend and respond to arguments such as this, who do not play the populist role that the Opposition plays continually-when confronted with this report and its conclusion will have no alternative but to support the Government on our retention of the 15 per cent tax rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I would like to remind an honourable senator that to assist with the dignity of this chamber it is better not to wander around to pass messages. We do have attendants in this place and I suggest that the honourable senator call upon the attendants to pass messages in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I am sure you are well aware of the fact that we are in fact pursuing an Australian Democrats' request at the moment. I wonder what the histrionics concerning various calculations contrived by the Opposition are really all about. I wonder how the figures with which the Government was asked to deal impinge on our proposition. If it were not so late it would be amusing to reflect on the fact that during the debate earlier there were at least two-and I think possibly three-versions, differently dated, of the now notorious ACIL Australia Pty Ltd report which has been referred to and now tabled by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I could pick one to table from any one of the half a dozen copies I have in front of me. I could table the one I have here dated 28 May, or I could table the one dated 7 June. I could dig about a little bit more and table one which agrees with neither of those. As Senator West was able to demonstrate in quoting selectively from part of the copy which she had, but which she did not date, it is possible to reach a number of conclusions. In fact, this very report has been used to substantiate a number of positions. One of those positions concerned the 12 per cent figure and we responded to that believing that the figures that were presented there had at least some possibility of being substantiated.

When I mentioned my reasons for not being attracted away from that position to the position adopted by the Opposition, I mentioned some of the assumptions that were made by the Opposition. I would like to refer to another document which has not yet been mentioned in this debate-that is a document prepared by the Centre for International Economics entitled Wool into the 21st Century. To spell it out a little more for those who are familiar with this debate, this document was endorsed by Jim Maple-Brown, Chairman of the Wool into the 21st Century Committee, and compiled by a well-known operator in this area, Dr Andy Stoeckel. I will quote eight or 10 lines from page 27 of that report. It states:

Attempting to show the difference in returns under different scenarios on a series of spreadsheets misses the point altogether since what should dominate the decision making is how to promote the efficient workings of a free market and the incentive to innovate. Combine all of that with the fact that we have no monopoly of power in the final marketplace into which much of our wool is going at the low prices prevailing now, it is obvious that the best policy is to offer all the stockpile to the trade at once.

That is an entirely different proposition based on the fact that we do not control the international market and we do not have any control over the things which influence that. That is one of the imponderables that have brought us to the situation which we are in now. We do not control the weather; we do not control the Russian market; and we do not control the Chinese market. We have no influence whatsoever over the acts of God which come to impinge on our wool industry.

I suggest that we stop the if's and but's and maybe's and look at the very few things we can see as tangibles in this area. One of them is the status of the stockpile now, which has been reduced marginally. I must say in passing that great mention has been made in the debate of the reduction of the stockpile to some 100,000 bales. As I understand it, those 100,000 bales have yet to be cleared; they have been offered. That is very much like the sort of proposition we get from the Opposition when it says in its selection of figures that $100m will be added to the calculations and reduced from the overall debt in the first year. That is a great assumption to make. That cash may or may not be available.

These are the sorts of vagaries that we have to take into account. In taking those vagaries into account I do not think we can tend towards the Opposition's position. The Government would do well to recognise the fact that the Opposition has just distributed an amendment which will introduce about 10 per cent. The Government should see that as a danger signal and perhaps realise that that amendment will be put. The way to prevent that amendment being put is to accept our request.
Question put:
That the request (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a difficulty here. Senator Bell, I think I should call Senator Tambling because he did foreshadow an amendment in his speech.
—He surprised us all with the lateness of the distribution. That is why I have moved mine now.
—I am sorry. What was that?
—Senator Tambling's amendment was distributed late and, in response to that, I have another amendment to circulate which is in the hands of the attendant now.
—On the assumption that it will not take long, I call Senator Bell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In response to the amendment which was recently circulated by the Opposition, I have a further amendment which proposes the rate of 13 per cent. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to each Bill:
Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), omit ``15%'', substitute ``13%''.

This request is also in response to the-I suspect-jovial suggestion from the Minister for Administrative Services that 12 1/2 per cent was a reasonable proposition. Here is half a per cent closer to the Government's proposal, and I invite the Government to entertain seriously this opportunity.

The Government should be considering seriously this amendment, because we have on our tables an amendment for 10 per cent which obviously the Opposition will be putting. I suggest that this is an opportunity for the Government to recognise that here is a chance to accept an amendment which is closer to whatever it was proposing and is further away from the position of the Opposition. Without elaborating the point, the proposal which we put at 12 per cent was the opportunity for the Opposition to grasp something which was realistic. This proposal is an opportunity for the Government to take. If this opportunity is not taken, then we will be left with what lies on the table-10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is very difficult for the Chair to hear. Senator Schacht!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Schacht is an expert in most areas, but maybe not wool. The Government opposes the further amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. Our view is probably shared by the Opposition in that, in a sense, what is happening at this late stage is somewhat of a farce. Figures are being plucked out of the air and we are not in that sort of game. We are in the business of a rational assessment of what is appropriate for the industry and for the industry's future.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do say that by moving this particular amendment, the Australian Democrats have had to do some pretty intense soul searching and, by doing so, recognise that the Government's position of 15 per cent is obviously the one that is much closer to what they are concerned about. If they move from their current amendment and adopt a 10 per cent figure, it makes a total farce of the process that has been entered into tonight. We say that 15 per cent is the figure that is sustainable by logic; we say that other figures are being plucked out of the air; and we also say that it is quite apparent that the direction of the Democrats is one close, and closer, to the Government's position on this matter. For them to be consistent, there is absolutely no logical, intellectually sustainable way that they would move from the direction in which they are heading to a 10 per cent figure. We obviously oppose the very late amendment of the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Would it not be more appropriate, at this stage, to consider the amendment moved by Senator Tambling? In terms of procedure and which amendments have been moved, I would have thought that the Tambling amendment would gain precedence over the Australian Democrat amendment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Perhaps it should have, but we have only one request in front of the Chair, so I will put that. I put the request moved by Senator Bell.

INTERJECT.PARA: Request negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment to each Bill:
Clause 4, page 2, paragraph (b), omit ``15%'', substitute ``10%''.

The debate on this issue has raged wide and far this evening. It has been a very considered debate with very considerable information put in. I remind the Australian Democrats of the very strong plight of the rural constituency at the moment, the tragedy of families in rural towns and the broader regional communities that are all dependent on this issue. I believe that all the issues have been properly addressed tonight in a very profound way. I invite support for the Opposition amendment.
Government senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear groans from Government senators. The consistent position that has been put by the Australian Democrats is that we have sought a figure less than 15 per cent. We are now looking at the third option, the third opportunity for us to vote for a figure less than 15. The position was stated in April and it has consistently been that we have argued that 12 per cent is the most appropriate figure. I have argued that strongly here tonight on behalf of the Australian Democrats. As a last minute opportunity for the Government to be able to sustain a figure lower than 15, I moved the amendment that was recently dismissed. We have no option but to accept the figure proposed by the Opposition.

—The Government of course opposes the request moved by Senator Tambling. In doing so, let me say that we are tonight witnessing a quite farcical game, and what I said earlier applies now. We are seeing a game of bingo being played with the lives and futures of members of the Australian wool industry. We will not and cannot tolerate that. Good government demands that we do not tolerate it. Those opposite would not know about good government. The basic point is that, in terms of the future viability of what is an extremely important industry in Australia--
—Next time you present the right report. This is the correct document in my hand.
—Senator Baume!
—Senator Baume calls that a crooked document.
—You gave us a wrong document.
—Senator Baume!
—That is an insult to those who produced it. We are used to that sort of--
—There is a later one, you silly fellow. Why don't you table the latest one?
—Senator Baume, you are warned.

—I have said essentially what I want to say. The Government's position is one that can stand scrutiny and is in the best interests of the short and long term future of this industry. We will not indulge in what I call a game of bingo with the Australian wool industry, a game that has been indulged in tonight by those on the other side for pure political opportunism. They have made a farce of the process and we will not sustain that. We will, I am sure, reject the request in the House of Representatives if it is carried by the Committee tonight.

—I rise in support of my colleague Senator Baume. I thank the Minister for tabling this document. Is he aware of and has he in his possession a later document from ACIL Australia Pty Ltd other than May 1991, the figures in which were based on a premise of February-March 1991, when the situation was far different from what it is today?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report that has been tabled is based on most recent presumptions. There is one page of a document that Senator Walters quite kindly managed to traverse the Committee and present to me tonight. If one looks at that report one sees that the assessments made therein are based on outside punts and assumptions which the Government does not accept and I am sure responsible commentators do not accept. That is the sort of document Senator Watson is referring to. That is the one the Government does not accept. We accept the full and comprehensive report that I tabled earlier tonight. On the basis of that, we will oppose the most recent amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the request (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

ROW.ENTRY: Senator Watson-As a small woolgrower I have an interest in the outcome of these proceedings. I declare my interest.
Senator Calvert-I also declare a similar interest.
The CHAIRMAN-Order! The time to declare interest is during the debate.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of that decision to support a 10 per cent tax, it is now necessary to move a consequential amendment and reopen the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991. Clause 25(2) of that Bill states that the Commission must receive an amount equal to 11 per cent. As a consequence of the last decision, that needs to be amended to 6 per cent and I would like to so move.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot move it yet. You can move it when I put the question that the Bills be reported. So I will put the question now in relation to those Bills that we just dealt with. The question is that these Bills be passed subject to requests.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bills be reported.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Crane) proposed:
Omit all words after ``That'', substitute ``clause 25 of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991 be reconsidered''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the Government does not support this proposal. As we have said consistently in the course of the debate this evening, we have come to the figures both in respect of the Bill we have just considered and this one based on the best economic advice available to us. We are not persuaded by the decisions made tonight, which are based on what we consider to be quite irrational assessments. That goes to this move to reopen debate on a previous Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, what has been indulged in tonight has been a game of bingo with the future of the wool growing industry in Australia. To the extent that the Government opposes that, we indicate now that we will oppose the request to the Bills when they go back to the House of Representatives. I also make it very clear at this stage that, if an acceptable solution is not reached and if the Government's sustainable assessment of 15 per cent is not achieved, what stands in place legally is a tax rate of 25 per cent. I think the Opposition and the Australian Democrats should take that fully into account. If that is the legally applicable rate at the end of this parliamentary process tonight, it is very much the responsibility of the other side of this House that that rate applies. It should be taken into account. Those opposite might think it is a great joke, but the sting in this process tonight will have to be copped by the Australia woolgrowing industry. The process tonight has evolved quite irresponsibly. I hope that the Australian Democrats do not fall for this move by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a question of falling for it. This is a consequential amendment and there is again no option. It would make a nonsense of the other proposition if we sought not to agree. It is ridiculous. We support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is 15 years since I have spoken in the chamber at 10 to three in the morning, so I just say that I support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crane's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN WOOL REALISATION COMMISSION BILL 1991
Ordered that clause 25 be reconsidered.
Amendment (by Senator Crane) proposed:
Clause 25, page 13, subclause (2), line 5, omit ``11%'', substitute ``6%''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have indicated that they will support this amendment. The Government opposes it. Given the fact that it is 2.55 a.m., we will not call for a division. However, we ask that our strenuous opposition be noted in Hansard. We will not be calling for a division, given the fact that it is late at night. However, that does not in any way detract from the fact that we are stridently opposed to this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has informed me that it uses direct mailing to distribute a range of periodic newsletters, booklets, and pamphlets to its client group and the wider community.
(2) The Commission does not separate the costs of this direct mailing as an item in Budget expenditure terms.
Since 1 July 1990 the Commission has expended $8,300 for direct mailing of material.
The anticipated level of expenditure to 30 June 1991 is $12,000.
Because of the relatively low cost involved, these costs are not separated as an item in Budget expenditure terms.

(3) The Commission has developed a database from which it operates its direct mailing. The mailing list comprises nearly 5000 names/addresses and has the capacity to be categorised by location/organisational classification/type of newsletter, report etc for despatch.
(4) The main direct mailing activities undertaken by the Commission this financial year have been associated with the distribution of three editions of the `ATSIC News' quarterly publication.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 15 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is the consultant employed by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to run the public consultation program for the Ecologically Sustainable Development Project.
(2) How much is this consultant paid and for what period will he/she be employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Capital Public Affairs Consultants have been contracted to coordinate the ESD public consultation program. Senior consultant, Ms Wendy Wicks, is the full time consultant attached to the ESD Secretariat to conduct the public consultation program.
(2) The cost of the consultancy is $51,000. The period of the consultancy is from March 1991 until the end of October 1991 when the ESD working group reports are scheduled to be finalised.
