QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the contract for the maintenance of the leased VIP fleet by a civil contractor, is there a `no strike' clause in the maintenance contract; if not, what arrangements have been entered into to ensure 34 Squadron activities are not affected by industrial action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A `no strike' clause is not included in the contract for the support and maintenance of the VIP aircraft for the RAAF.

Provision has been made in the contract such that, in the event that the contractor is unable to carry out its obligations due to labour disputes, the RAAF may utilise its personnel to carry out the contractor's obligation.
This provision includes access to the contractors premises and equipment as required. RAAF personnel are fully conversant with the aircraft and could undertake the required maintenance checks.
In the event of unexpected or local industrial action, normal VIP operations would not be affected since all turnround and routine maintenance checks are undertaken by RAAF personnel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the annual operating and maintenance cost of 34 Squadron under the lease arrangement, what hours were flown by the Squadron in 1990 in the VIP role, and in the defence role, and what were the comparative hours in each case in the last year of the old fleet.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: For FY89/90, the year of introduction of the new Special Purpose aircraft fleet, 34 Squadron flew 1841 hours VIP and 861 hours in the defence role on the new aircraft. For the current FY90/91, 34 Squadron has flown 2386 hours VIP and 895 hours defence to the end of May. For FY88/89, the last complete financial year of operations of the old fleet, 34 Squadron flew 3464 hours VIP and 1207 hours defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the stationery and stores requisitions filled by departmental offices and forwarded to Senators' and Members' offices outside the Australian Government Centre in each state:
(1) Are these delivered by Australia Post or by private courier and what is the deciding factor in the selection of the deliverer.
(2) What private couriers are used for these deliveries in each state, or are the same companies used throughout Australia.
(3) Was a tender called for each state for these deliveries or one Australia-wide.
(4) What was the cost of Australia Post deliveries of stationery orders to electorate offices in each state in the financial year 1989-90.
(5) What was the cost of courier company deliveries of stationery and supply orders to electorate offices in each state in the financial year 1989-90.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia:
Stationery and stores are delivered by both Australia Post and private couriers. Selection of carriers depends on weight of consignment, destination of goods and degree of urgency.
In addition, in New South Wales, some stationery and stores are delivered direct by suppliers.
Tasmania, Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory:

Stationery and stores are delivered direct by suppliers in Tasmania and, in most instances, in the Northern Territory. In addition, stationery and stores in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory are delivered by departmental officers.
(2) New South Wales-Comet Express
Victoria-IPEC, MACS Transport and AOT Services
Queensland-Comet Express, IPEC, Ansett Freight Express
Western Australia-Bring Couriers, Comet Express
South Australia-Comet Express, Tailgate
Tasmania, Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory-Nil

(3) An Australia wide period contract (PE 17 for the period 1 August 1989 to 31 July 1992) for the provision of national air and road freight has been arranged for use by Commonwealth Departments and Agencies. Where appropriate the contract services are utilised for deliveries to electorate offices. In addition, deliveries of stationery and stores have been made by other services. The reasons for selecting a particular courier service for a delivery will depend on the weight and size of the consignment, destination of goods, timely delivery and cost.

(4) New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia Australia Post deliveries were paid through the office franking machine and no separate records of costs in respect of stationery and stores deliveries are available.
Queensland-$3,692.29
(5) New South Wales-$13,984

Victoria-Some costs for deliveries also included charges for maintenance works and packing and cannot be separated. However, $13,265.13 of charges for courier company deliveries were costed separately.
Queensland-$4,930.34
Western Australia-$14,674.28

South Australia-Costs for most delivery services to electorate offices during 1989/90 were paid by the Corporate Services Group of the Department of Administrative Services, Adelaide and cannot be separated from other departmental charges. However, $1,650 of charges for courier company deliveries was costed separately.
Tasmania, Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory-No separate charges were made.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May 1991 (Hansard, page 3943), Senator Reynolds asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health the following supplementary question:

ANSWER.PARA: Could the Minister gain an assurance for the women of Australia that an officer who takes private legal action against the National Women's Health Program would not be required to be directly involved in the implementation of something to which he obviously does not have any commitment.
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Guidelines on Official Conduct for Public Servants cover the matters raised by Senator Reynolds and he would expect officers involved in the National Women's Health Program to abide by these Guidelines.
In this case, the doctor concerned has very specific responsibilities in the Department which do not touch on the matter on which he is taking private action.
The Government, of course, remains strongly committed to the women's health strategy and to funding women's health services.
